King SOLOMONS Portraiture OF Old Age. Wherein is contained A SACRED ANATOMY Both of Soul and Body. AND A Perfect Account of the Infirmities of Age, incident to them both. And all thoe Mytical and Aenigmatical Symptomes, expreed in the ix former Veres of the 12th Chapter of Eccleiates, are here Paraphraed upon, and made plain and eaie to a mean Capacity. By John Smith, M. D. E. Coll. Med. Lond. Cand. ET E. Coll. Aenea-naeni Oxon. quondam Com.

div.head: The Epistle to the Reader.
div.p:
WHooever thou art, into whoe hands this Paraphrae may fall, know that the Author of it, is not near enough any Nobleman to put it into his hands; nor hath he face enough (as is the mode of this daring Age) to call at a ditance; but could he do both, yet know alo he would do neither; for he deireth not, that any thing, either of others, or his own, hould be patronized beyond its own native worth;
And is himelf as willing, as any touchy-headed Decryers of Anatomy and Anatomits, of all Art and Artits; that all the hame that is due to the ill managing of this good Subject, hould return upon his own pa • e; And uch is his Allegiance to his King, that if he can but keep off their foul fingers from Him, to which they are apt enough, he cares not how heavy they fall upon himelf: And on the other hand, if there be any thing herein contained, of true value, it will but hine the brighter for the rubs and petulant endeavours of all Conductitious detractors; who being thrut out of ome mercenary Employments, in a few months time by their mother wit (which for want of good neighbours they greatly cry up themelves, and
intead of bad neighbours do cloely ininuate as if all others wanted it) can get knowledge enough in Phyick to contemn and vilifie, and in two words (viz. Galenits and fools,) abundantly confute all thoe worthy Perons, who from Childhood to Gray-hairs, have been tudying, endeavouring, and praying; have been exerciing both their minds and their bodies; their heads, their hearts, and their hands; that they may become expert Seconds unto Nature, and meet Combatants for all thoe dreadful Enemies that the Sins of man have tirred up againt the peace of his own body. But beide this cum of ill conditioned Zoili, there are others alo nipling at the heel of learned Phyicians: Whoe wounds though eemingly lightly inflicted, yet are
far wore than the former, and that not only becaue they are perons of credit and knowledge, but becaue they pretend Friendhip, and kis while they do the michief. Thee are thoe, whom Birth, Education, and Indutry, have o ecurely eated in honour, that nothing can poibly dithrone them, but that which cat the Angels from heaven, and man out of Paradice; that abominable
< in non-Latin alphabet > , which for ever did, and for ever will, et God in a reitance; and the bet of their Friends cannot but in time mind them, that thoe mart reflexions without caue, both in private and publick, not only upon particular perons, but upon whole Societies of men, (half of whom they know not o much as by hear-ay,) eem to have a tincture of that virulent
poyon, which as eaily and as quickly proceeds out of knowledge, as the Worm did out of Jonah, Gourd; and will (if not peedily prevented) oon wither into nothing all that content under which they have for a eaon gladly hadowed themelves. And here I am afreh put in mind of the Story of Herod, who perecuted the Worlds Worthies, and becaue he aw it pleaed the People, he proceeded farther alo: And thus proecuting his rage and ambition, in royal Apparel, and with Popular Oratory, the Angel of the Lord mote him, becaue he gave not God the glory, and he was eaten of Worms. That main and bet end, which ecureth all men in their undertakings, was it which firt moved the Author hereof to tudy acred Philoophy,
and to apply himelf to the interpretation of uch Scriptures, as border upon that Faculty unto which he hath betook himelf, ever ince he hath had the judgment of Election wherein he might be mot erviceable in his Generation. This was the good Seed: but falling into a barren and ill manured oil, hath for the preent, produced no better a blade, than what you here ee; which however, if it pleae the Lord to proper, may bring forth as ueful fruit as thoe that eem more fair and flourihing. Herein old men may ee their own natural faces, as in a Glas; and young men may foreee, what (if they live) will certainly betide them in their latter end. Sytemes and compleat Treaties (though out of fahion, and conequently
neglected in this Mimical Age) are of better ue, than fragments of Mechanim, and Independent Pieces of Experimental Knowledge, which by mot men at preent are had in greatet honour and reputation; But in this repect of honour, the ground-work of what is here dicoured upon, far urpaeth them all; the Author thereof being the wiet, and the greatet Earthly Potentate throughout all Generations. The Portraiture that is here drawn, is done by the hands of no meaner a peron than King Solomon, and may jutly be called,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; that uperabundant widom in natural things, which it pleaed God miraculouly to enrich him withall, beyond all that were before him, or ince to this very day; being no where more
Graphically delineated, than in this decription of Age; whereby it plainly appears, that Solomon was not like that forward Traveller, who was well skilled in Forreign Countries, and in the mean time knew little or nothing of his own native Land. For as he very well knew all Vegetables, from the Cedar in Lebanon, to the Hyop that pringeth out of the wall, and thoe Creatures alo of a •
higher rank, namely, all Beats, Fowls, Creeping things, and Fihes: So neither was he ignorant at home; but that wherein his greatet widom conited, was, that he perfectly knew himelf; And that Intus & in Cute; both in repect of the inward and the outward man: All the ecret and myterious powers of the mind were as naked and open before
him, as the viible parts of the Body are before a Vulgar Anatomit, and his < in non-Latin alphabet > in this Allegory contained, doth more fully and atisfactorily declare and ditinguih them, than whatoever hitherto hath been endeavoured to that purpoe, by the bet of Moralits; and as for the parts of the body, thoe appoite Symboles which are here all along the Decription brought to expres them, do abundantly declare his mot exquiite and exact knowledge in them all. Not only uch a knowledge, as was then attained in the World, or as hould in after Ages be attained by any; but uch an one, as was attainable, or as the Humane Nature was able to Comprehend; and whatoever certain Inventions in
Anatomy have crowned the ingenious Inquirers of ucceeding time, lie couched in ome one or other Expreion of this Allegory. Among many other things, it is here clearly demontrated, that Solomon perfectly knew, and as plainly as his Figurative Method would give leave, decribed the Circular Motion of the Bloud; the bet and mot ueful Invention of this Latter Age. And as for the Subject which is directly here intended, viz. the Decription of the Infirmities of Age, though it be Compendiouly handled by him, yet it is Compleatly done in all things appertaining thereunto, both Moral, Natural, and Divine. And indeed, what can the man ay that comes after the King? The mot knowing and
ingenious Perons in the bet enlightned Generations, can add no more hereunto, than they can unto their own tature: It only remains, that ome uch, give us the full Interpretation of what is here delivered, ince it pleaed the King to leave it to after Ages, inveloped with a Canopy of the ame widom that indited it. And if this weak Eay may excite any uch, for the future lovingly to Correct what is here amis, and to upply what is here deficient; it will be a mot acceptable work; but if for the preent, Courteous Reader, it may be of any ue to •
thee, as a Man, as a Schollar, as a Philoopher, as a Phyician, as a Chritian, follow the intimation that is here given thee, and I will follow thee with a good
wih, which I am ure hall be accomplihed for thee, and for all thoe, that honetly labour in Gods Word and Work? I mean,
div.closer: I bid thee God peed. J. S.

div.head: King Solomon's Portraiture of Old Age.

q.p: Remember now thy Creator in the daies of thy youth, while the evil daies come not, nor the years draw nigh, when thou halt ay, I have no pleaure in them
While the Sun, or the Light, or the Moon, or the Stars be not darkned, nor the clouds return after the rain.
In the day when the keepers of the houe hall tremble, and the trong men hall bow themelves, and the grinders ceae becaue they are few, and thoe that look out of the windows be darkned.
And the doors hall be hut in the treets, when the ound of the grinding is low, and he hall rie up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of muick hall be brought low.

Alo when they hall be afraid of that which is high, and fears hall be in the way, and the Almond tree hall flourih and the Grahopper hall be a burthen, and deire hall fail, becaue man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the treets.
Or ever the ilver cord be looed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the Citern.

div.p:
THE Oracles of God are given forth that the men of God may be made wie unto alvation,2 Tim 3. 15. and all thoe that through faith have themelves exercied
therein; hall, through grace, (the Spirit of God moving upon the waters,) obtain that mot deired end; but this main happines, is not the only, that may be acquired by earching the Scripture; for there are many natural things, the knowledge whereof may be better gained in one line of them, than in whole Volumes of confued Naturalits: Wherefore he that in the true fear of God hall apply himelf to them, may think not only to have eternal life, but by the way alo to obtain the true knowledge of mot things that appertain to this.M • t. 6. 33. Seek firt the Kingdom of God, and all other things hall be added unto thee. Solomon ought after nothing but widom, but ee what a gracious anwer he received, I have given thee a wie and an undertanding heart, 1 King 3. from v. 5. to v. 15. I have alo given that which thou hat not asked, both riches and honour, and I will lengthen thy daies. Thus it pleaeth God to deal with thoe who are incere, not only to give them their hearts deire, but to uperadd omewhat they were not aware of, that may be beneficial to them in their coure of life. Looking after the duty of man, which is compleatly et down in ver. 13. of this Chapter, I find before I come there, an Anatomical Enumeration of the ad Symptomes of extream Old
Age, And uch an one as I dare be bold to ay, is not elewhere to be found. When the widom of the omnicient God, through his Servant Solomon hall decribe it, why hould I earch any further? Aen • gmatical I confes it, and exceeding difficult; wherefore I have the more diligently applyed my elf to the Interpretation of it. And o much the rather, becaue I find various enes put upon the words, and carce any one hath, without interruption, carried the Allegory clean through the whole ix veres, as I judge it ought to be. And becaue a mitake in the parts of man, may caue a mitake in the literal iuterpretation, I (whoe tudy it hath been to be more vered in thoe than uual Interpreters) do take the liberty to endeavour explication, wherein, if beide my own atisfaction and content, I hall add any thing to others knowledge, I hall therein have a econd reward.

I am not ignorant of all, nor do I depie any, of thoe everal interpretations both Literal and Mytical, that everal learned and good men have been exerciing themelves in. There are that expound all this Allegory, or at leat ome part of it, to a tate of wickednes, to a tate of poverty,
• o a tate of piritual deertion, to a famine
of bread, or of the Word of God, to the everal diperions and Captivities of the Jews, to the detruction of both the Temples, and of Jerualem, to the obtinacy of the Jews, to the unprofitablenes of the Gentiles under their Minitry, to the Apotacy of the latter times, to the end of the world, and to the day of Judgment. I know God doth at undry times,Heb. 1. 1. and in divers manners peak unto the World by his Servants. And knowing this firt, that no Propheie of the Scripture is of any private interpretation; I know this from thence, that no private Interpreter whatoever is to bind up others to the meaure of his own undertanding. Now as I am againt no other, o there is no other againt me in this that I am about. All that can be aid concerning it, is, that it is low, and mean, and ordinary, however (confet by all) it is true, genuine, and proper. And this may be aid of it beyond all other whatoever; that it is the bais and foundation of all the ret. And every one of them receive their clarity of truth, from the Analogy they bear to this primary Interpretation; that is, that thee ix veres, are a true and proper decription, of the natural, infirm, and decrepit Age of mankind. That which the Latines call Aetas Capularis;
the age of him who is hortly to be taken; unto Death, or into the Coffin, or upon the Bier, or into the Grave; plainly the age of him, who is by Coure of Nature jut at his lat, and mut ere long necearily yield to inevitable diolution. There is in that language alo another word (which way oever we take its Etymology) that will excellently ignifie unto us the Condition here delineated. And that is Silicernium; for whether we take it, quai iliceâ herniâ laborans; he that is troubled with hard ruptures, as very old men for the mot part are, or Sili herbâ uurus, he that will oon call into ue uch an herb as was then accutomed to funeral entertainments, or Silentibus brevi Cernendus, he that will quickly be free among the dead; or latly, Silices cernens; he that by his age and infirmity is continually put in mind of his Tomb; or rather (that which eems to me mot proper) he that is bowed down with age, o that he cannot but behold the ground whereon he now tands, and under which he mut ere long be laid. And this anwereth exactly to the Greek word, < in non-Latin alphabet > .

I hall not take upon me preciely to limit the bounds of this decrepit tate, foramuch as they are various, in repect of
the dipoitions of mens bodies, of their coure of lives, and alo of the places and ages in which they live. The lives of the Patriarks before the floud were extended to almot a thouand years,Gen. 5. 27. and yet we read not of thoe ad Symptomes attending them, as attend us now at fourcore. About the time of the Floud, God abbreviates the coure of mans life, and eems preciely to et it at one hundred and twenty years.
• en 6. 3. I know very well mot men would have this Text to be undertood as a threatning only to the preent Inhabitants of the Old World, that it hould be o many years before the Floud wept them all away: But it eems to me (and not to me only) rather to intend the cutting hort of the life of man for the future.Joephus lib. 1. c. 7. For it is clear by the Context, that the Floud came upon the World within an hundred years after this denunciation; which was made when Noah was five hundred years old:Gen. 5. 32. Cha. 7. 6. And he was but ix hundred years old when the Floud of waters was upon the Earth. Now God doth eldome anticipate the execution of his Judgements in wrath, but doth often prorogue it in mercy. It is as clear alo, that many there were, even after the Floud, whoe lives were prolonged beyond this appointed period, but they
found it very burthenome and grievous, and mieries with their age dayly came upon them; the firt-born of death about that time began to devour their trength,Job 18. 13. and to take poeion of them in the right of him that was to ucceed. And they might then be aid to die, in the ame propriety of Language, as Adam did in the day wherein he did eat the forbidden fruit; but the Palmit gives a more exact account of this thing, which may tand firm to this very day:Pal 90. 10. The daies of our years are threecore years and ten, and if by reaon of trength they be four core years, yet is their trength labour and orrow, for it is oon cut off, and we flee away. But as the univeral Fabrick, that God at firt extracted out of nothing, draws nearer to its end, o doth every particular tructure therein made, weaken and decay. As the heaven and the earth wax old, Ia. 1. 6. o they that dwell therein hall dye in like manner. And therefore it is not to be thought, that in thee daies mans age hould be o long, nor o many arrive at it, as in the daies wherein the Bow of Univeral Nature abode in its greater trength. Nor can we exactly put the terms of any mans old age, o as to ay he is now old at this preent moment, but was not o before; for
it is that which creeps on by teps and degrees, as the hadow upon a Dial.

div.p:
Statutum est in Caelis. It is a tatute in Heaven,Heb. 9. 27. for all men once to dye; by vertue of which it is, that man mut necearily pas through all thoe various teps and paages, from the Womb to the Tomb, that are appointed unto him in that unalterable Decree. As ure as Man is born, o ure he mut pas along, and unles it pleae the Lord ooner by a violent troak to take him to himelf, he mut go from tate to tate, from age to age, and never tay, till he come to thee evil daies, and unpleaant years, mentioned in the Text. There was, it is probable, within the compas of the Creation, that which had a natural property in it to preerve mortal, yea, inful man without alteration.Gen. 3. 22, 23. Now let he put forth his hand and take alo of the Tree of Life, and eat, and live for ever; Therefore the Lord God ent him forth from the Garden of Eden to till the ground from whence he was taken. And when the Creatures hall be delivered from the bondage u • der which they now groan, this Panacea may again be retored to its Primitive ue: Then hall the leaves of the Tree of Life be for the healing of the Nations; Rev. 22. 2. but for the preent, this is kept from us by a flaming Sword, and therefore not to be attained unto. And I never knew any one touch
but the foot of that Mount, I mean, attempt any thing that is but analogous thereunto, but his work, if not himelf, was detroyed thereby. And as our Cae now is, he that made us, he can ave us; he that made the Sun, can caue it to tand till or go back at pleaure; and he that made man, can uphold him without thoe changes, which otherwie unavoydably attend him. And in the daies of wonder (when Shooes and Garments kept equal duration with mens fleh) o he did his Servant Moes, Deut. 29. 5. concerning whom it is aid, when he was one hundred and twenty years old,Deut 34. 7. his eye was not dim, nor his natural force abated. But this is his own Prerogative, when he pleaeth; In his ordinary Providence, as he hath et certain bounds that a man cannot pas, o he hath et certain other that he mut. Man that is born of a woman cometh forth as a flower, Job 14. 2, 5. he fleeth as a hadow; he fleeth from Infancy to Childhood, from thence to Youth, from thence to Strength, from thence to Full Age, from thence to Declenion, from thence to the State we are upon. And thus ome interpret the econd vere, While the Sun is not darkned, (i. e.) the prime of youth be not pent, the light of that Sun, is the full age; the Moon, is declining age; and the Stars, are
the beginning of Old Age; but this I judge not o primarily and properly the meaning of the place, as you will hear in this enuing Explication.

head.q: Vere I. Remember now thy Creator in the daies of thy youth, while the evil daies come not, nor the years draw nigh, when thou halt ay, I have no pleaure in them.

div.p:
THis Chapter begins with an Exhortation to the mot neceary duty of man, which is preed upon him by a double inconvenience that will certainly come upon him, and for the future render him uncapable to perform the ame. The lat and the greatet is that of death, decribed in the eventh vere: And this is the night wherein no man can work: The other is that of age, decribed in thee ixformer veres. And this is the Evening or latter part of the day, wherein
it is very ill working, and nothing can be done, in comparion of what might have been done before; let the neglect therefore of this duty for ever be annexed to a
< in non-Latin alphabet > , God forbid that any one hould defer the remembrance of his Creator untill he be not able to remember at all, or put off the work of the highet concern, until he be altogether unfit to perform aright any of the meanet: But becaue it is my preent deign only to meddle with the Allegory wherein is the decription of Age, I hall not detain you in this mot important entrance, but immediately fall upon my work. In this vere we have only a general decription of that infirm condition, which is more particularly treated of in the following veres.

Age though it naturally creeps upon all men, whatoever their Contitutions and Compoitions are, yet it is it elf a dieae. Senectus ipa morbus. And it doth certainly induce uch a Cachexia, or ill habit, that it renders us inerviceable to our ends, and doth as it were et open the gates, that all that troop of enemies may enter in, which follow here in their order.

Here are two expreions that intimate unto us the unavoydable approach of thee decrepit years (i. e.) come and draw nigh;
of which gemination, ignifying the ame thing, I may well ay, as Joeph did upon the doubling of Pharaohs dream;Gen. 41. 31. It is becaue the thing is etablihed by God, and God will hortly bring it to pas. Whooever we are, whatoever we are doing, whitheroever we are going, they are till coming on. Be we Male or Female, be we Jew or Gentile, be we bond or free, be we Princes or Subjects, be we what can be imagined, they come, they come: While I write, while thou readet, while we wake, while we leep; while we abide at home, while we go abroad; while we eat, or drink, or port; while we retire our elves, we pray, or fat; while we neglect our elves, while we defend all we can againt them, they draw nigh, they draw nigh. And that man who wrote a book,Gal. lib. de Mara • moc. 2. de non enecendo, lived to his own digrace, to ee his own errour confuted in himelf.

Here are two words alo to expres the continuation of this tate o long as it hall be, (i. e.) daies and years; both thee words ignifie alo the ame thing in the general, viz. how long this tate hall remain: And thus Jacob ueth them both, in giving an account unto Pharaoh how long his life had continued:Gen. 47. 9. The daies of the years of my pilgrimage are one hundred and
thirty years, few and evil have the daies of the years of my life been, and have not attained unto the daies of the years of the life of my Fathers, in the daies of their pilgrimage. But in particular, they intimate unto us a diverity of their continuation to divers perons. Some men pot over this bad way, and remain but a very little while in it; others pas over it more lowly, and continue therein much longer. Some have but a few daies of labour and orrow, others have them prolonged out to years. As the Lord only knows what peron in the world (for there are but few in thee lat Ages) hall be brought to this tate; o he only knows how long they hall remain in it. Whether this time hall be more or les, whether daies or years hall determine it, is to us uncertain, but this is mot certain concerning them both, that if they be at all, o long as they are, they hall be evil, they hall be unpleaant.

div.head: Evil daies.
div.p:
I here take the word evil in a good ene, that is, not for the evil of in, but the evil of miery, the fruit of in. I know there be them that would have this word, if not the whole Allegory, undertood of uch daies and years as wicked men, by
their giving themelves up to follow their own hearts luts with greedines, do voluntarily bring upon themelves; but it eems to me to be otherwie, and that chiefly from thee two reaons: 1. Becaue I find nothing in the Allegory that is not competible to every particular peron that lives to the time of this tate, both to the good and bad, both to the righteous and the wicked; Weaknees, infirmities, dieaes both of body and mind attend them all: Iaac, Jacob, Eli, David, as well as thoe who lead never o contrary lives, mut bear the burden of their age, if they live to the time. It is mot certainly true, a coure of wickednes doth wonderfully haten both old age, and death it elf. The wicked man hall not live out half his daies; Pal. • 5. 23. nor hall he keep off decrepitnes half the time;Pro. 5. 9 his honour hall be given away, and his years unto the cruel. And beide the hatening of thee evils, he doth infinitely augment them both for number & quality, he hall have a thouand fold more, and a thouand fold greater: Every ore hall be a Plague, and every ach hall be an hell unto him; but this is not the condition in this Text decribed, but the declenion of mans life as a man; and that from this econd reaon drawn from the Context
when I look immediately before the decription I find youth, mentioned: Remember thy Creatour in the daies of thy youth. when I look immediately after it, I find death, decribed, The dut hall return to the Earth as it was, and the pirit hall return to God that gave it. Now as youth and death, are appointed for all living, without any dicrimination of him that weareth, or him that feareth an oath, as terms à quo, and ad quem, of their pilgrimage; o this tate alo, as an intermediate tage, is as certainly appointed to them all, unles it pleae God before that contituted time, to give them a deliverance by immature diolution. It is aid of Old Age,
Auonius.
Expectata diu votique optata ecundis,
Objicit innumeris corpus lacerabile morbis.
Though this tate be never o much deired of men, yet when it comes, it brings along with it abundance of all manner of evils, as the following Dicoure will ufficiently make appear, and therefore may well be called, an evil tate.

But here I mut needs meet with this mot obvious objection:Prov •••• . Is not Old Age a great bleing from God,Gen. 15. 15. and are not gray hairs an honour,Gen. 25 8 do not you call that evil, which
God calls good?Judg. 8. 31. How often in Scripture is it aid,1 Chron. 29. 28. A good old age, and counted as a priviledge? I mut needs therefore here ditinguih of old age; and conider it in a threefold tate. Firt, Crude, green, and while it is yet in the beginning, while men are able to do buines, and go about their employments, and this is but one little remove from manhood, and doth immediately border upon it. The econd is, full, mature, or ripe age; when men begin to leave off their employments, and betake themelves to retirednes; when God hath no more work for them, and they have no more trength for him; or latly, extream ickly, decrepit, overgrown old age; in which it may be truly aid,Job 30. 2. Old Age is perihed; when their breath is corrupt, when their daies are extinct, and the grave is ready for them: Job 17. 1. And this only is the tate the Wie man here o Rhetorically decribes. And that age which is o often called good, I take to be the econd before mentioned tate; and o much the rather, becaue in mot places where it is aid, they dyed in a good old age, it is alo added, and full of daies; by which I undertand, not a fulnes of poibility, that they lived o long, as from the principles of their Compoition, they could not
have lived any longer; but a fulnes, as I may o ay, of atiety; they had enough of living, they lived as long as living was good, they lived to a full, ripe, and mature age; uch an one as would force them, to be of the mind with him in the Fable, to refue immortality in this preent life; and earnetly to deire it in a better.Tithonus There is an excellent illutration of this in the peech of Eliphaz, wherein he ets down the pecial Providences of God towards them that fear him, and are bette • ed by Correction;Job 5. 26. Thou halt come to thy grave in a full age, like a hock of corn in its eaon: Now if a hock of Corn tand very long in the field, it heds, and is poiled, and the eaon of it is as well lot, as if it had been taken in too green. Jacob, mot certain it is, died in this good old age as well as others; yet he himelf aith unto the King, a little before he died, that the dayes of his years were few, and he had not attained the dayes of the years of his Fathers in their pilgrimage.Gen. 47. 9.

Had St.2 Tim. 4. 6, 7. Paul departed when he had fought the good fight, finihed his coure, & kept the faith, and was ready to be offered; he had urely dyed in a good old age, although his pule had not then beaten above threecore years Now, mot certain it is,
that the arriving at this tate is one of the greatet outward bleings that man is capable of in this life. Nor dare I ay otherwie, if it hould pleae the Lord to protract the life of man to the extreamet point it is capable of; If he hould withhold his hand from puhing down the houe which he hath made, and let it fall to decay upon its own principles, his forbearance would be the greater, its fall would be the leer; however in the mean time, it would tand mot ruinate, deformed, ueles, and incumbred with infinite inconveniencies, that it was never lyable to before; He • quam continuis, & quantis, longa enectus, plena malis. But this is not all, it is not only an evil age, but there is no pleaure in it; As there is no condition that frail mortality is capable of o good, that hath not a participation of evil; o there is carce any condition o evil, that is not attempered with ome good; but this eems to be excluded from uch a mercy as this.Prov 31. 1 • . It is aid of a good Companion, he will do a man good, and no harm all the daies of her life: But contrariwie, it may be inverted concerning this bad and moroe Companion, he will do a man evil, and no
good, o long as he continueth with him.

div.head: I have no pleaure in them.
div.p:
I take pleaure here alo in the bet ene, not for any inful content whatoever, not for the luts of the fleh,1 Joh. 2. 16. the luts of the eyes, or the pride of life; but for thoe lawful pleaures and repats both of body and mind, that the nature of man, while able, might comfortably have olaced her elf in. The mind of man buiing it elf, and taking contentment in the peculation of natural caues, the body of man in all its outward enes, in all its internal appetites, porting and refrehing it elf in all proper and peculiar objects; but no uch refrehments as thee in old age; which is a principle o well known to be true, and o much rooted in the judgment of men; that the news to the contrary (though brought immeditely from God himelf) did, at the firt, tartle, and put a very hard tres too, upon the faith both of the Mother, and Father of the Faithful. Pleaure in old age, (and to uch perons who were as good as dead, and with whom it had ceaed to be after the manner of men and women) was uch an incredible thing, as both Sarah and Abraham laughed at the
news; which laughter, as it might proceed partly from a confident affiance upon the Word of God, and a contentation thereupon,Gen. 17. 15, 16, 17. (as is uually aid,) o partly without all doubt, from that reluctancy they found in themelves,Gen. 18. 11. and thoe heart-riings, and internal arguings againt the reception of thoe joyful tydings; the pirit indeed was ready, but the fleh was weak. And this will ufficiently appear in the Text, from the grounds of their laughing, their reaoning thereupon, and from the Lords anwer to them both, and what pains he takes, and what arguments he ueth further to perwade them, that it hould be o indeed as he had promied.

There is a learned Commentator aith upon the word < in non-Latin alphabet > here tranlated pleaure:Lorinus. Hebraea vox non modo voluptatem, ed etiam negotium quodlibet opuve ignificat; The original word, aith he, ignifieth work and buines,Eccl. 3. 1. as well as pleaure. And o indeed it doth, and may very well do in this place. When decrepit age is come, a mans work is at an end, he is able to do no more.Eccl. 9. 10 Solomon aith, there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor widom in the grave whither thou art going: Now o • d men are very near it; our Englih Proverb is, They have one foot in the grave;
they have no more work to do, their coure is finihed, and their time of departure is at hand.

head.q: Vere 2. While the Sun, or the Light, or the Moon, or the Stars be not darkned, nor the clouds return after the rain.

div.p:
HAving before in general hewed this tate to be mierable, he now comes to tell us wherein thee mieries particularly conit. I mut here be neceitated to go an untrodden path, and poibly an unacceptable one to ome. As for all thoe Interpretations that are beide the Allegory, you know I have already waved them, and therefore hall not o much as mention them in this vere, nor in the whole enuing Dicoure. As for thoe that ay, the Sun, and the Light, the Moon, and the Stars, ignifie the everal Ages that man mut pas through, as was before hinted; they make this Allegory, not o much a decription of old age, as of the way to it, and therefore are not to be admitted: foramuch as this is the decription of compleat and perfected decrepit age, as you
have already heard. There are that take thee Luminaries abolutely literally, for the everal heavenly bodies as they tand fixed in their Orbs, and differing from one another in glory. But unto man in this tate they are not really darkned, for as they communicate of their light and influence equally both to the good and bad, to the jut and unjut; o alo, to the young and old, to the trong man, and to the feeble, by reaon of his age. And then it mut of neceity be undertood, per Hypalagen, only that they appear o to them, by reaon of their inability to receive their light, and by reaon of the weaknes and dimnes of their outward ene. And o this opinion will in effect coincide with the following, which is indeed mot coniderable. And that is, that thee lights are metaphorically here expreed, and do principally allude to the lights of the body. And this interpretation doth principally and primarily arie and take its authority from the Chaldee Paraphrae; which is by Interpretation as followeth: Antiquam mutetur plendor gloriae faciei tuae qui aimulatur oli, & lumen oculorum tuorum antequam obcaecetur, & decor maxillarum tuarum antiquam obtenebrecetur, & pupillae oculorum tuorum qui aimulantur tellis
antequam extinguentur. And after this, men of very great names have walked in the ame teps. But as mot other Interpreters eem to train the Metaphor too far, and carry it beyond the ignification of the natural parts of man; o thee eem to me to draw it too traight, while they keep it within the compas of the external parts of the body. And o much the rather, becaue by this Expoition is intimated only the change of the countenance towards deformity, which is ufficiently elewhere expreed, as you will hear anon; and the dimnes of the ight, which is far more plainly expreed in the latter end of the third vere, nemine contradicente. And that in this brief decription the Wie man hould tautologize, is not to be uppoed. On the other hand, it is not to be imagined, that any infirmities appertaining to this tate, epecially thoe of the mind, which are the greatet of all, hould be neglected herein.

Now as Delilah aid to Sampon, Judg 16. 17. Thou hat mocked me thee three times, and hat not told me wherein thy great trength lyeth; o might it be aid of Solomon, if he hould
take upon him to decribe any thing, and do it but in part, and o deceitfully, that he hould neglect the principal part, wherin the great trength lyeth; but I am otherwie perwaded; that he hath here told us all his heart, and that there is no remarkable infirmity, either of body or mind, that belongs to age, which is not contained in this Allegory. Now foramuch as all the Symptomes in the four following veres belong properly to the parts of the body, as you hall hear. I take this vere to be a decription of the infirmities of the internal powers of the oul; and why mot Divines do on et purpoe avoid this Interpretation, which is o plain and obvious in this place, I cannot tell, unles it be becaue they are o much taken up with the contemplation of the oul of man, that they forget it hath any thing at all to do with the body. There is a vat difference between the oul of man as it is in its united tate, and as it is in its tate of eparation. It is not ent from heaven into the body as an aitant only, or like ome tutelar angel, with Commiion and full power to guard, protect, and counel that peron, towards which it is for a eaon the deputed Miniter. For if o only, then it might recount and tell us, how curiouly it wrought for us in
the lower parts of the earth, and what wonderful Idaea's it had before it, to have done further for us in that darkome region, had we been capable to receive them; yea, then it might accompany us beyond our pilgrimage, remaining in the body even after diolution, and taking care for our burials.

But the Cae is far otherwie, it is ent to inform the matter, and together with it to make up one Compoitum, the man being not the one, nor the other; but mot properly that which doth arie from the perfect union of them both; and whatoever is predicable of the whole, is predicable of the parts united; whatoever may be aid of the man, may be aid of the body and oul united; and as they are throughly joyned together, o they do intimately participate one with another, they are cleaned, they are defiled together; they are bound, they are looed together; they are well, they are ill together: If the fleh upon him have pain, Job 14. 22. the oul within him hall mourn; they grow up together, they tand together, they decay together. How often are perons in Scripture aid to grow both in mind and body, and eminently concerning our Lord, which is intar omnium; he encreaed in widom,Luk • . • 2 in tature, in
favour both with God and man. The oul is as weak as the body, both at firt and lat; Senes bis pueri, is a known maxime, and dayly experienced; and by all men undertood of the feeble undertanding. Anima comes into the world, tanquam raa tabula; and it goes out tanquam deraa. The oul appears at the firt as an unwritten Table-book, and when it diappears at the lat, it becomes blanck as it was before. Jobs pious and patient exclamation,Job 1. 21. Naked came I out of my mothers womb, and naked mut I return, may be wel extended to a eparation, not only from the goods of the body, and etate, but from thoe alo of the mind; which hath nothing at bet, but the begining and ground-work whereof at the leat, is picked up from the Communication of the outward enes, and when thoe publick Intelligencers fail, o alo doth this their Lord and Mater. And therefore by the Sun, Light, Moon, and Stars being darkned, we do poitively aert to be meant, the mot inward powers of the mind, in this tate do, together with the outward members of the body, weaken and decay.

But it may be here aid, is the whole inward man liable to this decay? Is there not omething in man, while in this tate, altogether
independant of the body? and perfectly free from the frailties of age? Doth not the Scriptures in many places eem to peak of renewed trength in this tate of weaknes, and plainly prove, that while the outward man decayes, 2 Cor. 4. 16. the inward man may be renewed day by day; for the right undertanding of this, and everal uch places as thee are, we mut of neceity ditinguih of the inward man. There is the inward man of the head, (as I beg favour to ay, ince the oul of man there chiefly doth exercie its principal faculties,) and (ince the other contraditinct term is o appoitely given in Scripture, viz.) the inward man of the heart; plainly, there is the inward man of nature, and the inward man of grace; there is the inward man of the firt birth, and the inward man of the econd birth, or of Regeneration. Now I peak here concerning the former of thee, that hath its decayes as age comes on, not at all concerning the latter; And as I have before excluded a tate of in from the Text, o I do here wholly exclude a tate of grace. The partial falling from divine grace, is not o much as aimed at in this place of Scripture, as the total not in any. Mot certainly true it is, that the work of grace tands upon its own foundation, not
at all depending upon the principles of humanity, either for its Creation, or Renovation; foramuch as the holy Spirit of God, who is as much at liberty as the wind, is both the begetter, and the trengthener.Joh. 3. 4. And as a man may be born when he is old, contrary to the reaon of Nicodemus, o alo may he be freh and flourihing in his old age; Thoe that be planted in the houe of the Lord hall flourih in the Courts of our God, they hall bring forth fruit in old age, they hall be fat and flourihing. Pal. 9 • . 13, 14. David prayes, O Lord when I am old and gray-headed forake me not; piritual deertions, and piritual manifetations, are immediately handed out from God, and do not at all depend upon the mutability of the nature of man, nor accompany him in his everal changes.

They are only the everal lights of nature, which, as age comes on, fall to decay without remedy. Now, as God, in making of the greater world, aid,Gen 1. 14, 16. Let there be lights in the firmament of heaven to devide the day from the night; And he made two great lights, the greater light to rule the day, and the leer light to rule the night; he made the tars alo: So alo hath he done in the little world of man; he hath made two great lights, (as they are
et down in this vere,) the one, viz. the greater, to rule the day of man; which is that clear hining part of man, whereby he is differed from all other created beings whatoever, and dicerns himelf o to be; and this I undertand by the Sun, and the Light: And the other, viz. the leer light, to rule the night of man, which is that darker dicerning part of man, that hath very little, or no light in it elf, neither doth ditinguih him from irrational Creatures; And this I undertand by the Moon; he made the Stars alo, as it followeth yet more plain.

div.head: The Sun.
div.p:
By the Sun, I undertand here the mot uperiour power of the rational part of the oul of man, that primary light of the undertanding, that doth at once both receive the pecies as they are communicated from the Imagination, and alo render them intelligible to the mind; that pure innate light of the mind, without which no man that comes into the world, can either apprehend what is from without tranmitted to him, or actuate any of thoe phantames which are already impreed. This we may ee illutrated by the light of the body, which is the eye: For in the eye
there could be no perception of any outward object, unles there were an inward implanted light in the proper Organ, which doth both dipoe it to receive the viible pecies, and render them proportionable to the Organ, giving them thereby actual repreentation. Now that which this implanted light of the eye doth in viion; the ame doth this Sun of the oul in the undertanding.Prov. 20. 27. This is that which in Scripture is o often called the Spirit, or the pirit of the mind. And ometime in a ditinction from the oul, as where it is aid,Eph. 4. 23 I pray God your whole pirit, oul and body may be preerved blameles to the coming of our Lord Jeus. 1 The. 5. 23. Now, becaue this is a difficult poynt, and hath gravelled mot undertakers, I will give one Eay more, and that from Scripture-light, which hitherto may not have been taken notice of, to the preent purpoe; It is aid, The Word of God is quick and powerful, Heb. 4. • 2 and harper than any two edged word, piercing even to the dividing aunder of oul and pirit, and of the joynts and the marrow. Among many other truths this place doth afford us this for one; That it is very difficult to divide or ditinguih between the oul and the pirit, becaue there is an intimate Communion and Conjunction
between them; uch an one, as in ome meaure bears proportion with that, which is between the joynts and the marrow. Now becaue this latter of the parts of the body, (though hard in it elf,) yet is far eaier to be undertood, then that former of the parts of the mind, let us well conider this, and poibly it may give us ome light to the other. The joynts are the turning places of the body, upon which all the actions of the limbs are performed, and therefore they are articulated everal waies, according as the poition, alteration, motion of the adjacent parts do require; thee are the mot viible acting parts of the body; The marrow (by which we are to undertand not the medulla oium, the marrow of the bones; but the medulla pinalis, the marrow of the back; for this hath much more intimate communion and conjunction with the joynts than the other hath,) is the apprehending and intructing part of the body, that which carries the impreions of external objects to the inward ene, and reconveys the mandates thereof to the members of the body, to be put in execution upon the joynts.D. Willis, c. • 9. Ejus munus et pirituum copias & motuum obeundorum instinctus extra deferre, atque enibilium impreiones intus convehere; this
is the ecret inward influencing part of the body. In like manner, the oul is the mot apparent active part of the mind of man, whereupon all its operations, both peculative and practical, are turned and performed; of which there is a particular account given in the explication of the following word: but the Spirit is a more myterious, and hidden power, that doth mot ecretly, and undicernably, both gather up thoe intimations that come from without; and alo give forth an effectual influence upon the whole inward man, to put all its well regulated Commands in execution upon the oul: Both which offices of this Sun (viz. both of reception from the outward enes, and actuation of the inward) is very clearly expreed in that peech of Zophar unto Job; I have heard the check of my reproach, and the pirit of my undertanding caueth me to anwer. As if he had aid, I have received through mine ears the ound of my reproach, and an anwerable impreion is made upon my pirit; and the ame pirit alo hath drawn forth my undertanding into act, towards the formation and production of an anwer. And this is the contant manner of the operation of mans undertanding; this is alo that part of the mind, which Aritotle, and
all his followers, meant by their Intellectus agens; this is that Candle of the Lord, or light within them, which the unound Teachers of old,Pelagi •
and thoe more innocent ones of late, would have to be a ufficient guide to everlating life: But if it be o, it will be good hearkening to it, while it doth remain in its trength; for this Sun alo, as years come on, doth certainly decline, and great mut that declenion be. For if the light of the body, Luk. 11. 34. which is the eye, be darknes, great mut that darknes be; much more urely if the light of the oul, which is the Sun, be darkned, how exceeding great mut that darknes needs be: Indeed, there mut be a defect in the whole undertanding, when this primum mobile can crace act any longer; and therefore it is, that the Apotle peaks concerning the piritual undertanding, alluding therein unto the natural;Eph. 4. 1 •
Having their understanding darkned, through the ignorance that is in them, becaue of the blindnes of their heart. When there is ignorance to receive, and blindnes to guide, in this principal faculty, all thoe which are thereby acted, mut certainly be weakned, as the next word doth clearly import.

div.head: The Light.
div.p: By the light therefore, I undertand all thoe more inferiour powers of the rational part of the oul of man, that are any way et on work by vertue of the principal Agent; which is an efflux from the before mentioned Sun; the Poible undertanding alo, in all its operations participates in like manner of this tate of weaknes. Now the operations of mans undertanding are various, both ad extra, in repect of the Objects; and ad intra, in repect of the will.

The firt, are peculative, the lat, are practical. The firt (whereby the undertanding is converant about things as they have in their own nature a ditinct being) are principally three. The firt is perception, or the imple apprehenion of an object, from the immediate impreion thereof by the minitry of the before-mentioned Sun. The econd is Compoition, or Complexion, whereby we try, and weigh the particulars that we have before received, and compound, and divide, joyn, and eparate one thing from another, as may be mot convenient for the improvement of them, to their appointed ends. The third is, reaon, or dicoure, whereby
we gather up to our elves omewhat farther than we undertood before, and make our elves maters of a new and better knowledge, which the things themelves received, as in themelves, could not adminiter.

The lat (whereby the undertanding is converant about things as they are good or evil) may alo be reduced to three. The firt is Concience, which is a reflection of the undertanding upon a mans actions, together with a entencing them to be good or evil, according to thoe unquetionable principles which are already received. This is the earch which the Candle of the Lord makes in the lower part of the belly.Prov 2 •
27. The econd is direction, or judgment, whereby the undertanding doth propoe an end to be deired and proecuted, the execution of which, that is, the reting atisfied in, and deiring of that end, is that which Morallits acribe to the will, and term < in non-Latin alphabet > . The third is Conultation, or < in non-Latin alphabet > , the reaoning about the means to attain that end, together with an Inquiition and Collation of everal means among themelves, and an election of thoe which are mot proper, the embracing of which, and putting them in execution, is that which they call < in non-Latin alphabet > .

Now thee, and all the operations of the rational oul, however they may be ditinguihed, have in this tate an anwerable imbecillity. Be a man never o apprehenive, be he never o ingenious, be he never o rational, be he never o conciencious, be he never o judicious, be he never o prudent; when his Sun begins to et, and his light to decline, he mut become weak as another man, nay, weak as a child. And this the Author of our decription here, though he o well knew it, and foreaw it, yet was not able to prevent it in himelf, but found his own words adly verified in his own condition. For it came to pas when Solomon was old, that his Wives tu • ned aw ay his heart after other Gods; 1 Kings 11. • . he that for undertanding urpaed all men, ince God gave unto him widom more than to any man, before him, or ince, to this very day; And for light of Concience alo,V. 5, 7. ince the Lord had appeared to him twice, yet, when he was old, he fell to uch irrational, • ottih, eneles abominations, and that only by the • eduction of women, as nothing but the frailty of age could poibly have given way unto.

Now as the oul is, by reaon of age, weakned in the directing part, which
uually is called, the undertanding; o alo in the executing part, which uually is called, the will. Old men when they do apprehend an end, and the means to attain it, they haeitate about proecuting the mandates of the mind, and tand for the mot part timorouly and child-like at, hall I, hall I. I find one Commentator upon the place ay, Non fruitur libero arbitrio. Lorin ••• . There is not a ready embracing, nor a free acting towards the attainment of what is by the undertanding firt dictated. Farther yet, old men are very eaily drawn off, and lead aide from their own intentions, every weak uggetion is too trong for them, and takes them Captive at pleaure; and as our Saviour aid to Peter, though in another ene, o may it be aid to every one who hall live to the time, When thou wat young, thou girdet thy elf, Joh 2 • . 18. and walkedt whither thou wouldest, but when thou halt be old, another hall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldet not: A man hall not then be mater of his own actions, but be very liable to the eductions of whomoever hall beet him.

And thus by thee two words, the Sun, and the Light, you perceive is meant, the whole rational oul, with all its powers and operations, as it may be found exerciing
it elf both inwardly and outwardly. And though here be two words more ignificantly et down, for the fuller and clearer manifetation of what is here intended, yet it might have been expreed (though not o plainly) by one word only. And therefore it is, that the Syriack Tranlation, and ome followers of it, have only the Sun expreed: Antequam Sol obtenebrecetur: for the Sun may ignifie, not only that light which is contained within its own body, but all thoe Emanations that illuminate whatoever is thereby enlightned. And the womans Candle in the Gopel, by which he found her groat, might ignifie, not only the light in the Candle it elf, (which anwereth here to the Sun,) but all the light in every part of the room alo, (which anwereth here to the light.) And thus we find the greater light, which rules the day of man, to be darkned; the leer, which rules the night, is that which followeth.

div.head: The Moon.
div.p:
By the Moon we mut undertand that other part of the oul of man, which is not in it elf rational, < in non-Latin alphabet > , Aliquo tamen modo rationis particeps. I confes, reaon may in man have ome
influence upon it, but in its own nature it is altogether devoid of it; it is that part of the oul which is uually called enitive, and is common to all other animals as well as unto man; and in him is but the leer light, and ruleth but the darker part only, and therefore may be mot aptly expreed by the Moon. It is converant principally about thoe pecies which are communicated to it, from the outward enes; the operations about which are either imple, or compound: The imple operations are firt to receive them as they are communicated from without, and then to retain them for o long time as it is exerciing it elf about them. Secondly, To dijudicate them as they are in themelves, and to dicern them as they differ from all other whatoever. The Compound operations are excellently decribed by a modern Author of our own; who aith,Dr. Reynolds upon the faculties, p. 24. that the liberty of the Imagination is threefold, Either Compoition, or new mixing of objects; Tranlation, or new placing of them; Creation, or new making them. Now all thee, or whatoever ele may be comprehended within the compas of the pure enitive part of the oul, are but the operations of one faculty, and therefore by one word, are mot fitly here expreed.
And though the Philoophers have uually ditinguihed them into more, as into the common ene, the Phanie, both Etimative, and Cogitative; yet really and truly they are but one: for as one uperiour faculty in the uperiour part of the oul, which is the undertanding, could both receive, compound, and collect, as you heard before; what hindereth but the ame may be done in the ame manner in the inferiour? And we are not to multiply faculties without neceity: Beide the ground of their variety is not to be admitted. For they uppoed the operations about their objects to be divers, attributing perception and dicerning to the common ene only, dividing and compounding to the Phanie.

Now the phanie doth as well perceive and dicern, nay, better too, than the common ene doth; and the common ene may be aid to compound, and divide, as the phanie doth: Therefore ome, more quick ighted of late, perceiving this ground not ufficient, that they might be ure to uphold Aritotles diviion of the inward enes, have found out another way, and ay, that the common ene is converant about a preent object only, the Phanie about that which is abent; but this eems as
weak as the former, and that according to the Peripatetick Doctrine; foramuch as the Phanie is converant about an object only while preent with it; Indeed it can detain it a while, untill it have done its work about it; o can <> common ene alo; And it can receive it again after it is paed away, and <> upon it anew, but for this it mut be beholding to the memory, and can do nothing upon an object by its own trength, but while it hath it preent with it. I argue this, only to hew that they are but one faculty, and therefore by this one word, viz. the Moon, they are both repreented: which (as the more uperiour powers of the oul, and all the members of the body,) hath in this tate of weaknes its anwerable declenion. I confes, with Aritotle,
Arit. de anima, lib. 3. if an old man had a young mans eye, he would ee as well as a young man; but I deny that, which I uppoe he meant by it, that is, that he would perceive and dicern as well as a young man, unles he had a young mans internal faculty alo. It is one thing, to ee, it is another thing, to know that a man ees, and to ditinguih what colour, and what figure he ees. As age brings a weaknes upon the outward ene, o that they cannot ee, o alo upon the inward, that they
cannot dicern could they ee; And this is mot ignificantly expreed by old Barzillai, when King David would have had him, to feed him at his own Table; I am this day, 2 Sam. 19. 35. aith he, fourcore years old, and can I dicern between good and evil? Can thy ervant tate what I eat, or what I drink? Can I hear any more the voice of inging men, and inging women? He firt expreeth his inward decay, I cannot dicern; and then his outward, I cannot tate, nor hear. It is proper to the outward ene, to tate and hear; but it appertains to the inward, to know whether the objects both of tating and hearing, and of all the other outward enes, be good or evil. And thus old Iaac was impoed upon, not only in repect of the dulnes of his outward enes, (all five of which are mentioned in that one Chapter, where his younger Son is aid to come with ubtilty,Gen. 27. and take away the bleing,) but chiefly in repect of the weaknes of his inward ene, wherein he was mot mitaken; for he dicerned him not. Ver. 22. And thus you have the leer light, that rules the night of man darkned, as well as the greater, that rules the day; that which is ubervient to them both, is that which followeth.

div.head: The Stars.
div.p:
By the Stars, I undertand, < in non-Latin alphabet > , All thoe pecies whatoever, either rational or Imaginary, that (like the Stars in their Orb) tand fixedly treaured up in the memory. Now the Stars do not properly pertain either to day or night, but are ditinct Luminaries from the Rulers of the day and night, and ubervient to them both; and do communicate both day and night, to all inferiour bodies, of their influences, and alo of their light; for although the greater light of the Sun in the day time doth caue them to us to diappear, yet they are till hining, as is ufficiently demontrated in the Eclipe of the Sun, when that greater light is darkned; or in the narrow and long contraction of the viible pecies, either by art, in glaes, or naturally, if a man tand at the bottom of a deep and narrow well; then will the Stars give their light apparently at noon day. In like manner, all the pecies and repreentations of things that are pat, whether they are the product of the day or night, that is, as you have heard, either of the undertanding, or of the Phanie, are treaured up in one ingle faculty of the memory. And that the Stars have belonged
only to the night, hath not been a more common mitake among the Vulgar; then that the memory belongeth only to the Imagination, hath been among the Learned. And therefore they have much troubled themelves, and confounded others, in finding out another receptacle of the intelligible pecies, which they call Reminicency or Recordation; as though one and the ame faculty were not able to retain the pecies that are of a dive • s nature; the ground of this mitake hath principally rien from this; that they have given more unto the memory, than properly doth belong unto it, in that they have aigned unto it three operations, viz. Reception, Retention, and Rendition; that this faculty doth not only keep, what is committed to it, (which indeed it doth mot faithfully,) but that it doth alo take into cutody, that which it keeps; and deliver it up again, when called for; hereby making the memory, both Candus, and Promus, of the things therein contained, and giving unto it uch a power, as many Noble men to their Butlers, whereby they become more Maters of what is contained in their Cellars than they that made them. Now if we will divide aright, and give unto the memory that which is its; and unto the
undertanding and imagination that which is theirs; we hall oon undertand how pecies of a divers nature, whether enitive or intelligible; more or les pirituallized; and diverly circumtantiated, in repect of time, or place, or whatoever ele may alter them; may eaily be contained within the ame faculty without multiplication. Say we, that the undertanding and imagination as they make their everal pecies, o alo they take them, and they lay them up in the memory, as they are by them altered or circumtantiated; and as they have occaion to make ue of them, they look for them, and find them treaured up in the ame nature, order, and manner, that they put them in; and from thence they themelves take them out again: The memory in the mean time doing nothing at all, towards either the receiving them, or delivering them up, but only exerciing its paive power in the keeping of them; which keeping alo is nothing ele, but the duration of that impreion (without any act, or endeavour, or knowledge, on the part of the memory) which the more uperiour faculties make; The Memory being mot truly that, which Philoophers have uually aid of the Will, Caca pot • ntia;
keeping thoe things committed to its charge, with no more knowledge, or action, than the Wax doth the Impreion, or the Paper the writing theron made, or the Coffer the Treaure therein repoited: Which being o, it may eaily contain things of a divers nature, and as much diverified in repect of circumtances, as the uperiour faculties can poibly make them. The ame Coffer may eaily preerve the Gold of one man, and the Silver of another, till they each of them come, and take their own goods again. And thus we undertand, that the power of this faculty in man is only paive, and its only work is to retain thoe things that are committed to its charge; which work it performs with great trut, o long as man abides in trength, but as he declines in age, o alo doth this faculty in its ue; not only unfaithfully and confuedly retaining the Images that are made upon it, but oftentimes letting them lip.

q.l: Nomina ervorum, nec vultum agnocit amici
Cum quo praeterita caenavit nocte, nec illos,

div.p:
And as it is aid, concerning the greater
World, when it hall draw towards its end, The Sun hall be darkned, Mat. 24. 29. and the Moon hall not give her light, and the Star • hall fall from heaven, and all the powers of the heavens hall be haken; o alo may it as well be aid in that Worlds Epitomy, Man: As he hall draw towards his end, his undertanding hall be darkned, his Imagination hall be weakned, and withhold its light, and thoe things that were fixed in the Memory hall fall from thence, and all the powers of the mind hall be broken; And this is that which to me eems the true meaning of this econd Vere.
And this the enuing Proverb doth ufficiently confirm.

div.head: Nor the clouds return after the rain.
div.p:
Having before hewed, that the precedent words do not ignifie the infirmities of the eyes, I need ay no more, to hew that thee do not intimate the rheums or ditillations from the eyes or head, falling upon any of the ubjected parts. It will be enough plainly to declare, that thee words ignifie, that the mieries and infirmities of old age, do unceantly and unavoidably ucceed one upon another, as the howers in April. And they are placed here in the midt between the decriptions of the infirmities of the mind which preceded,
and thoe of the body which immediately follow; as having reference to them both. Whereby we mut undertand, that all the infirmities that appertain to this tate, whether they be thoe of the mind, or thoe of the body, do immediatly follow one upon another, and one Paroxyme upon another, and that without remedy. Nubes pot imbrem, is a known Adagy, ignifying, the peedy ucceion of mieries upon mieries; as on the contrary is ignified joy and happines, after affliction, by that Proverb, Post nubila Phoebus. The infirmities in this Allegory mentioned, if they hall at any time fall upon a man in any other age, may poibly be eaed: And if o, there is good hopes that they may be kept from redintegration, or ever returning more; but in this age no uch hopes; if their violence may poibly be for a time remitted, yet they will as certainly return again, as the clouds after a rain in a rainy eaon. Now when the weather is (as we uually ay) et in to rain, it is wonderful to ee, how quick the clouds will rie and ride one after another, and every one, the mallet of them, pour down rain upon the earth beyond all expectation. And if there hall be any mall interval between hower and hower,
and the Sun at any time begin to peep out between the clouds, it is oon darkned again; and the clouds return thicker and blacker, and the howers greater and longer, than they were before. This is a mot lively repreentation of the infirmities of the decrepit age of man; wherein as deep calls unto deep,Pal. 42. 7 o one grief, pain, weaknes upon another, untill all the waves and billows thereof are gone over him.

And if nature hall be able at any time to gather up her elf, and unite all her force, to give a glimmering light through the darknes that oppreeth her; yet it cannot long continue, but a greater darknes will preently ucceed, as it is in the light of a Candle, which is almot conumed in its ocket; ometime ome light appears, then preently it is darkned again, and ome uch interchanges may be for a eaon made, but it will grow darker and darker, until at length it be quite extinguihed. And that wonderful redintegration of the ight and teeth of the old Miniter in Yorkhire (like all thoe lightnings before death,) was but the lat and utmot
endeavour of perihing nature, Et quai m • x emoriturae lucernae upremus fulgor. If old Jacob hall be able to trengthen himelf,G • n 48. 2. and it up in his bed, at the news of his Sons approach to viit him; yet his weaknes mut return again, and he mut lye down in his bed again, and again, until at length he lye down in the grave.

If Art hall be able to contribute any thing to the preent allay of any of the mieries of this tate, yet they will urely and unavoidably return again; if eeing delightful objects, or beloved friends, if hearing of news, or pleaant dicoure, or melodious muick; if the pratling of Grandchildren may give any divertiement or refrehment to the mind: if a more utable air, convenient bathings, unctions, or frictions;Gen. 2 4. if an eaier bed, if avory meat, or delightful wine, or any thing ele, outward, or inward, that Art can find out, may give any eae or refrehment to the body, yet the comfort of them will be but for a mall eaon, and the former troubles will certainly return again.

If a young Virgin, lying in Davids boome, hall cherih him a while, and adminiter that heat and comfort to him that Cloaths could not do, yet it mut be but for a time,1 Kin 3. and David mut grow cold, and
chill, and comfortles again, and that more and more, until he be taken into the houe of all living. And this is the great miery that attends all the mieries of this mierable tate, that they are altogether incurable; and though ome refrehment may ometime eem to interpoe for a eaon; yet they will all mot certainly return again, as the clouds after the rain.

head.q: Vere 3. In the day when the keepers of the houe hall tremble, and the trong men hall bow themelves, and the grinders hall ceae, becaue they are few; and thoe that look out of the windows be darkned.

div.p:
HAving ufficiently before hewed us, what the infirmities of the mind are in this condition, he comes now to treat of thoe of the body; wherein the body is mot aptly compared to a building, or an houe going dayly to decay, and that cannot be repaired. And this imilitude of the body, whereby it is compared
to an houe, is mot Scriptural. David aith,Pal. 1 • 9. 54. Thy tatutes have been my ongs in the houe of my pilgrimage. And Paul aith, If our earthly houe of this tabernacle were diolved, 2 Cor. 5. 1 we have a building of God, an houe not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.

Now the decays of this houe in old age are many; four of which, viz. thoe in repect of the keepers of the houe, the trong men, the grinders, and the lookers out of the windows, are mentioned in this vere, in the Explication of which I hall be the briefer; becaue what I undertand by them all, in this vere, hath been for the ubtance of them, formerly treated of by others. And here the current of Interpreters hath run much-what the ame way, and left behind them les obcurity in thee words, which are indeed in themelves the plainet that are contained in the whole allegory.

div.head: The keepers of the houe hall tremble.
div.p:
I could willingly conent to thoe, that by this expreion would have the ribs to be meant, were the predicate as applicable as the ubject; the Thorax doth mot a • ely keep, and excellently well defend the principal parts therein contained. And
Job peaks of the fence of the bones,Job 10. 1 • . as of the inews: Thou hat fenced me with bones and with inews, but how they hall be aid to tremble, is not to be made appear; foramuch as experience doth ufficiently confirm, that they tand as fixed in old as in young, and more fixed too. And indeed their Articulation, both to the Sternon, and alo (and epecially) to the Vertebrae of the back, is uch, that they admit of very little and obcure motion, but not at all of this trembling. And therefore we mut find out ome other parts of the body which are the contituted keepers of the houe; And they certainly can be no other than the hands. Now the anatomical hand contains not only the Carpus, metacarpus & phalanges digitorum, but the whole uperiour artus; all thoe higher parts of the limbs that are divided from the trunk of the body, and therefore it is well divided in brachium, cubitum, & extremam manum. And thee are they which mot properly are tiled the keepers or defenders of the houe; and that which makes it the more unquetionable is, becaue they anwer o directly to the trong men, as it follows in the next words. And thee hands and arms do everal waies keep and defend the houe. And there is nothing
more frequent in Scripture than the expreing of defence by the power of the hands and arms; when Jacob bleed his Son Joeph, he pake how he was defended from them that beet him, and aith, His bow abode in trength, the arms of his hands were made trong by the hands of the mighty God of Jacob. Gen. 49. 24. And as if there were no other way of expreing preervation, defence, and deliverance, thee members are almot alwaies mentioned, and mot frequently attributed to God himelf; They got not the Land into poesion by their own word, Pal. 44. 3 neither did their own arm ave them; but thy right hand, and thine arm, becaue thou haddet a favour for them. And if there be any impotency in the hands and arms, a man is no longer able to defend himelf; Job hath a mot remarkable expreion to confirm this truth; If ever he ued his defence and help to oppres the Fatherles, he wiheth that now he might be left altogether helples, and that his defenders might be taken from him, or rendred wholly unerviceable to their ends; If I have lift up my hand againt the fatherles when I aw my help in the gate, Job 31. 21, 22. then let my arm fall from my houlder blade, and my arm be broken from the bone. Beide this, they may be aid to keep the houe, in that
they provide for it, getting maintenance for the whole body, for by working they get bread.2 The. 3. 10. Acts 20. 34. Paul aith, Thee hands have minitred to my necesities. And as they do defend the houe, and provide for it; o alo they do offend whomoever would hurt it; they do not only get, but protect, and alo keep off the adverary. And all this was done at once by the power of the hands of the Jews in their great neceity, when they were rebuilding the Temple, their hands were throughly filled, and employed in a double defence; For they which builded on the wall, Neh. 4. 17 and they that bare burdens, with thoe that laded, every one, with one of his hands wrought in the work, and with the other hand held a weapon. Now uch, through the widom of God, is the dexterity of the hand, that it can employ a weapon to be a better defence to a man, than whatoever is naturally allotted to any creature beide. And that audacious Carper at the works of God (who complained that other Creatures had naturally a defence given, and man only left weaponles) was ufficiently ilenced, when it was told him; Man had reaon and hands, which together, can make a better defenive or offenive weapon for him, than all the horns, and hoofs, the tusks, and talens, or whatoever nature
hath more largely lent to other Creatures, can do for them. And if we throughly conider the fabrick of thee parts, according unto what Anatomy doth give ufficient light unto, we hall yet farther be convinced of the truth of this matter. If we conider on the part of the bones, firt the Scapula, and take notice that it is eated in the trong part of the back, with freedom of motion in its place, in which it is contained by the Clavicle, and with great advantage of moving the arm which way oever it pleaeth; that it is formed with its bais, angles, • ibs, procees, Cavities, for the better eat of the mucles, and command of them to their appointed Services; that it is articulated to the humerus per Arthrodiam, wherein the Cavity is improportionate to the head of the humerus, that the houlder may thereby with greater facility and liberty admit of all manner of motion, which it could not posibly have done, had this articulation been any firmer and cloer in it elf. Now that this joynt may be kept from luxation, either from it elf, or from any thing might fall upon it, to which it was very liable by reaon of what was before aid; It is ufficiently defended by a very thick, and nervous ligament; and by the broad Tendons of four
great Mucles; which do o trictly compas about the joynt, that by its own motion, though never o violent, it cannot be put out; and alo by the Clavicle or kennel bone, which is o directly laid cros over it, that it defends it from all external violence whatoever. Again, if we conider the humerus, its head, its neck, its pullyes, its Cavities, its Extuberances; If we conider the Cubitus, and the Radius, and their divers articulation; the one being per ginglymum, which gives flection and extenion with trength; the other per arthrodiam, which gives pronation and upination with eae. Latly, if we conider the bones of the extream hand; and therein the eight bones of the Carpus, which are joyned to the Cubitus, and to the bones of the Metacarpus per arthrodiam, among themelves per harmoniam, if we conider the four bones of the Metacarpus, and their articulation to the fingers per Enarthroin, the fifteen bones of the fingers, and their articulation among themelves, (for the firmer holding any thing in the hand,) per ginglymum. Now I cannot pas the thumb in the general name of the fingers, without a particular and pecial taking notice of it; foramuch as that above all the ret both in its ue,
and alo in its repute, may be aid to contribute chiefly to the keeping of the houe; for it is equivalent to all the fingers, and therefore in Latine is called, Pollex, à pollendo, being as it were an antagonit graper to the whole hand, and doth as much towards the firm holding and dextrous uing of a weapon as all the hand: And therefore it is that idle perons, or effeminate men, or whooever are unfit for ervice in war; are called polletrunci; as who hould ay, men that have not the ue of their thumbs. And it was a Cutome among the Nations, for the Conquerours to cut off the thumbs of the Conquered, thereby rendering them digraced, and utterly unable for future employments either at Sea or Land. And Scriptural Story alo eems to confirm this in Adonibezek, who aid,Threecore and ten Kings, having their thumbs and their great toes cut off, gathered their meat under my table, as I have done, o God hath requited me. Judg. 1. 7. Thus far on the part of the bones. Again, if we conider on the part of the Mucles; how they are variouly haped and formed according to their everal ues, how they are perforated according to neceity, how they are eated to the bet advantage, how they are to one another friends or antagonits, how they
are derived from one part, and inerted into another, how much trength and vigour they have, how by their hormetick power and contraction into their own bodies, they can readily perform whatoever motion the Organ is capable of; they can tir the limb inward, outward; forward, backward; upward, downward; they can perform adduction, abduction; flexion, extenion; pronation, upination, the Tonick motion, circumgiration; and all thee with o great expedition and agility, that they are much ooner done than aid, yea, as oon done as thought on; the actions of the Mucles keeping pace, nay, many times out-tripping the volubility of the mind: If we yet further conider them in their Tendons, and the variety of them, how they are either olid, plain, round, broad, long, hort, one, many; or of whatoever form may render them mot expeditious in their motions; how they are trengthned by everal Ligaments, epecially that annulary Ligament in the Writ.

I ay, if we conider thee wonderful things, wherein man differs from all other Creatures, and many others, which good skill in the anatomy of thee parts would eaily furnih a man with, all which would be too large here to inert; It would enforce
us to ay, that thee of all the parts of man do mot properly defend him, and may jutly be tiled, the keepers of the houe.

Now, that thee may be aid to tremble, needs no words to make appear, foramuch as the experience of every old man doth ufficiently confirm it. Which word doth comprehend within it elf all the weaknees, infirmities, inabilities of thee parts in this condition: Whether they be outward, as tiffnes, contraction, rugoity; or inward, as aches, pains, numnes, palies, cramps, tremblings; yet notwithtanding it hath, in a more epecial manner, relation to that grand ymptome, that doth mot certainly attend this condition; which is called, Tremor artuum, the continual and unavoydable trembling of the hands and arms. Now, foramuch as the lat age of man is eminently above all others he paeth, the cold and the dry; it mut needs incline him, and at lat mot certainly cat him into this ditemper.

For thee two qualities, and, for ought I undertand, thee alone, are the natural fathers of this trembling child. If we remember how going abroad in a bitter cold morning, how drinking a great deal of cold water, or wimming in the water; if we know how the ue of Poppies, Henbane,
