Opium, the cold fit of an Ague, and other cold things, will eaily et us a haking; if we conider that long fatings, great evacuations, epecially Venerial, which do mot dry the Nerves, violent heat in Feavers, fluxing by the ue of Quickilver, immoderate weatings in hot houes, or elehow; do caue the ame ditemper; we hall be induced chiefly to attribute this terrible ymptome, to thee two deadly enemies of a well tempered Contitution, coldnes and drynes; which are o contrary to the intruments of voluntary motion, whoe life and vigour conits in radical heat and moyture; that they take off their trength, and render them unable to perform their duties, making them o weak, that even the weight of the member they are to move, is now their equall Antagonit; for they going about to move the member as they uually had done, are reited with equal force by the weight of that member; which caueth as it were a continual combate between the trength of the mover, and the weight of the moved, o that the Limb is alwaies drawn one way by that, and another way by this, which caueth a perpetual trembling of the keepers of the houe; which is reckoned here as the firt, and indeed is one of the
mot remarkable ymptomes upon the body of man in this decrepit tate.

div.head: The trong men hall bow themelves.
div.p:
Having before treated of the infirmities of the uperiour Limbs, he comes now to thoe of the inferiour; the keepers of the houe being the hands, the trong men can be no other than the feet; now as the hand was divided before, o alo is the anatomical foot, containing not only tarum, metatarum, and phalanges digitorum, but alo femur, tibiam, and extremum pedem; and as before I hewed, the beginning of the hand was to be accounted from the Scapula, o here I mut alo tell you, that the beginning of the foot is from the Os Iliuns •
And thoe Mucles which are inerted into the thigh, and have their ue for the motion thereof; notwithtanding their origination may be either from the back, (inwardly as the chief flector the Poas, or outwardly as the firt extendor, Gloutaeus major,) or from the
<> Ilium, (as mot other movers of the thigh have,) ought all to be accounted into the number of the trong men. And if we well conider the true nature of progreive motion, and firm tation on the ground, we hall oon conclude, that the intruments of them
both (which are none other than thoe we are treating of) are the bet demontrators of humane trength, and may more aptly than any other parts of the body be called the trong men. And this we may alo have confirmed in the holy Writings of God; the trength of the legs, as the intruments of motion, eem to be expreed by the Prophet,Pal. 147. 10. when he aith, He delighteth not in the trength of the hore, he taketh not pleaure in the legs of a man; their trength, as they are the intruments of firm tation, is excellently expreed by the Spoue, when he aith concerning her Beloved;Cant. 5. 15. His legs are as pillars of marble. And as they are the Intruments of both, you have them notified in the Story of Peters curing the lame man;Acts 3. wherein (as if the ue of legs (both for tanding and walking) and trength were Convertible terms, ignifying the ame thing; we have his cure once expreed by thee words; Immediately his feet and his ancle bones received trength, V. 7, 8. and he leaping up, tood and walked; and preently after only by the word trength; Ver. 16. His name, through faith in his name, hath made this man trong. I hall give but one intance more, and that mot remarkable, having in it the great widom of God to expres this thing; and
that is the touch of the hollow of Jacobs thigh;Gen. 32. 25. when God would intimate to Jacob, his own weaknee, and his inability to wretle, and to prevaile with God and man by his own trength; he mites him in the thigh. Thus he dealt alo with Paul, 2 Cor.12. 3. who leat he hould be puffed up with his Viions and Revelations of the Lord, (having been taken up to the third heaven, and o much piritualized, that it was hard to ay, whether he was in the body, or out of the body,) he had uch a direct contrary infirmity laid upon him, that it might ufficiently take off all other men, from admiring him, and himelf, from being lifted up beyond what he ought to be; Lest any man hould think of me above what he eeth me to be, Ver 6, 7. and that he heareth of me, and let I hould be exalted above meaure through the abundance of revelation, there was given to me a thorn in the fleh, the meenger of Satan to buffet me, let I hould be exalted above meaure; all occaions of glorying in his pirituality, was abundantly taken away, when he had a continuall memento of his carnal weaknes, a thorn in the fleh. And thus alo may Jacob, and all Jacobs children, for ever, be taken off from boating in their own trength from his prevailing with God and man; ince
ever after he bare that mot certain ymptome of humane weaknes, halting on his thigh, for when this part is once rendred unerviceable, there can be no more trength to contend.

And the perfect conquet that Sampon got over the Philitines, whereby they were unable any more to reit, is expreed, He mote them hip and thigh. Ju • g. 15. 8. Beide, the Counel which is given to Johuah is worth our oberving to this purpoe, whereby he is taught to make the hores of the many Kings he hould uddenly ubdue, for ever more unerviceable, and yet to ave their lives;Joh. • 1. 6. Thou halt hough their hores, and burn their Charets with fire. Whereby we may undertand, that if the back inew of an hore hind leg (wherein the great trength of thee parts lyeth) be cut in under, he is made altogether as unfit for ervice in the war, as the Charets that are burnt. I might further yet confirm this truth by an Anatomical Enarration of the everal compounding parts of thee limbs, but foramuch as I did that before, in the treating of the uperiour Artus, I may the better omit it here; becaue there is a very great imilitude between thee parts and thoe poken of before; and what was there aid of them, as
unto the parts, and alo unto the dieaes, may for the mot part be tranlated hither, and aid of thee. And it is the principal argument that induceth me to believe that we are in the right in our Interpretation of thee two ymptomes, becaue of the likenes of the parts we are peaking of, and alo of the terms to expres them. It is well known to all thoe that take delight to earch into the wonders of God in the frame of mans body, that the Shoulders, Arms, and Hands; and the Thighs, Legs, and Feet are very much alike; o alo are thee two expreions, the keepers of the houe, and the trong men. The dieaes alo of thee parts in Age are much-what the ame, and o alo are the words that here expres them. For although we tranlate the latter word, Shall bow themelves; yet the Vulgar Latine tranlate it, Nutabunt, hall nod or hake; and doubtles, the original words are of very near ignification, o that the Syriac Tranlation, and the Chaldee Paraphrae upon thee words differ very little or nothing at all, but tranlate them both to trembling or haking. However give me leave to take notice briefly of one or two things wherein thee members differ from thoe before poken of, and Wherein their trength and ue is principally made appear.

The bone of the thigh, is of all other bones of the body the bigget and the longet; and is called in Latine, Femur, à ferendo, becaue as a trong man it doth utain and bear the whole weight of the body. It hath in the head of it three eminent procees; The firt is the great and the round head, which is inerted into the large Cavity of the Hip, per Enarthroin, which admits of all manner of motion, and there is detained by a double Ligament; the firt is common, broad, thick, membranous, that doth trongly compas the joynt about, and the other is a round, and Cartilagineous Ligament, which proceedeth out of the very head of the Femur, and being inerted trictly into the Cavity of the Os Icii, doth firmly hold this bone in its place, that it cannot be moved. The other two procees are called, the Trochanters, the leer, and the greater; whereby the Tendons of the Mucles moving the thigh, are more conveniently eated, that they may the better wheel about that Limb to whatoever poition they pleae. It hath mo • eover at the upper end a more lender part, which is called the neck of the Femur, which is o framed for the more convenient lodging of the Mucles, and paing of the Veels,
(viz. the Arteries, Veins, Nerves,) for the ue and benefit of the ubjected parts. Its form alo is mot remarkable, in that it is on the external or forepart, gibbous or bunching outward; on the internal or hind part, imous or bending inwards, which frame doth wonderfully conduce to the conveniency of itting, to the firmnes of tanding, and to the dexterity of walking.

Latly, It is articulated to the Tibia, per laxum ginglymum, which adds very much to the expedition in motion, and is of uch a frame, that on the back part it leaves a mot convenient hollow place, which we call Poples, the ham, for the paing down of the Veels; and on the fore part it is wonderfully defended by the Patella, or knee pan, as by a hield, the form, and name of which, this bone doth continually bear. And it is o much the more to be oberved, in that no uch bone is in the uperiour Artus, nor in the whole body beides; for it is articulated to no bone at all, but is kept in its place by a double Ligament, the one inward, which is that round, bloudy Ligament, which firmly annexeth it to the thigh; the other outward, which is the Conjunction of the Tendons of the four Mucles which extend
the tibia, which together make a broad Ligament that doth encompas the whole knee, and trongly bind it in its place; wherein it exceedingly conduceth to the defending of the joynt, over which it is placed. For that Articulation being looe in it elf (as was before aid) would be very apt to luxation in udden and great flexures of the knee, or in going down teep places; were it not by this hield bone abundantly trengthned, and ufficiently defended from all thoe inconveniencies.

Moreover, the Conjunction of the Fibula, being otherwie than that of the Radius, which anwereth it in the arm; is well worth our obervation to our preent purpoe; the Radius of the arm is Articulated (as you have heard before) per Arthrodiam to the Humerus, which renders it more expeditious as to everal motions, and therefore more properly a keeper of the houe; but the Fibula is not at all Articulated to the Femur, but is affixed to the external part of the Tibia, and doth tand as it were an underprop to that, whereby they may joyntly with greater trength upport the whole body, and be the more jutly called, the trong men. There is yet one obervation more from the Anatomy of thee parts, that doth with great delight
and content demontrate, that thoe are the keepers of the houe, and thee the trong men, and that is from the variety of their flexures; the hand in all its everal joynts, is bended one and the ame way; the houlder is bended inward, or foreward, and extended outward or backward; o alo is the Arm, the Hand, the Fingers, and this is for the better apprehending and comprehending any thing, and uing any defence; and therefore they are the keepers of the houe: The foot is bended in its everal joynts, everal waies; one, one way; and another, another; the thigh is bended forward, the leg is bended backward; and again, the foot is bended forward, and the toes are bended backward; and this is for the greater coveniency of going, and for the firmer tanding, and therefore thee are the trong men.

We might yet further and principally confirm this thing, by the everal forms and ues of the Mucles of thee parts; for it is not o much great bones, nor great veins, nor a great deal of bloud or fat, that makes a man trong; but great, and trong, and eminent Mucles, they are the true indicators of trength. Now thee parts of the body have bigger, tronger, and more raied Mucles than any beide; and by
how much the higher the Tendons of the Mucles are raied, with o much the greater trength mut they needs perform their Offices, and o much the more declare the trength of a man; and therefore we have an ordinary obervation, and a probable one, to judge of a mans trength, or weaknes, by the elevation or depreion of the Calves of his legs. I might alo add many more obervations of the like kind; but I deit, foramuch as a good Anatomit can furnih himelf with enough; and he that is none at all, can carce undertand thee, when he is told.
And becaue the great trength of a man lyeth in thee parts, therefore in his infirm and weak condition thee parts mut be more eminently feeble.

A Child before trength comes on, and an old man after his trength is departed, mut have but little ue of thee members. As it was aid of Aa, In the time of his age, 1 Kings 15. 23. he was dieaed in his feet; o may it be aid of all who hall live to that time. Now, foramuch as what was aid before of the infirmities of the hands, may alo be aid of thoe of the feet, I hall chiefly refer you thither: However, becaue the word is here omewhat differently tranlated in our Language, and we
have no reaon to complain, foramuch as it doth primarily o ignifie; o that ome have tranlated it, Pervertentur, others, Curvabuntur, and the Septuagint, < in non-Latin alphabet > ; I judge there is one grand ymptome of age that in this place, and upon thee parts is principally aimed at; and that is the pervertion, crookednes, abbreviation, and alteration of the poition, of the everal joynts of thee parts; and their inability of being reduced to a firm, trait, and tonick poture, wherein the trength of a man doth wholly conit. And it is wonderful well worth our obervation, that if a man at his bet and tonget etate, hould be kept in that bending poture, which age necearily binds every man unto; he, in that condition, were carce able to go, or tand, without the help of a taff; and the reaon of it is plain, becaue the Center of gravity is not equally poyed upon the bais of the feet; but hangeth as a weight behind, and therefore had need of another Fulciment, upon which it might the more firmly ret. And therefore it is aid of old men: Membra levant baculis; when thee members are perverted in their joynts, and the tone of the Mucles is o much relaxed, that they are unable to bring them to traitnes again, there is great need of the
upport of a taff; for without it, there is an utter inability of going teadily, and tanding trongly, which is the principal ymptome intimated by the trong mens bowing themelves.

div.head: The grinders ceae becaue they are few.
div.p:
That there may in mans body be other grinding, than matication, or chewing the meat in the mouth; and other grinders, than the jaws and teeth, the enuing Dicoure; and that there can be no other in this place intended, this preent Dicoure, I hope will make appear. Grinding all men know to be performed by two hard bodies, the one immoveable, upon which the grinding is made; the other moveable, which by trong Compreion againt the former, and by its motion, makes the grinding; o that to it, there is neceary both thee, viz. the firm tander, and the trong mover; the upper, and the nether miltone, as we have them often mentioned in Scripture;Deut. 24. 6. now anwerable unto thee in the mill, there are for that grinding which is performed in the mouth; two jaw bones, which are called the upper and nether Mandible. The upper Mandible, is compounded of eleven everal bones, which among themelves, and to thoe adjacent
are joyned either per uturam, or harmoniam, which admit of no motion at all, and therefore this tands firmly in its place, and is that immovable miltone upon which the grinding is made; the nether Mandible is one ingle, hard, and trong bone, whoe Articulation is very looe, for the greater liberty of motion; and it hath two or three pair of Mucles, epecially the Temporal, which trongly bring it upward, for the cloer acting againt the other Mandible, and one wonderful pair of Mucles, called, the Maeters, and are derived from a double original, and beyond all others of the body whatoever, have their everal Fibres o croing and interwoven one with another, that they are everally inerted into this lower Mandible, and o are able to move it upward; to the right, to the left; forward, backward, and conequently round about, and o performing that action which we call Matication or chewing, and therefore this is that other movable miltone which makes the grinding.

Now out of both thee, equally proceed in the eaon of them a certain number of mall bones which we call the Teeth; which howoever they may be numbred among the bones, yet they have
one or two epecial properties which are competible to no other bones of the body, (at leat in that meaure,) whereby they are principally adapted for the grinding.

The firt is, they are naked, they have no covering or skin upon them, no not o much as that common Membrane, called, the Periotion, which doth encompas all the bones of the body beide; and that is becaue they might the better atting one anothers bodies, and in their attrition one againt another they might feel no pain; but I mut needs here take notice that the words of Job eem to be againt me, where he aith,Job 19. 20. I have ecaped with the skin of my teeth; This is eaily anwered, if we conider the two parts of the Teeth, viz. the Bais, and the Radix; that, is the part which eminently appears white above the Gums; this, is that part which is within the Gums, and tands fixed in the Mandibles: Now by Jobs skin or covering of his teeth, it is apparent he meant the gums which cover the roots of the teeth; his ores, and his boyls were o great and terrible upon him, from the ole of his foot to his Crown, that there was no part of the skin of his body to be een, but only about his teeth, which in all uch Cutaneous dieaes doth for the mot part wholly ecape.
The econd is, they have the veels which convey life and ene unto them, contained only in the inward parts, that the outward parts may be freer and better to grind.

The third is, that they are growing or encreaing o long as man lives, o that what is worn away of them by their continual attrition and manducation; is dayly repaired, otherwie they would grow horter and moother, and not be o able to perform their work; and this is a wonderful piece of the widom of God in nature, which Art cannot poibly reach unto; and therefore becaue they cannot make their mills grow, as they dayly decay by grinding; they are fain to upply that want, by often pecking their miltones, and at length changing them; and by thoe means as it were renew their teeth, without which they were able to do nothing at all.

The lat I hall mention is, that the teeth of all the bones of the body are the hardet, and will uffer the leat from any other bodies whatoever, and therefore are the fitter for uch a work as this. A miltone is of all other tones uppoed to be the hardet, and therefore Job when he had expreed the hardnes of the heart of
the Leviathan by a tone; as if he had not aid enough, he farther adds one degree more, yea, aith he, As hard as a piece of the nether miltone. Thee hort obervations may uffice to teach us in the general, that the teeth alo may be called the grinders. If we yet more particularly conider them, and how they may be divided, we hall have a farther light into this matter. The teeth are of three kinds, either Inciores, Canini, or Molares: The firt are the broad fore-teeth; the econd are the next round teeth, which are uually called the eye-teeth; the lat are the great double and hindermot teeth; the firt, bite or cut the food; the econd, break or bruie the food; the lat, chew or grind the food. And this ditinction alo may be found in Scripture, the firt are alluded to, where it is aid, The Prophets bite with their teeth. Mic. 3. 5. The econd, where it is aid, He hath the cheek teeth of a Lion: Joel 1. 6. And both thee, where it is aid, There is a generation whoe teeth are as words, and their jaw teeth as knives. Prov 30: 14. The lat is alluded to, where it is aid, While the fleh was yet between their teeth, ere it was chewed, the wrath of the Lord was kindled againt the people. Num. 11. 33. They had bit the fleh of the Quails, and had paed it from the firt
teeth, to the lat, which are the grinders, and there it tuck till they died. And thus at length we are fallen upon the true, proper, and trict intruments of grinding; we have hitherto been hewing the whole frame of the mill, and how everal parts do wonderfully contribute towards this work, and now we are come to thoe parts, wherein the cloe pinch of grinding lieth, and that is in the great, broad, and hindermot teeth, which from the day of the writing of this Allegory, to this preent time, have ever among Anatomits retained the name of grinders.

And that not without exceeding good reaon, for the form and figure of thee, above the ret doth abundantly hew that thee are the fittet of them all for this work; for thee are bigger, larger, broader every way; epecially at the top, where their form is much-what like to that of a mill, where alo they have eminent aperities, & protuberances, exactly anwerable to the roughnes of the Miltones; by which the grinding is far more eaily and perfectly performed; beide, thee are more firmly inclavated, and infixed into the jaw bones, by treble, or quadruble roots; whereas all the ret are but by ingle, or double at the mot; and being more trongly rooted,
they are the fitter for more eminent ervices; Latly, and chiefly, the experience of every man doth ufficiently confirm that this is the proper ue of thee teeth; and that the more olid food which needs greater manducation, cannot be ufficiently comminuated for chyle, or ground low enough for the tomack, untill thee teeth have done this work upon it. And thus it is plain, that the jaws, and teeth, and eminently thee lat mentioned, are appoitely and elegantly called the grinders; which how much ervice they do to man while uable, and how much detriment and los they bring upon him when they ceae from their ue, is well known to all men. Strong meat belongeth to men of full age, Heb. 5. 14 aith the Author to the Hebrews. It belongs to them, and only to them, becaue they alone, have, as I may o ay, their mill in tune, their mouth full of trong teeth, and et directly one againt another, whereby they may bring the tronget meat into a meet conitence, and a due preparation for eaie digetion in the tomack. But it may here be aid, there are many Creatures that are not thus trongly armed, and have not o many teeth, nor thoe they have o well et, as your poition uppoeth they hould be, for the due
preparation of the meat; And thee are the Sheep, the Goat, the Cow, the Deer, and all other Creatures that have teeth only on the lower Jaw, and none at all on the upper. Thee have no antagonit grinders, nor contra-acting miltones, and yet thee Creatures in their full age, eat as olid food, and as hard of digetion, and withall, do as well with it, as they that are better provided in this repect; to this I mut needs anwer, it is very true, o that from hence we may take occaion to admire the widom of God in the various formation of everal Creatures, tending notwithtanding to the ue and benefit of them all. However this in thee Creatures is a want, and mut have tood for a want, had they not been abundantly upplyed in another kind. For all thoe Creatures that are thus deficient in their teeth, and only thoe; are they which chew the Cud, which is a reauming the food into the mouth, and a grinding of it a freh the econd time, o that they are fain to do that at twice, and to be three or four times as long about it, as thoe creatures whoe grinders are better placed; neither would this uffice alone, for if they hould be chewing their meat all the day long with the teeth that they have, it would never be ufficiently
prepared for nourihment, were there not yet a farther preparation in their bodies for that purpoe; and that is, that thoe Creatures, and only thoe, have a peculiar veel in their bodies aigned for this work, and that is that which Anatomits call, Oma • um, and our Butchers, the Read; wherein the meat mut be macerated for a certain eaon, and by the fermentum therein contained, brought to uch a Conitence, that afterwards by a little chewing in the mouth again, it may be committed to the tomack with the ame hopes of ucces, that in other Creatures that are toothed on both ides, it is committed at the firt: Now, man being in the number of thee lat mentioned, mut for the due preparation of all trong food, trut alone to his grinders; o that the time of ablactation of the child, and of alteration of the diet of the old man, is mot certainly indicated by the beginning and ceaing of the ue of the Teeth; milk is fit for babes, before their teeth come; and old men when their teeth decay,Heb. 13. 14. are again become uch as have need of milk, and not of trong meat.

Now by the ceaing of the teeth we mut undertand, all thoe infirmities that are incident to them by reaon of age, whether looenes, hollownes, rottennes,
brokennes, blacknes, foulnes, tench, wormeatennes, excrecency, or whatoever ele may be any impediment to them in their ue. But the chief ymptome here intended is, the falling out, and conequently, the paucity of the teeth; which is gathered from the reaon here annexed, Becaue they are few; which is very well tranlated in our Language, following the Vulgar Latine; Otioae erunt molentes in minuto numero. For although the Original word do primarily ignifie no more than becaue they are diminihed, yet it mut of neceity be undertood, in repect of their number; for otherwie they are not diminihed, but do grow o long as they remain in the head, even to the extremity of old age. But as age comes on, the natural moyture at the root of the teeth is conumed, and a preternatural is ditilled thither in its room, which doth by degrees relax them in their ockets, and at length quite expell them: And when ome of them are thrut out, and but a few left in, it is eaie to conceive from what hath been aid, how the chewing in the mouth ceaeth; yea, it ceaeth more, when the teeth are few, than when they are none at all. For then the Gums might act one againt another, and, foramuch as they grow harder in old age, might
do omething weakly towards the chewing of the meat; but when they are few, they hinder thoe from working in the leat, and having no antagonits (were they firm in the head which they are not) are not able to work themelves, and o the whole grinding ceaeth; which is a very great and mot certain ymptome of this tate of weaknes, and yet is neglected by our great Mater of natural knowledge in this kind,Hippo. l. 3. Apho. ult. in his bet enumeration of the dieaes of age.

div.head: And thoe that look out of the windows be darkned.
div.p: That by this clear expreion the eyes and the infirmities of them in old age, is intimated unto us, was never yet, and I perwade my elf never will be, in the leat meaure doubted or quetioned.

The Tunicles or Coats, through which the ight is made, are only two, for although there are other Tunicles of the eye, which conduce wonderfully to the ight, (as you hall hear beneath,) yet thoe through which the pecies pas, are only the Tunica Aranea, and the Cornea. The firt is o called from the imilitude of a Spiders Web, becaue it is mot fine and ubtile, and being derived from the Brain and Optick Nerve, it becomes a mot tenuous vetment for the humours; and is o pellucid, and tranparent, that among the Learned it bears the name of Speculum. The other is called, Sclerotica, or Cornea; and that is, that hard and horny Membrane, which being derived from the dura mater, encompaeth the whole body of the eye, without any perforation; and on the back part, behind the ight of the eye, is more obcure and dark; but on the forepart, is far more plain, polite, and
diaphanous, that the pecies may pas through its body mot pure and unaltered. And now I am come to that part of the eye, that doth mot aptly reemble the glas of the window, by reaon of which a man may be truly aid to look through a window, and an old man,1 Cor. 13. 12. to ee through a glas darkly, without the ue of Spectacles, which ome would fain have here to be undertood; of whoe opinion I cannot perwade my elf to be, becaue it is uncertain to me, whether thoe helps of nature were then, and there, in ue: And mot certain it is, that they are without the compas of the Allegory, and are not part of that houe or body of man, whoe decay is here o lively repreented. Beide, this Tunicle hath the ame ue to man, in his perfect tate, that Spectacles have in his imperfect. And this be confident of, that there is nothing that Art hath found out to help man in his decayes, that hath not its footteps firt in Nature, and is not an imitation of thoe things in man, that were mot compleatly in him in his perfection. And here I mut of neceity go one tep farther, than our common Oculits; who acribe to this part but a low and a mean office, which is only to keep the humours <> their place, or at the bet,
to defend the inward parts from external injuries; but without all quetion, it hath this farther, and more noble ue, viz. o to dipoe and order the viible pecies, that they may in the mot convenient manner, make their impreion upon the proper Organ of ight; and this their Craitude or thicknes, together with their Convexity or bending outward, doth ufficiently make appear. I here all along retain the term of the Ancients, viz. viible pecies, as being mot known, and that by which I may be better undertood among mot, to whom this Paraphrae may come, though it be not o proper, and the Conceptions which they had about them, are not to be admitted; for there is no new Entity, either material, or immaterial, cat off from the object, ditinct from it, & from the light, which is the caue of viion in the eye; by the viible pecies therefore, I mean no more, than the everal beams of light being o reflected from the object, as that they become fully fraught with the repreentation of it, (not only in repect of the proper object of ight, which we call colour, but of thee common ones alo, which we call ituation, figure, ditance, bignes, and the like,) and have a compleat power of impreing the ame upon the Retina, which
is the trict and proper Organ of ight, and is nothing ele than the dilation of the Optick Nerve all about the bottom of the eye. For the better undertanding of all which, we mut know that the pecies pas along the medium in a Pyramidical figure, and as they are cat off from one point of the Superficies of the object in a Cone, o they mut be reduced again in the ame Conical figure upon one and the ame point of the Organ; which reduction is performed by that collection, refraction, and direction, which hapneth to them in thoe everal pellucide bodies through which they pas, and primarily (while the eye remains in its vigour) in the Tunica Cornea; but as age enfeebleth the eye, the form and figure of it becomes more plane and depreed than it was before; and the Crytalline humour, which had a power of reducing it elf, and conequently the whole body of the eye, to a more oblong and Convex hape, becomes dry, and altogether unable for uch an end; o that now the Species cat off from the object at a convenient ditance, cannot be brought to a Cone upon the Organ, which mut needs breed a confuion in the fight: To avoid which conuion, old men hold the object that they look upon at a greater ditance from the
eye, becaue o, the preent Contitution of the eye can better regulate the Species; and thus alo Spectacles are placed before the eye to collect, refract, and guide the Species, that they may point together upon the Retina; which by how much the thicker, and more Convex they are, by o much the more powerfully do they do this work: And therefore as age encreaeth, and the form of the Crytalline humour, and of the whole eye is more depreed, o much the thicker, or o much the more Convex, or both, mut the Spectacles be made, that they may be anwerable to the age. And this is done only in imitation of that, which is far more perfectly done while man abides in trength, by the hard Membrane we are now treating of; and this is the firt ene in which the eyes may be called the lookers out of the windows.

The other is, that whereby they may be aid to look through the holes of the window, when there is an open paage, and nothing at all interpoeth between them and the object. And this indeed is the mot proper reading of the words. < in non-Latin alphabet >
ignifieth in foraminibus, or as the Vulgar Latine, per foramina; and the Seventy,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Now there are everal waies,
whereby the eye may be aid to look in, or through the holes.

The firt is, in repect of their eat, or the form of that place, in which they are fixed in the head. And if we hould trictly hold the word to that interpretation of in foraminibus, or the lookers in the holes, nothing could be o applicable as this; and hereunto to be ure the Chaldee Paraphrae hath reference, Qui vident per Cancellos Capitis tui, thoe that look in, or through the trong bounds of the head, which can be no other, than thoe firm holes, or arches, which are made in the fore-part of the head, for that very purpoe, viz. to receive into their Cavities the whole body of the eye: And thee are by Oculits called Orbitae, and are each of them compounded of ix everal bones, which, being mot conveniently uturated among themelves, do make up thoe curious arched chambers in which thee lookers or beholders dwell, in which, and from which, they may be aptly aid to perform their offices. And to thee alluion is had in the Plague wherewith the Lord will mite thoe that fight againt Jerualem, Zach. 14. 12. Their fleh hall conume away while they tand upon their feet, and their eyes hall conume away in their holes.

Secondly, They may be aid to look in, or through the holes; in repect of the palpebrae or Eye-lids; for although the ue of the eye-lids is to cover or cloe the eyes, o that they are called, Oculi ab oculendo, vel occultando, becaue they lye hid under their lids; yet whenoever the eye is exercied in eeing, they mut depart one from another, and o leave an open hole through which the ight may be made. And thus every man dicerns in himelf that he can take away ight, or caue it at pleaure, by drawing, or withdrawing; by letting down, or pulling up, thee hutters of the windows. And it is wonderful to conider how ready they are in this work, that they might be no impediment to viion, o that an intantaneous action is no way better expreed, than by the motion of the eye lids:1 Cor. 15. 52. Behold I hew you a mytery, we hall not all leep, but we hall all be changed in a moment, in the twinckling of an eye. And when we look earnetly upon any thing, we teadfatly keep the windows open; and a hut eye, in Scripture phrae, ignifieth impoibility of eeing;Ia. 6. 10. Shut their eyes let they ee; and an open eye ignifieth power of looking or beholding;2 King. 6. 20. Open the eyes of thee men, aith Eliha, that they may ee, and the Lord opened their eyes,
and they aw, and behold they were in the midst of Samaria. And a Seer, and a man whoe eyes are opened, are the ame thing, Balaam the on of Beor hath aid, Num. 24. 3, 4. and the man whoe eyes are open hath aid, he hath aid, who heard the words of God, who aw the viion of the Almighty, falling into a trance, but having his eyes open; And thus alo may the eyes be aid to look through the holes, and all thoe that have taken exact notice of the Foramina Cutis in the body of man, have been ure not to neglect thee.

Thirdly, They may be aid to look through the holes, in repect of that outward Membrane of the eye, which is called Adnata, or Conjunctiva, and this is that which being divided from the Pericranium, is next of all to the Orbita, and firmly holdeth the eye in that Cavity, it encompaeth the eye round on the back part, and on the fore-part o far as the white of the eye goeth, and no further, and o leaveth the whole Iris, the rainbow, or party-coloured part of the eye, as an open hole, which the viible pecies may freely without interruption pas through; the truth of this any one may dicern in the inflammation of the eyes, for that is a dieae for the mot part eated in this part
alone; then you may ee the veins and the Arteries very red and wollen, o far as this Membrane or the white of the eye reacheth, and the Iris or darker part of the eye in the mean while wholly free.

Fourthly, The eyes may be aid to look through the holes in repect of the Pupilla, or the apple of the eye, which is nothing ele, but an open hole in one of the coverings of the eye, as I may ay, bored for that very purpoe, that the lookers through the windows might have an open view; for that Covering which is called Tunica Uvea, is a thick, and a cloe, a dusky, and a dark Membrane, through which the viible Species, or the light cannot eaily make its way. And therefore on the back part its ue is to preerve, and to keep together the innate light of the eye, and alo to give a top to the viible pecies, o that they can pas no farther, but mut there impres their Images; like the lead, or the teel, or whatoever ele is put on the backide of the Looking-glas, without which there can be no impreion made; but on the fore-part it is mot conveniently perforated, and at uch a proportion, that the light or the pecies through it have freedom of acces: which perforation is the apple of the eye, that wonderful part,
which is o often noted in Scripture to be above all other parts of the body tendered and oberved,Gen. 32. 10. Pal. 17. 8 Pro. 7. 2. and therefore here I would principally take notice of it; and of all the parts of the eyes, and of all the holes through which they look, let this be alwaies accounted the mot obervable. For it may be dilated or contracted as it may be conducible to a more perfect ight; if there be requiite thereunto, a greater or a leer light; if the object we would look upon, be farther off, or nearer to the eye; or if we do more carelely or curiouly look upon it; this hole is preently made wider or narrower; that it may be the more erviceable for the preent occaion.

Latly, They may be aid to look through the holes in repect of the Optick Nerves, for thee above all the other Nerves of the body are apparently perforated; and although neither thee, nor any other, doth o appear in a body that hath been long dead, yet doubtles they have open paages while the body is yet alive, foramuch as they are the Conveyers of matter, though more pure and refined, from one part unto another, as the other Chanels of the body are. And here the Cavity and Poroity of the Optick nerves, ought as well to be reckoned among the,
holes through which ight is made, as any other that are placed before the proper Organ, upon which the repreentation of outward objects is firt made, and that becaue there can be no perfect perception of any thing, unles the impreion made upon the Senory be truly conveyed into the mot inward recees of the brain, where the oul makes its eat of judicature. For as all the things in a Chamber may have their firm repreentation in a glas that tands upon the Table, yet if any thing interpoe between me and the glas, I dicern nothing at all; and they are all as much hid from me, as if they had never been there repreented. And thus we know a total obtruction of the Optick Nerve, which is called, Gutta Serena, makes as perfect a blindnes, as an obtruction of the humour Aqueus, which is called, a Cataract; And thus I have endeavoured to hew, and that I hope with ome atisfaction, how the eyes may be called, the lookers through the windows. Now as age comes on and encreaeth, it is well known to all men how ight goeth away and decreaeth; the lookers out of the windows mut auredly be darkned, and by how much the more excellent thee parts are, by o much the more apparent
are their decayes. It is aid of the heart, it is primum vivens, and ultimum moriens; but contrariwie it may very well be aid of the eye, that it is ultimum vivens, and primum moriens. This mot wonderful and tender part of man, in that it hath more curious and more various work in its formation, is the lat that lives; and in that it hath need of more life and vigour, more firmnes and purity in its operation, it is the firt that dieth; and indeed the inenible encroach of age, is no where o oon dicovered, as in the eye; and men are loath to think themelves declining in age o oon as the eye gives warning thereof; and we have carce any decription of an old man by his infirmities, wherein thoe of the eye are not principally mentioned: When Iaac, Jacob, Eli, Gen. 27. 1 Gen. 48. 10. 1 Sam. 3. 2. and others are recorded as old, it is aid of them, Their eyes were dim, and they could not ee; for whatoever may either incraate the diaphanous bodies before mentioned, and render them les tranparent; or top the everal perforations, and o hinder that open view: mut of neceity caue a diminution, and in time a perfect abolition of the ight; and here give me leave to name one or two principal ymptomes of viion that are the chief attendants of this declining
tate; The firt is Caligo, which is the obcurity of viion by reaon of the Craitude or thicknes of the Tunica Cornea; which by reaon of the drines of age doth together with the nails of the fingers,Fernel. grow darker and thicker, and conequently loe dayly omewhat of its perpicuity: Another is Glaucoma, which is the change of the colour of the Crytalline humour, by reaon of its dulnes and thicknes, whereby old men do look upon all things as it were through moak, or a cloud, and o do but darkly dicern them: Another is Zinifiis, which is a change of the figure of the whole eye, whereby it becomes more plain and depreed, and a drines in the Crytalline humour, whereby it is unable to reduce the eye to that form, which may be mot advantagious to viion; o that they cannot perceive any thing at an equal ditance, but mut have their objects more remote from the eye, or the pecies firt refracted and directed by the ue of Spectacles; Another is Suffuio ex cruditate, or any interpoition of any preternatu • al matter between the ight and the Tunica Cornea: I might alo add Corrugatio & relax • tio uveae tunica, the contraction or dilatation of the apple of the eye; or whatoever ele by obcuring the glas,
or obtructing the holes; may be jutly aid to darken the lookers out of the windows.

head.q: Vere 4. And the doors hall be hut in the treets, when the ound of the grinding is low, and he hall rie up at the voice of the bird, and all the Daughters of muick hall be brought low.

div.p:
THus far the Preacher hath been treating of all thoe faculties which are termed Animal, and their decaies in the time of age; he paeth in this vere to thoe other which are called natural, of which he treateth in the beginning of this vere, and then to thoe that are mixed, in the latter end; and that in a double repect, firt, thoe that are mixed of the faculties, inward and outward, and that is expreed in the want of leep, in thoe words, He hall rie up at the voice of the bird; foramuch as leep, Fernel l. 6 Pathol. c. 11. if perfect and ound, is the ligation of all the enes both inward and outward for the refrehment both of the mind and body. The other mixture of faculties is of vital and Animal, in the lat words,
All the daughters of muick hall be brought low; For the paive daughters of Muick belong to the Animal faculty, being the Intruments of an outward ene, viz. hearing: And the active daughters of Muick belong to the vital, being the intruments of repiration, as you hall hear hereafter. Now to the undertanding of this vere, epecially the former part of it, I hope to let in ome glimmering of light, which formerly hath lain undicovered.

div.head: The doors hall be hut in the treets, when the ound of the grinding is low.
div.p:
For the right undertanding of thee words, we mut be ure in the firt place to take notice that all thee words are but one Sentence, and confequently but one Claue of the decription of age; the former words, viz. The doors hall be hut in the treets, are not a ditinct ymptome of themelves, as mot men have formerly aid, but they have their reference to the enuing words, viz. When the voice of the grinding is low. And the doors and treets here mentioned, are no other, than uch as concern the grinding, and are as inlets and outlets, waies and paages unto that. And I perwade my elf, that the hitherto micarriage in the Interpretation of thee
words hath proceeded from neglect of this conideration. The doors hall be hut when the grinding is low, and only then; and the lownes of the grinding, is the caue of the hutting of the doors. In humilitate vocis molentis, aith the Vulgar Latine. Ob, per, vel propter depresionem vocis molentis, ay others, and that very cononant to the Original, inamuch as the grinding hall be low, or by reaon of the lownes of the grinding, the doors hall be hut in the treets. Wherefore for the better clearing of the whole Sentence, we mut firt of all hew what is to be undertood by the grinding, and afterwards what the doors and the treets are, and what the ound of the grinding, will eaily be made appear. The widome of Solomon is o famous throughout all Regions and Ages, that I need not here Apologize for it. It would be unbecoming an ordinary Writer, much more the Penman of this Allegory, to deliver the ame thing twice in a breath; And I wonder with what face any Interpreters could put o great an aburdity upon the Wie man, as to make this grinding ignifie no more than that jut mentioned before. But for the clearing of this, we mut know that grinding is of two orts, either Per extra poitionem,
or Per intra uceptionem, (as Philoophers ue to ditinguih of augmentation,) there is an extrinecal, or an intrinecal grinding; the former of thee is performed when two hard bodies acting againt each other, do break and bruie into mall parts, that which is put between them. And this is the grinding as in a Mill, of which you heard before. The latter of thee is performed, when the parts of the ame mas, by reaon of the exaltation of ome internal principle, or the addition of ome fermentum, are o acted among themelves, that the whole mas, and every the leat part thereof, is changed and brought into a new Conitence. And this Philoophy calls Fermentation, and is that of which the Wieman peaks in this place; And it is therefore called grinding, becaue it accompliheth the end thereof better than any mill can do. It will comminuate things of o hard a ubtance that no mill can break. I would fain know what Mill could have ground Aarons golden Calf,Exod. 32. 20. Deut. 9. 21. but by the help of fire, and poibly ome pecifick mentruum, as a proper key for that Solar Mineral, it was eaily ground to powder. Again, it can divide the matter that is to be ground into maller parts than any mill
can do; it will not leave the mot minute part unearched, A little leaven, 1 Cor. 5. 6. Gal. 5 9. Mat. 13. 33. aith the Scripture, leaveneth the whole lump. And our Saviours expreion of it, is yet more ignificant, The Kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven, which a woman took and hid in three meaures of meal till the whole was leavened,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , till the whole of mas, and every one of the leat parts thereof be leavened. No Mill can be et o low, as to grind every Corn, and every part of every Corn; but Leaven leaves none untouched, but divides (beyond what Philoophy gives way for) into parts indiviible.

Now of this ort of grinding there is very much to be found in the body of man: And indeed all the natural alterations that tend either to the preervation of the peron, or propagation of the kind, are the products of this intetine grinding. And there is carce a part in man, epecially an internal vicus, that doth not particularly contribute to uch a work as this. And urely, that which lies daily upon our trenchers, had need of many through grindings, that it may be really tranubtantiated into our fleh; thee in the body of man are by Phyicians called digetions, or concoctions, and are to be found almot in every
part, as was aid before; but I hall intance only in a few, and thoe well known to all thoe that have the leat skill in natural things; and thee few grindings, together with the voice of them, the doors and treets that lead to, and from them being well undertood; thoe that are more accurate in the knowledge of all the alterations of the nourihment of man, may thence from eaily attain the whole intent and purpoe of the Wie man in this part of the decription of age. I hall only mention five: Three in repect of the Individual; and two in repect of the Species; and they are thoe common ones; Chylification, Sanguification, Asimulation, Lactification, and Spermification.

The firt of thee, viz. Chylification is thus performed, after the meat is ufficiently chewed in the mouth, it is committed to the tomack, where continually there lyeth treaured up a certain acide juyce, the relicts of the lat Concoction; which (as the Leaven in the bread) doth preently infect the whole mas, and every part thereof; and doth o penetrate and earch the parts, and o divide and eparate them one from another, and joyn it elf to every one of them, that at lat the matter of nourihment is o perfectly ground, that it is
brought to a new Conitence and colour, very like to the Cream of Barly, and is that Phyicians call the Chyle; and this is the firt intrinecal grinding that the food receiveth, and is next of all to that of the mouth, and not altogether unlike to it; and therefore when matication is but weakly performed, you heard before that it was helped by infuion of the food in a Ventricle prepared for that purpoe, whereby the parts were acted among themelves, and better comminuated, than if they had been never o long chewed in the mouth.

The econd of thee, viz. Sanguification is performed, when the Chyle it elf is ground over again, and receiving yet farther exaltations by a greater olution of the more noble, and active principles; it once again depoites its old colour, and conitence, and o at length becomes perfectly changed into that true liquor of life,Lev. 17. 11, 14. which is called bloud; and although it mut alwaies be acknowledged that the Chyle doth receive many alterations, and exaltations before it come to the heart; almot in every part it paeth through, both in the guts themelves, in the Meentery, the Glandules, and the milky veels, both of one ort, and of

another; and alo in the veins; and after it hath paed through the heart, it mut be once or twice circulated through the body, and receive everal defaecations, as in the Liver, the Spleen, the Kidneys, and the like; before it be compleatly accomplihed for its ultimate ue, all which exaltations, and defaecations, are included in this Text; yet it mut till be remembred, that the principal and upream exaltation of the bloud, the mot eminent and remarkable grinding towards Sanguification, in comparion of which, all the others are little to be accounted of; is alwaies performed in the heart, that fountain of life; for as oon as the Vena Cava hath committed the matter of nourihment into the right Ventricle of the heart, the fermentum therein contained working uddenly and throughly upon it, ets the active principles at a greater freedom, and o inducing new motion, and effervecence into the bloud, doth happily impraegnate it with vitality. And not only this new matter of nutrition, when it firt attingeth, the heart is thereby enlivened; but the bet bloud it elf, after that by various circulations, and imparting its power and life to the parts that are nourihed by it, it becomes weak and much depauperated; is
fain to return back again to the heart for a freh impraegnation. And uch a vat difference there is between the bloud in the Arteries newly brisked in the fountain, and that in the Veins lowered and impoverihed with its journey, that the Ancients took them for two everal things, and knew not that they were the ame; like the men of Bethlehem, Ruth 1. 19, 20, 21. who knew not Naomi, nor would acknowledge her the ame peron, becaue he went out full, and returned home again empty; and he her elf was not unwilling to have changed her name: And he that hall call the rich bloud going out in the Arteries, Aerial, Jovial, Spiritual; and the mean and poor bloud returning home in the Veins, Earthly, Saturnal, Gros, hall make no Schime at all in the unquetionable doctrine of Circulation.

The third of thee, viz. Asimulation, is then performed, when the nutritive juyce is ufficiently prepared in all things that are allotted to it, and by the impule of the conveying veels is brought near to the parts that are to be nourihed, and then every one of the parts by a certain allective property of its own, doth draw that which is mot agreeable to it elf, and then falls to acting, earching, breaking it over
again into mot minute parts, and o thoe that are like to prove unconformable, are excommunicated to the pores; and the other are taken into joynt fellowhip and communion, and o made one with the part; and that which is mot remarkable is,Gen. 18. 10. that according to the time of life, wherein augmentation or encreae of tature is appointed to man, every one of the parts takes o much to it elf, as will anwer its dayly growth, and after that is accomplihed, every part takes only o much to it elf, as doth anwer its dayly decay.Exod. 16. 17, 18. The Children of Irael gathered Manna in the wildernes, ome more, ome les, yet when they did mete it in an Omer, he that gathered much, had nothing over; and he that gathered little, had no lack; they gathered every man according to his eating: This is truly verified in the food of all mankind. Some there be that make greater preparations for the belly, otherome there be that make leer, yet when this comes to the meaure of God, I mean, to be put to that end which he hath appointed, he that made the greatet hath nothing over, and he that made the leat hath no lack, every one according to his wating. The Princes uperfluities, and the Beggars penury, both of them make but equal reparation
for the dayly Conumption of their own fleh.

The fourth that I mentioned, was the making of the milk; which although it be peculiar to one Sex only, yet I cannot but take notice of it among the ret, becaue a principal alteration of the nutritive juyce is thereby made, and the widom and goodnes of God is therein (as in the formation and birth of the Infant) mot eminently made appear.Pal. 22. 9. Thou art he (aith David) that took me out of the womb, thou didt make me hope when I was upon my mothers breats. Now, this is thus performed: The Breats by their attractive property, draw from the Arteries that bloud, which is the leat altered from Chyle, as being mot agreeable to their glandulous ubtance; and from the Nerves, that juyce which they convey for the nourihment of the permatick parts, and by a pecifick Fermentum in themelves contained, do ubact, and comminuate, both thee liquors, and by a perfect mixture of them, and a certain peculiar alteration, at length prod •• e that white, weet, pleaant, alimentory liquor which we call the milk, which containeth in it meet matter of nourihment for all the parts of the Child, both anguineous, and permatical: and
is the mot proper food for it, and exactly agreeable to that, with which it was utained in the womb.

The lat of thee we have named is, the production of eed, which becaue it is the highet, and mot wonderful of them all, it had need of greater preparations, and more alterations than all the ret; and therefore it is, that there are everal veels appointed for that purpoe, and many admirable Combinations, Complications, and intertextures of them all, which are not elewhere in the body to be found. The Vaapraeparantia, and Deferentia, the Vas Varicoum, the Epididymis, and Paratatae, the Veiculae eminales alo, and the Protatae, do each of them add omewhat to the making of the Seed meet for propagation; but it mut alwa • es be acknowledged, that the principal Fermentum that doth mot of all exalt the eminary matter, and chiefly render it prolifick, is contained in the oft, pungy, glandulous ubtance of the Tetes; which therefore bear their name, becaue they give tetimony of virility, and hew that a man is perfec •• n his kind,Gen 5. 3. and therefore able to produce his own Image; the piritous & benign matter mot apt for generation, being from all the parts of the body by the Arteries and Nerves
conveyed to thee parts; it is herein by a myterious faculty of their own, elaborated into that noble Elixir; which from one man hath dilated the world to o many millions as of which it now conits; and doth continually from generation to generation make abundant reparation for the cruelties of the King of terrours. For although in the pace of an hundred years or thereabout, all the living upon the face of the earth are driven thencefrom by the troak of death, yet by the vertue of this divine extract, the earth is at all times ufficiently peopled, and the Inhabitants thereof perceive no lack. So that this doth in a manner perpetuate mortality, and caue men to urvive the funerals of all mankind. Hence it is that the widom of God in Scripture doth alwaies expres Poterity, and the Generations that were yet to come, by the word Seed, Gen. 3. 15 I will put enmity between thee and the woman, between thy eed and her eed. And the Lord aid to Abraham, Gen. 15. 5 Look now towards heaven, and tell the Stars if thou be able to number them, o hall thy eed be.

And this is the lat operation in man which I hall mention that is here intended by the word grinding; and this, viz. the preparation of eed (if not all the other)
is eminently called grinding, in that place where it is aid,Job 31. 10. Let my wife alo grind to another, and let others how down upon her; and all the other alterations of the nutritive juyce in man (if not this alo) are eminently o called, in the Story of Samon; for although it be generally undertood that Samon ground in a Mill, and our later Commentators, (as if in a Mill themelves) following the beaten tract, do all take it up from others, and leave it unto others as granted: yet in the Text there is not once mention made of a Mill, but there are many Circumtances that do to me clearly evince the contrary; the words run thus,Judg. 16. 21. The Philistines took him, and put out his eyes, and brought him down to Gaza, and bound him with fetters of bras, and he did grind in the prion houe: Wherein it is very obervable, that it is not aid, they made him grind, or they forced him to grind, but he did grind in the prion houe: And it is o much the more obervable, becaue all the injuries done to him before named, are expreed by a force put upon him; they took him, they put out his eyes, they brought him down to Gaza, they bound him with fetters, and if this lat, had been a like injury and force unto him, it had been more congruous to have
continued the ame manner of expreion, and to have aid, They made him grind; but the violence is here left out, and his grinding made his own doing, He did grind in the prion houe. Beide thoe Manicles put upon him were exceedingly inconvenient for a grinder in a Mill? And it is mot improbable, that for that mall advantage or pleaure that hould accrue to them by his grinding in a Mill, that they hould at any time take off his etters, ince they had had o many, and o ad experiences of his unparallel trength. And if at any time they hould looe him, then ure was the leat danger, when the Lords of the Philitines, and three thouand of the people were gathered together to ee him make port; yet at that time he was kept (by his chains doubtles) at the dipoure of a Lad;Ver. 26. For Samon aid to the Lad that held him by the hand, uffer me that I may feel the pillars whereon the houe tandeth, that I may lean upon them. Moreover, the ancient Rabbies give us an Interpretation upon this place, which is not altogether improbable, and which is confirmed unto us by Hieron in his Commentary upon the econd vere of the forty eventh Chapter of Iaiah, and that is, that this people being very deirous of Giants, and boating much in their
trength (as is well known by acred Story) brought of their choicet, and lutiet women to him in the Prion, that from this mighty Detroyer of their Country, they might have a Gigantick Race for its preervation: However in the main, I perwade my elf, his grinding was nothing ele, but performing the offices of nature, his eating, and drinking, and being nourihed there; his turning his food into chyle, his chyle into bloud, his bloud into fleh, and other the like natural operations, which is the true meaning of the word grinding in this place.

We now proceed to the ound of the grinding, which is nothing ele but that, by which the grinding is known, ome natural ymptome ignificative of digetion; and all thoe indications that do demontrate that the works of nature proceed aright, and according to their primitive intitution (whether it be the appetite of the parts, their action or excretion of their excrements, thoe ubervient faculties which uually are called Attraction, Retention, Expulion, or whatoever ele may manifet Concoction) may truly and properly be called the voice of the grinding. I hall intance in a few, whereby the ret may be eaily dicerned, and therein I hall
oberve my former method having reference only to thoe five great works of nature before treated of. The voice of the firt grinding, is the natural appetite of the tomack to meat and drink, and is uually called hunger and thirt; the trength and power of the tomack to retain its food; and the eaonable evacuation of well concocted excrements. The voice of the econd, is a free paage of the chyle without obtruction, a quick, trong, and a lively pule; a due eparation of gall, of urine, and the ret of the excrements of this Concoction. The voice of the third, is the proper tone of all the parts of the body, the fatnes and fulnes of the fleh, and convenient perpiration. The voice of the fourth,Gen. 31. 3 is the Cutome of women, the tiffnes, lively colour, and frehnes of the nipples, the moothnes, fairnes, elevation, and towring of the breats, as it is called in Scripture,Cant. 8. 10. Her breats are as towers. The voice of the lat, is appetite, aptnes, and ability for Copulation; Inflation, and Turgecency of the Seminary veels both preparatory, and ejaculatory; commonly called, Fratration; a right temperament of the parts appointed for propagation, trength, vigour, and livelines of the whole body beide: Thee, and the
like excellencies of nature are the voice of the everal grindings while they remain in power; but as age enfeebleth a man the grindings are weaker, and the everal voices of them more ubmis; wherefore it doth necearily follow, that in decrepit age, all the before mentioned indicatours of trength and perfect Concoction mut be depraved, diminihed, or abolihed; which is the lownes of the ound of the grinding, and doth include the weaknes of the natural faculties in man which tand in direct oppoition to thoe excellent voices before treated of, and uch are thee that follow: Dejectus appetitus, imbecillitas tomachi, faeces alvi indebitae: obtructiones omnes, pulus debilis, ra ••• , tard • s; mala anguinis defaecatio quoad erum, bilem, &c. tonus partium vitiatus, Carnis ariditas, indebita perpiratio: Ceatio menium, papillarum pendentia & lividitas, mammarum flacciditas & rugoitas: impotentia & inappet entia Concubitus, vaorum permaticorum imbecillitas & < in non-Latin alphabet > , Rom. 4. 19. tetium & partium propagationi dicatarum Cachexia & refrigeratio, totius corporis langu • r & marcecentia. Thee are the decaies of man intended in this part of the Allegory.

Now the grinding and the voice thereof being thus far explained, I quetion not
but the doors and treets, that relate thereunto, are by this time undertood; but becaue the word doors hath ome peculiarity in it, I cannot but take more notice of it: < in non-Latin alphabet > this word being of the duall number, ignifieth properly the two doors, or both the doors, or the double doors. And although I know no authority for the tranlating of it into Latine, otherwie than fores, or otia; yet I ubmit it to the Learned to conider, whether the word Valvae or Valvulae will not as well, if not better, agree to the Text; the folding doors, or the doors that clap together, or that have a double ue. For the better undertanding it, therefore we mut know that the doors that relate to the grinding before poken of, are of two orts; either the extream doors, or the intermediate doors. Again, the extream doors alo, are of two orts; either the fore doors, or the back doors; either the doors that firt let in the matter of nourihment for the body, that it may therein be ground for its ue; or the doors that lat let out the relicts of the grindings, or that matter that upon the everal grindings becomes altogether ueles. The fore doors, or the doors by which the food is firt let into the body, are none other than the Lips, for by the
hutting of them, the meat is kept out, and by the opening of them, it is let in, to the firt grinding in the mouth. And as they are called doors in repect of words, foramuch as they let them out;Pal. 41. 3 Keep the door of my lips, aith David. And again, Keep the doors of thy mouth from her that lieth in thy boome. Mic 7. 5. So they may as aptly be called doors in repect of the meat; for they let that in.

And hence it is, that the Orbicular Mucles, which make the ubtance of the lips, (being therefore called the Calves of the Lips,)Ho. 14. 2 and have the power of the keys to hut and open them, are called Oris Pylori, the explication of which word (as being very conducible to what we are now about) you have hereafter. And therefore thoe former Interpreters that have applied thee words to the Lips, have done exceeding well; the report they have given hath been true; yet I may, with the Queen of Sheba, farther add, Behold the half hath not been told us, 1 King. 10 6, 7. the widom of Solomon exceeding the fame which we have heard. For beide thee fore doors, there are other extream doors alo, viz. the back doors, which erve only for the carrying out of the Excrements. And although the Ears, the Notrils, and the
Eyes, and all the Emunctories of the body may be here included, yet thoe which are principally intended, are thoe eminent Poterns, which o long as man lives in trength are alwaies ready for their work, which is to give pas to thoe three everal Excrements which we dayly avoid, either by the guts, the bladder, or the habit of the body; and therefore thee doors are, Sphincteres ani, & veicae, & pori Cutis: For all thee have a power of opening and hutting, and conequently of keeping in, or letting out, whatoever comes unto them, and are often at convenient eaons retracted for the cleaning of the body. Thus far of the extream doors, which are placed at the extremity of the body, and erve only for inlets or outlets to the urface of the body, for all that which is either deired or rejected of nature. The intermediate doors are eated within the body, and are inlets and outlets only from one part of the body to another; like the doors within the houe, which according to their hutting or opening are tops or paages from one Room of the houe to another. Thee may be aid to be double doors, becaue they relate to two parts, to that which is before, and to that which is behind; they let out of that, and into
this; and of this ort there are very many in the body of man, and ome, I perwade my elf, that are not yet ufficiently dicovered. The firt that the matter of nourihment meets with after it is chewed in the mouth, is the Pharynx, or head of the oeophagus, which while it be kept cloe, keeps the meat in the mouth, till it be there ufficiently ground, and afterward by the retraction of the Mucle of the throat, which for this very reaon is called Sphincter gulae, it is committed into the throat, which is the high way to the tomack; but before it can come there, it meets again with another door, which is called, the mouth, or uperior Orifice of the tomack, which unles it be opened alo it cannot pas. And this any man may perceive in himelf in a morning, or after the mouth of the tomack hath been long and cloe hut, if he hatily wallow down olid food before he drink, it makes a top there, and tands knocking as it were, with pain waiting for admittance. The third door that the chyle meets withal, is the paage out of the tomack into the guts, and this is the inferiour Orifice of the tomack; which is o wonderfully framed, that it gives eaie admittance for the chyle from the tomack to the guts, but back
again from them to this, very difficult, or none at all; and it hath a power of dilating or contracting it elf, making way, or topping it, according as the neceity of Nature requireth; from whence it is by Anatomits called Pylorus, which is a Greek word, as mot of the Anatomical terms are, and is derived from < in non-Latin alphabet >
porta, and < in non-Latin alphabet >
curam gero: and is as much as Janitor, the Porter or door-keeper; and it doth faithfully, according to the dictates of nature, hut or open that paage unto which it appertains. Beides thee three, there are many others which I hall only generally name; The Capillaries of all the containing veels in the body, the feveral tops of all the Veins and Arteries, which are called valvulae, epecially thoe eminent ones about the heart, of which more hereafter, the poroity of all the inward parts of the body, the Valvula Coli, the Annulus Fibrous of the bladder of gall, the everal heads of the Ureters, their wonderful inertion into the bladder, thee, and whatoever ele in the body of man can by their contriction top that which comes unto them, and by their dilatation give it convenient paage, are in this place called, the doors of the treets.

The treets are thoe open waies and
paages in the body of man, which the matter of nourihment paeth along without let or moletation.1 King. 2 • , 34. Thou halt make thy elf treets in Damacus, aith Benhadad to Ahab; that is, thou halt pas through Damacus at thy pleaure, without interruption; there hall alwaies be a broad and an open way. Platea dicitur à < in non-Latin alphabet > , latus; and in this place is, as much as, Latitudo foranea patens & aperta. And of uch there are divers found in our body; The oeophagus, or Gullet, the ix everal intetines or guts, as uually they are divided by Anatomits; the milky veels of one ort and of another; all the Veins and Arteries; the Nerves and Lymphaeducts; the ductus Cholidochi, Pancreaticus, Salivalis; the Vaa praeparantia & deferentia, tubuli lactiferi; the Ureters and the Uretra, in a word, all the Communes ductus, or open paages which are by nature appointed for the conveyance either of the Aliment or Excrements, are the treets here intended; foramuch as they have reference to the grinding before mentioned, and are the common roads or high waies to, and from, the places where the grinding is performed.

What remains now, but only that I briefly name unto you thoe ymptomes of
age which are ignified unto us by this claue, The doors hall be hut in the treets. What the doors are you have abundantly heard, the hutting or them is nothing ele but their ceaing from their ue, or their not being exercied to that end unto which by nature they are appointed; when by reaon of the extremity of age the voice of the grindings is very low, then hall the doors, all the doors, both the doors, the doors of both kinds, the double doors, hall be hut in the treets; they hall all have lot their opening faculty, o that they hall neither let in, nor let pas, nor let out, what they ought to do, as they formerly did, o long as the trength of man remained, and the voice of the grinding was high. Occluio labiorum contraum cibum; oberatio pharyng is, ulriusque orificii ventriculi; deglutiendi difficultas, impotentia reerandi in omnibus, arteriarum & venarum, imo omnium internarum partium otiis, & valvulis; pororum contrictio; dyuria, tranguria, icuria; alvi adtrictio, en potius pigra tardaque depoitio. Thee and the like ymptomes that arie from the inability of thoe parts that have in themelves a power of opening and hutting for the benefit of the body, are hereby indicated unto us. And thus far of the
natural faculty of man, both in reference to the preervation of the Individual, and the propagation of the Species; from which hort obervations they that are better skilled in the hidden mytery of the frame of mans body and know all the wonderful alterations that are therin made may eaily attain the knowledge of the full cope and intention of the Wie-man in this place.

div.head: He hall rie up at the voice of the bird.
div.p:
This expreion being in it elf eaier than the ret and having been well undertood by mot that have conidered this. Allegory, I hall not much init upon it. I hall only tell you, that it is to be undertood of thoe infirmities of age, whereby men are altogether unable to take that content and quietnes, that leep and nocturnal repoe, which formerly they had ued to be refrehed with, there are that earnetly contend to have the latter part tranlated. Ad vocem paeris; others would have it, Ad gallicantum; others are content with, Advocein volueris. For my own part I think it not worth the dipute what this bird is in particular: The generall word pleaeth me bet, and the Original word, Omnem ignificat avem mane urgentem ad gurriendum; For the Radix
is < in non-Latin alphabet > and hath two eminent ignifications, one is, Alas habere ive evolare; and the other, Maturare ive mane urgere; and that which ele where is tranlated the early morning,Ezek. 7. 10. is from the ame root with this word in the Text, o that if we ay, the early bird, or the bird that is warbling its accutomed note betime in the morning (without decending to particulars) we hall take in the whole latitude of the ignification of the word, and the full cope of this part of the decription of age; which is nothing ele but to hew how retles, and wakeful men are in their old age, o that that which is aid of the abundance of the rich man, may as truly be aid of the infirmity of the old man,Eccl. 5. 12 it will not uffer him to leep. In the night time poibly he may have ome unquiet drowings, but when the morning approacheth, that time wherein man in his perfect tate taketh the greatet refrehment, and the oundet leep; then hall he be broad awake, and riing up; He hall rie up at the voice of the bird; that is, at that time when they utter their voices; not (as ome have interpreted it,) Cauâ vocis aviculae, by reaon of the voice of any bird, as the crowing of the Cock, or the like, as if the voices of them, hould wake them from
their leep; for it is not aid, he hall wake at the voice of the bird, but he hall rie at the voice of the bird, preuppoing his being awake long before, it may be all the night: Beide the enuing words, as you hall immediately hear, do demontrate the deafnes of old men, and therefore it is not to be thought that they hould eaily be tartled, as it were, and awaked at the voice of any bird; therefore it mut of neceity be undertood, as it is elewhere phraed,Cant. 2. At the time when the inging of the birds is come. Now the time of the inging of the birds may be aid to come, Annually, or Diurnally. The yearly coming of the inging of the birds is in the pring of the year; to which alluion is had in that place of Solomons Song: And the dayly coming of the inging of the birds is in the pring of the day, or very early in the morning; by which time the decrepit old man is very weary of his bed, having in it neither eae, nor leep. The inging of the birds, and the ighing of old men, are early Contemporaries: Thee are as
• oon weary of their lodgings, through the pains and wakefulnes, that hath attended them in the night eaon; as they are lifting up their pleaant notes, after their refrehment. Anxiety and trouble of mind, was
o grievous to Ahauerus, Het. 6. 1. that it is aid, On that night could not the King leep: Upon the ame occaion it is aid concerning Darius, Dan. 6. 18. His leep went from him: Pains and dieaes of the body, were o troubleome to Job, that he complains,Job 7. 4. When I lye down I ay when hall I arie, and the night be gone, and I am full of toings too and fro, untill the dawning of the day: both thee joyned together in age, together with that which is wore, namely, the natural drynes of the brain, and a Conumption of thoe benign vapours that overcome it in leep; mut needs produce the like, or more uncomfortable effects. So that the ymptomes hereby indicated unto us are, Anxietates animi, inquietudines nocturnae, & dolores Corporis; and principally the product of them both, which is Vigiliae.

I hould thus pas hence-from, were there not a grand objection lying hid in the body of this dicoure, which upon this occaion doth more apparently dicover its face. It may be here aid, are there not ome Contrarieties in this decription of age, or at leat in this Interpretation of it? Are there not ome inconitent ymptomes reckoned up, to make this mierable tate yet far wore than it is? Was
not Carus and Apoplexia dieaes of overmuch leep, in the Expoition of the econd vere numbred among the Symptomes of age: How therefore comes it to pas that Vigiliae, or over-much wakefulnes can be an attendant upon the ame condition?

To this I mut anwer, Were this our fault, it were not ours alone; for o clear is the Cae, and the truth of it by dayly experience o apparent, that whooever hath at any time treated of the dieaes of age hath contantly enumerated them both, Hippo. l. 3. Apho. ult. Galen l. 3 c. 6. de anitate tuenda. Ranchin. de morborum enum d • lis. as being not the leat inconitent one with another; and that is, becaue they are not of the ame kind; Necee et ut oppoita int ub eodemgenere. Now leep, and the abtinence from it, may each of them be conidered either in genere naturali, or in genere praeternaturali; there is a natural, there is a dieaed or preternatural leep. And between thee there is a vat difference. Natural leep, is a woing of the body and mind to quietnes, whereby the benign vapours, by their amicable embraces of the brain, get power of it, for its refrehment: Preternatural leep, is a committing a rape upon the body and mind, whereby the offenive uperfluities, by their violent aaults, force the brain to a
benummednes for its detruction; the ame Diametrical difference there is between natural and preternatural wakefulnes. Natural waking, is when the brain, by its own vigour and trength, doth, Samon like,Judg. 16. 20. arie and hake it elf; Cating off all thoe exhalations which, having pent their vertue for the refrehment of the body, are become altogether ueles; o that hence-from all the pirits of a man are enlivened, As a bridegroom coming out of his Chamber, Pal. • 9. 5 and rejoycing as a trong man to run a race; but when the race is run, and the pirits are thereby tired, there is need of a recruit by leep. So then, when there is in the nature of man a paucity of thoe pleaant vapours, and an ineptitude in the brain to receive thoe few that are, there mut needs follow natural watching or wakefulnes. Preternatural waking and watching, on the contrary, are, when there is an external force put upon the brain, either to raie it from leep, or to keep it o. Now, to apply this ditinction, we mut know that leep and the want thereof are directly contrary one to another, uppoed alwaies they be in the ame kind.
