Preternatural leep, and preternatural watching are altogether inconitent, and therefore an Apoplex and a
Frenzy, are in no wie incident to the ame peron at the ame time: So alo natural leep and natural watching are inconitent one with another, and not competible to the ame age; but are to be found in man at as great a ditance as his life will give way for; Senibus naturale est vigilare, pueris dormire; but when they are one of one kind, and another of another, namely, preternatural leep, and natural watching, they may both of them without any incongruity at all, be reckoned up as the Symptomes of old age.

I make the more of this ditinction, (though very common and ordinary,) and o I would have others do too, becaue of its univeral ue upon this occaion; for not only here, but in mot of the other decriptions of age, it hath its place for the deciion of Controveries; in the very lat decription, Pigra & tarda alvi depoitio was numbred as a ymptome of age, becaue the Sphincter ani is hardly and eldome retracted for the natural evacuation of the Excrements of that kind; yet alvi humiditates are reckoned as an attendant on the ame tate, Hippo. l 3. • pho. ult. becaue without any opening of the door, there is a preternatural flux that way. So alo in their Urine, there is a continual topping, and
yet withall a continual dropping. The Teeth are relaxed by reaon of drines, and yet moyture expels them their ockets. Siccity of the Eyes is their chiefet dieae, and yet they run with a continual Rheume; Hardnes and drines alo is the temper of the brain, and yet it is alwaies ditilling Coryza's and Catarrhes. In a word, this ditinction will be found of mot general ue, foramuch as there is uch an intricate mixture of naturality and preternaturality in age, o that that plain and eaie decription which is uually given of it, eems to me ingenious and mot ignificant. Senectus et morbus naturalis.

div.head: All the Daughters of Muick hall be brought low.
div.p:
The Organs that have reference to Muick in the body of man (beide which I would by no means eek an Interpretation) are of two orts. They are either uch as make muick themelves, or uch as take and receive the Muick that is by others made; the firt of thee I call, the Active daughters of Muick, foramuch as they are themelves muical, and every one of them bear their part in making of it; the other I call, the pasive daughters of Muick, foramuch as they only receive it, taking
delight in that, of which they have not the leat hare in making.

The Chaldee Paraphrae hath reference to the firt of thee, when it aith, Remittentur labia tua à dicend • Cantico. The Lips, and whatoever other parts in man, are any way intrumental unto inging, may be very well ignified unto us by the Cantatrices multeres, or female Choriters in the Text; and thee are very many in our bodies. For beide thoe remote helpers, the Thorax, the Diaphragma, the Mucles, the Nerves, the Glandules, &c. There are three everal kinds of Organs, that do more immediately, and yet ditinctly and gradually conduce to the production of vocall Muick. The firt, are thoe that prepare and adminiter the matter for a ound; The econd, are thoe that form that ound into a voice; The third, are thoe that modulate that voice unto Muick.

The firt of thee, are none other than the Lungs, which are the proper intruments of our breathing; which how excellent it is in it elf, and how neceary to our being,Gen 2. 7. Job 1 • . 10. the Scriptures of God do demontrate without compare. The life of man in this world, runs parallel with his breath;Pal. 104. 19. All the while my breath is in me,
and the Spirit of God is in my nostrils; Job 27 3. and the death of man is till ignified by the departure of his breath; It is aid of the widows child, He had no more breath left in him. 1 Kings 17. 17. Pal. 146. 4. Plainly throughout the whole Word of God, breath, and life, and oul, and pirit, are ynonomous, and often made exegetical one of another. Among other excellencies of breathing, that whereby it is made intrumental to peech and harmony is not the leat; in all wind Muick, there mut be firt a gathering of the air into ome Cavity to contain it, and afterward a preing of it forth into thoe pipes or holes, that are artificially made for the dividing it unto its appointed end; Now of this kind of Muick is the voice, and the Lungs being of a light, oft, pongy ubtance, are thoe parts, that do both draw in, contain, and pres forth the air, the matter of the voice, according as there is occaion. And thoe Creatures that have no Lungs have conequently no voice, o that Fihes, which are herein deficient, are mute even to a Proverb. And man himelf, if by reaon of any preternatural matter tuffing the Lungs, or by reaon of any violent motion, or long expiration, he becomes out of breath, he is not able to peak, much les to ing, till he have recovered it again.

The econd ort of Organs that conduce to Muick, are uch, as form the breath into a voice; And they by Logicians, under whoe ubject they do directly fall, are accounted nine, numbred up in this following Ditick.
Smith aditus ad Log. l. 1. c. 2.
Intrumenta novem, unt guttur, lingua, pala-
Quatuor& dentes, ac duo labra imul. (tum, And moreover, hence it is that the wiet of Grammarians, oberving that the everal words, by which man uttereth his voice, are formed againt thee everal parts, ometime more againt one, ometime more againt another; have aptly divided their Letters, the firt compounding parts of words into gutturales, linguales, palatina • , dentales, & labiales, according as in their pronuntiation they bear themelves the hardet againt either of thoe parts.

That part which thee two Artits have called guttur, Anatomits do more trictly and properly call, Trachaea ive apera arteria; and ince the word Artery is derived
< in non-Latin alphabet > , this of all the parts of the body may primarily and mot aptly bear that name: for this is the great Con
•• uit pipe of air in repiration; it gives pas
unto it in inpiration, and in expiration (whereby the voice is framed) it gives a certain impreion, which is the firt alteration of it towards Articulation; which impreion doth remain in the voice when perfected; o that if thee parts do firt dipoe the voice to hoarnes or hrilnes, or any other preternatural tone, the whole peech hath a tincture of the ame imperfection. And hence it is, that the Welh pronunciation being performed by too hard a colliion of the air againt thee parts, makes all their letters and words to become guttural.

The econd Intrument of the voice is the tongue, and this, by reaon of its fungous ubtance, and volubility, is o meet, and o principal an agent therein, that peech it elf, and all the variety thereof, doth among all orts of men go by the name of tongue;Acts 2. There were in the daics of the Apotles dwelling at Jerualem devout men out of every Nation under heaven, and they all aid, we do hear them peak,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , in our own tongues, the wonderful works of God. Ver. 11. And this great miracle, both as unto hearing, and alo unto peaking, is introduced by the appearance of Cloven tongues,Ver 3. to hew that the chiefet intrument of the voice,
was to be acted by the Holy Ghot;Ver. 4. For they began to peak with other tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance. Among the many expreions that the Word of God abounds with, for the confirmation of this truth I cannot but take pecial notice of that of David, Pa. 139. 4. where he aith, There is not a word in my tongue, but thou knowet it altogether. As if that member alone kept the power of words within it elf, and ordered them all according to its own pleaure; and where there is an inability of peaking, it is aptly aid, uch perons are tongue-tied, and when that faculty is again retored,Mar. 7. 35 it is aid, the tongue is looed; and o was it with Zacharias, concerning whom, after he had been dumb for a eaon, it is aid,Luk. 1. 64 his mouth was opened immediately, and his tongue looed, and he pake and praied God.

The third Intrument towards the formation of the voice is the pallate of the mouth, for beide, that ome particular Letters and words are formed more immediatly againt this part, it doth alo give trength & clearnes to the whole voice, and to all the words that are pronounced in the mouth. And this it doth the better do, becaue the tenuous bone that makes the Pallate, is an arched roof, covered over with a
nervous skin, corrugated with everal aperities, for the better retaining and rebounding the air in the voice. And all our places dedicated to divine ervice, are made of the ame concamerated form on the top of them, (quetionles in imitation hereof,) for the better ounding and echoing orth both of vocal and intrumental muick. And beide the bone which contitutes the Pallate, there is a little flehy part, which is called the Uvula, that doth o much contribute to the voice, that it deervedly retains the name of plectrum vocis. Paulus Aegin • ta l 6. c. 51. That the Pallate or roof of the mouth is a great intrument in peaking, is ufficiently proved by the defect thereof, for if there be the leat fault in this part, there preently ucceeds a faltring in the Speech. So that a man may ay to any Son of Venus, who hath followed her detructive enticements to this imperfection, Thou alo art one of them, thy peech bewrayeth thee. This part, together with that lat mentioned, is taken notice of, as erviceable unto peech, by Jo • , when he aith,Job 29. 10. The Nobles held their peace, and their tongue cleaved to the roof of their mouth. And God himelf aith unto the Prophet, I will make thy tongue cleave to the roof of thy mouth that thou halt be dumb. Ez • k. 3. 26.

Fourthly, The teeth, and epecially the four fore-teeth, are very intrumental to our peech, Dentition and Locution are for the mot part Contemporaries; toothing and peaking uually come, and go together; the Child cannot peak till he put forth his teeth, neither can he peak well, when he heds them, nor leave his liping till they come again. And the reaon of it, is becaue there are many words that are pronounced by the dilatation of the tip of the tongue, and clapping of it againt the teeth, which any man may eaily experiment in himelf, if he will but gently aay to pronounce any word that hath Th together in it; and all thoe Operators that live by etting in of Artificial teeth, do oberve that they have more come to them upon the account of their peech, than for all other ends whatoever; and indeed this ingenious help of Art, doth in no other defect of nature, make uch compleat reparation.

The lat Intruments of the voice are the Lips; even as the Apera Arteria (as was aid) gave the firt Articulation, o thee do give the ultimate Completion to our words; o that when they have once lipped this guard we can have no more power over them. Necit vox mia, reverti:
that which is gone out of thy lips thou halt perform, Deut. 23. 23. aith the Lord. How exceedingly intrumental the lips are to peaking, the Scripture doth abundantly prove, He that will love life, and ee good daies, 1 Pet. 3. 10. let him refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they peak no guile. Hence is it, that as the words are, o the lips are often aid to be:Pal. 12. 2. 17. 1. 31. 18. Ia. 6. 5. 28. 11. Heb. 13. 15. Ia. 57. 19. therefore we read of flattering, fained, lying, unclean, tammering lips, &c. And again, words are elewhere called, the fruit of the lips; Let us offer the acrifice of praie to God, that is the fruit of the lips. And thee are the econd ort of Organs that conduce to vocal Muick, namely, thoe that form the ound unto a voice.

The third are thoe that modulate this voice into muick; and although it here mut alwaies be acknowledged, that every one of the parts before mentioned, do alo contribute omething towards modulation; yet the more proper and peculiar intruments thereof, are the Cartilagineous parts of the Apera Arteria, or the windpipe; and epecially thoe which are termed, the Larynx and the glottis. The Larynx is the head of the windpipe, which although it be but a very little part, yet doth conit of more variety of compounding parts,
than any other whatoever; as little as it is, it hath thirteen Mucles belonging unto it, mot of which are framed only for the modulation of the voice; ome hut the pipe, ome open it, ome dilate, ome contract it, o that acting everally, or joyntly according as there is occaion; they do wonderfully conduce to the variation of the tone. It hath moreover five Cartilages, whoe ubtance and conitence is mot apt of all other whatoever, for the dividing of a ound; ome of them are movable, ome immovable, ome of one form, ome of another, that they may the better contain the air; and alter and break the voice into melody. Beide it hath certain Glandules belong unto it, which by their vicous moyture do o irrigate, and as it were oyle the pipe, that it takes off the harhnes that otherwie would be found, and adds much weetnes and pleaantnes to the Muick. The glottis is reckoned among the Cartilages before mentioned, yet becaue it is the principal intrument of modulation, we cannot but take mot pecial notice of it. And it therefore bears its name, becaue what eminency the tongue hath above the ret in reference to our peech, the ame hath this part in reference to our inging; for the air being
preed forth from the Lungs, this part rieth up to meet it, embraceth it, plaies with it, and by a certain innate property of its own, without the help of Mucles, alters it, divides it, at its own pleaure, into all that diverity of amplifications and flourihes, that the Art of man can poibly reach unto. If a man make a pipe in the middle of a green reed, and leave the inward thin film as the tongue of the pipe, and then breath againt it; he hall then find, that tongue to receive the breath, and o to modulate it; that it hall be a lively, though but a hort reemblance, of what we are now peaking of. And indeed, whatoever Art can do, mut give way to the works of nature: And that one pipe in man, which hath the widom of God for its formation to the intent of muick, can amplifie and divide a ound, to as much variety of muical accents, as Davids Intrument that had ten trings.Pa. 144. 9. For there is no Intrument howoever formed, that can urpas the muick of the voice, which is performed by the everal Organs we have here recited, which may therefore jutly be called, the Active Daughters of Muick.

The Paive Daughters of Muick, are thoe which only receive the Muick that
is by others made, and thee are the Organs of hearing; which indeed may mot properly be called, Filiae Carminis, or Filiae Cantici, and eem primarily to be intended in this place; for as a learned Commentator rendreth the reaon of it exceeding well;Corne • . • L • p. Aures ad hoc unum factae unt, ut voces & Carmina audiant, quare ex iis natae, • orumque filiae ee videntur. And again, Objectum delectabile efficit in auribus enationem delectabilem, quare ejus quai parens, & mater ee videtur. All the everal graces and eligances of Muick, the oft and ilky touches, the quick and pleaant relihes, the nimble tranitions, and delicate cloes, are far more exactly repreented in the Intruments of hearing, than the Image of the Mother is in the Daughter; Ventrem equitur partus, the birth is like the belly that bears it, but the Muick that is heard, is even the ame with that which is made: For there is a continuation of the audible Species from the maker of them, to the lat receiver; without any production of new. And that this may be the better done, there are everal parts, both for the apprehending of the variety of ounds, as they pas up and down in the air, and alo for the Commodious conveying of them, that they
may make a due impreion upon the proper Organs of Hearing; plainly, there is the outward and the inward Ear.

The outward Ear is pread abroad like a net, that it may catch and gather into it elf,Avecen. that vocalem, or onantem undam, as it roles about the Ocean of the Air; which that it may the more conveniently do, the Cartilagineous part of it is divided into two winding Channels, called the Helices, or Elices, which draw and uck into themelves the wave before mentioned, and pas it into the Auditory gulph. I know the word Helices, is motly wrote with an H, and then it mut be derived from < in non-Latin alphabet >
cum apero, which ignifieth Involvo, Circumago, Circumvolvo. And thus primarily the word ignifieth a certain ort of twining Ivy, and from thence then mut the Metaphor be fetched, and that very appoitely, relating to their form: But I rather incline to thoe who write it without an H, and then it mut be derived from
< in non-Latin alphabet >
cum tenui, which ignifieth, Coarcto, Cogo, in angustum redigo, in arctum Congrego, and thus the word ignifieth primarily, little Channels that are made to draw the water from ome great and bro • d over flowing ulci aquarii, water furro ••
or trenches to draw in the tream, and this relates to their ue. And thus it is an elegant Metaphor from waters; for thee parts do Elicere, allure and uck into their narrower Channels thoe ounds that wander more at liberty in the open air; and then they convey them to the meatus auditorius, which is ufficiently defended by the Tragus that is over it, and the Antitragus, that is near it, o that no violent noie can offend it, nor any preternatural matter fall into it, to obtruct it. This outward Ear is placed upon the Os p • troum, on the ide of the head, and at ome ditance from the head, and were it not preed and bound down while it was tender, it would tand at a further ditance, and conequently more commodious for hearing; o that while our Mothers and Nures tudy Ornament, they injure us: Indeed, they do hereby make us more unlike to the beats, but it is in uch an excellency, that it were well for us if we urpaed them. And hence may the reaon be given, why thoe that are thick of hearing, may find great benefit by laying their hand dilated behind their Ear, or uing ome Otaco •• t • on, and placing the mouth of it towards the ound, that they may thereby the better apprehend it; like unto thoe Animals, that litning
after any noie, prick up their ears, as we ay, and cat them forward, for the more expeditious receiving thoe motions of the air, that otherwie would pas by them more inenibly.

The inward Ear is a great ecret, and uch an one, that while the men of greatet knowledge have gone about to find-out and decribe, they have every one of them unk under his burden, and confet his own inability in ome uch expreion, as the Palmit concerning the general frame of mans body; Such knowledge is too wonderful for me, Pal. 139. 6. it is high, I cannot attain unto it. The firt part we meet with is a thin, trong, pellucide Membrane, called, the Tympanum, which being placed tranvere the hole of the Ear, doth divide between the ou • ward and the inward Ear, as the Diaphragme doth between the breat and the belly; within this there are three Cavities, the Concha, Labyrinthus, Cochlea; there are alo three little bones, the Malleolus, the Incus, and the Stapes; Moreover, there is implanted in the Ear, a pure, ubtill, and quiet air; which is called, aer innatus; And latly, and chiefly, becaue the proper Organ of hearing, we may oberve the Filaments, or the utmot extremities of the ofter part of the Auditory
Nerve, as they are wonderfully dipoed in the inward Cavity by the innate air; and then the whole Nerve it elf; by the help of thee everal parts our hearing is thus performed. The motion of the air (as that of the water) is continued by certain circles and rings, till it be taken by the outward ear, and by the Elices is conveyed upon the head of the Tympanum, where it makes the very ame impreion that it received from the body that made it; which impreion, by reaon of the Conjunction of the bones before mentioned, is continued unto the innate air, which, becaue in its elf mot quiet and till, is eaily moved according to the motion of the Tympanum; o that the Filaments hereunto annexed mut of neceity anwer the foreaid motion, and o conequently gather into themelves the ound or muick, which they convey to the Auditory Nerve, that from thence it may be ent to be dicerned and judged in the inward ene.

Thee are the Daughters of Muick, which, o long as man abides in trength, are exceeding lovely and flourih; but as he declines in age, thee alo pas their flower, they become humbled, and decline apace towards uelesnes and deformity.

In Age the everal holes and Cavities of the Ears are topped, the Drum is unbraced, the Hammer is weakned, the Anvill is worn, the Stirrop is broken, and the inward Air is mixed and defiled, the Filaments are dulled, the Nerve it elf is obtructed; o that there cannot but follow heavines of hearing, and at lat, deafnes it elf. And this is that imperfection which Barzillai complains of to King David, 2 Sam. 19. 35. I am this day eighty years old, and can I dicern between good and evil? Can I hear any more the voice of inging men, and inging women, wherefore then hould thy ervant be yet a burden to my Lord the King? And this certainly is the principal Symptome here intended by thee words, The Daughters of Muick hall be brought low. And therefore the Vulgar Latine tranlates it only, Oburdecent omnes filiae Carminis; but the word < in non-Latin alphabet > is of a far larger ignification, and might be tranlated many waies, as Deprimentur, Dejicientur, incurvabuntur; but cannot poibly be better tranlated than it is already by the Seventy,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , humiliabuntur, brought low. And this till holds out the native Latitude of the word; which I would by all means have preerved; that all the Daughters of Muick, both Active and Paive, and
their infirmities in age may be here included; o that all thoe ymptomes of the decrepit tate of man, that belong to any of the Organs before mentioned, whether of peaking or hearing, are to be undertood by this lat claue; All the Daughters of Muick hall be brought low; and uch are thee that follow: Dipnaea ive pirandi difficult as, destillationes tuim inferentes;
< in non-Latin alphabet > , ive vocis abolitio, diminutio out depravatio; exiccatio aperae arteriae, induratio Cartilaginum Laryngis, ordes aurium, praecipuè autem barycoia ive gravis auditus & urditas.

head.q: Vere 5. Alo when they hall be afraid of that which is high, and fears hall be in the way, and the Almond tree hall flourih, and the Grahopper hall be a burden, and deire hall fail; becaue man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the treets.

div.head: They hall be afraid of that which is high, and fears hall be in the way.
div.p:
The powers and faculties of the mind, as they are weakened in age, are abundantly decribed in the econd Vere: In thee words is notified unto us, that mot remarkable change that is made upon the affects and paions of the mind in the ame condition. And this is only in repect of fear, and thoe that are nearly related unto it. For as for thoe which are placed, < in non-Latin alphabet > , in appetitu Concupicente, uch as Love, Hatred, Deire,
Joy, and the like; they are in no wie exceive in this weak tate of age, foramuch as a firm and a vigorous habit of body, quick and lively enes, both outward and inward, do mot promote them; So that where there is a general defect in both thee, and all deire doth fail, it is not to be uppoed, there hould be any predominancy of any of thoe paions, that proceed from the Concupicible appetite; as for thoe which are placed, < in non-Latin alphabet > , in appetitu iracente; They all have for their object either good or evil; thoe which have good for their object, as Hope, and uch like, have little or no place in the time of age, foramuch as it is an evil time, and there is no pleaure in it. Now, all imminent evil is looked upon either as vincible, or invincible; if a man look upon an approaching evil, as that which he is able to overcome, it naturally produceth boldnes in him, which is the contrary paion to fear, and can in no repect agree to the ame perons. It remains therefore, that that ditres of the mind, which arieth from the apprehenion of ome approaching evil, that is either detructive or burdenome to our nature, and not eaily reitible by our trength, is the paion that is mot incident
to Age. True it is, that anger and vexation, grief and adnes, and uch like, as have for their object ome preent evil, and border hard upon this we are peaking of; may in ome meaure be found in Age; yet the true and proper, the mot notorious trouble of the mind, is that dumpih, melancholy, detructive paion of fear; which together with all its attendants and neceary conequences, uch as upition, jealouies, upertition, dilike, incontancy, betraying the uccours of reaon, are too familiarly oberved in the bet of men that are crooked with age; And by how much the more man declines, by o much the more do thee uperfluities encreae, like Miletoe, and ome other Excrecencies of trees, that flourih not, till the tock decay from which they pring. And the reaon of it is, becaue the true Caues of this affection (namely, miapprehenions of the things feared, and inability to reit them) are encreaed together with age, and therefore mut needs produce their anwerable effects. The firt of thee Caues, proceeds from the weaknes of the Imagination; the other, from the lownes of the pirits, and the imbecility of the outward Organs: The firt, makes the Caue of fear to eem the
greater; the other, to take the deeper impreion. Imagination puts a double fallacy upon ancient men; firt, it makes them undervalue themelves, and minorate their own abilities; and then it makes them overvalue the objects of • ear, and make them far greater than they are; like ome Perpective glaes, that at both ends mirepreent the things een, yet with a contrary appearance, at one end making them appear leer, and at a farther ditance; and at the other end, greater, and nearer than they ought. And hence it is, that they are o timorous upon every the leat occaion; that which is aid of wicked men, may alo be aid of old men; They are in great fear where no fear is; Pal. 53. 5 Qu ••
finxêre, timent; the weakned Imagination creating objects of fear unto it elf, or at leat much falcifying them, and encreaing them, like the man in the Gopel, that had but an half and a broken ight, He aw men as big as trees walking. Again, the dulnes and • eavines of the pirits, and the impotency of the members, renders a man mot obnoxious unto fear; the pirits being of a trong, quick, and ubtile motien, are the principal intruments of in
• er coure between the oul and the body, and do conequently bring in the greatet
aid and aitance againt this paion; but, in age they are benummed as it were, and congealed, o that they ceae much what from their operation and motion, and can adminiter little, or no courage at all.

Nor is it thus onely with the Spirits, but the Organical parts alo of the Body, are in this tate made unfit for their Functions, and altogether unerviceable to reit the very appearance of danger; and tand (as I may o ay) ready prepared for the entertainment of fear; The great conequences whereof, uch as whitenes and tiffnes of the hair, trembling of the joynts and heart, impotency of peech, failing of the eyes, and atonihment, palenes of the face, horrour, gnahing of the Teeth, involuntary Emiion of Excrements, are very eaily produced in this condition; nay, they are mot of them already there to be found, without an object to effect them; therefore no wonder if thoe things which are < in non-Latin alphabet > to the trong Man, prove < in non-Latin alphabet > to the decr • pit.

Thee things were known to be true, without an Intance; yet, I cannot but take notice of Jacob, who, while young and trong, did exceed mot Men we read of, for Courage and Boldnes; with what audacity did he manage the two great Enterprizes
of obtaining both the Birth-right and the Bleing; and that while he was yet very young? with what Courage did he undertake, and go through with a long and loneome journey, and hard and a deceitful Service? but when he was old he was of a more timorous pirit: it was fear let fall that paage, If I am bereaved, I am bereaved. Gen. 43. 14. Such newes as one would have thought would have refrehed his heart, when he was old overcame it; for when it was aid Joeph is yet alive, Gen. 45. 26. and he is Governour over all the Land of Aegypt, Jacobs heart fainted: Fear was a paion o ready at the door, that it tept in firt, and had almot over-born him, and left no place for joy to enter in.1 Sam. 2. 22. God Eli when he was very old, was very fearful, he timorouly reproves the outragious wickednes of his lewd Sons; and after this black and dreadful enemy had once taken poeion of him, it followed him continually, and dogg'd him till he died. When the Iraelites and Philistines were about to joyn Battel, he ate in a fearful poture, and it is aid, his beart trembled; and when the iue was told him,1 Sam. 4. 13. he fell from off his eat backward, and his Neck brake that he died; and the reaon is added,V. 1 • . for he was an old Man and heavy. I will not here be o bold as thoe
that ay (building their opinion upon the original word) his falling down backward and dying, was from a voluntary Principle; but I dare ay, it was from an inward one: his Age had o enfeebled him, that he was not able to bear the newes of a defeat, epecially uch an one, wherein the Ark of God was taken, but his darkome inward foe, taking advantage hereupon; trikes him urely, under the fifth rib, that he died.

The Objects of old Mens fears are here preented unto us under a double notion; Firt, thoe things which are high, Excela timebunt, aut de excelo; They hall be afraid of that which is high: Secondly thoe things which are lower, more plain and obvious, even in the way; Conternati in via, vel formidabunt in viis; Fears hall be in the may. Conternation and Fearfulnes do not urprize Men, and overthrow them all at once; Nemo repente • it timidisimus; but they come on by degrees, and firt thoe things that have more of dread in them, become the objects of their fear: High things; high, either in repect of place, as teep and emineut Wayes, Hills, and Mountains, Steeples and Towers, which formerly they could without fear acend, and walk upon: or high, in repect of the
Air, as Fiery Meteors, Strange Apparitions, Thunder and Lightning, and uch like: or high, in repect of abtrunes, or myteriounes, as the deep and ubtile points in Divinity, about the Ecence of God, and the duration of Eternity, about the Immortality of the Soul, and changes of the Body, and many other things, which while young they could better have born the Dicoure of: or high, in repect of Hardhip, or Difficult; thoe great Enterpries, and hazardous Undertakings, which while trong they durt with boldnes have ventered on, do now become a terror to them, even in the thought of them; but as Age comes on, and their feares increae upon them, not onely thoe things which are high, but even plain and eaie things becom the objects of their fear; Pavores in via: Mole-hills are now as dreadful, as Mountains were before; every thing that is near them, and about them; every thing that is plain and obvious; every matter that is facile, and eaily attainable, bears it elf with terror towards them; they are afraid of every thing they are doing: they walk in fear, ometime leat peradventure they hould dah their foot againt a Stone; ometime leat that other People heedlesly paing by, hould ruh upon them, and
injure them: being concious to themelves of their own impotency, it makes them mot obnoxious to this terrible paion, which is the great change that is made upon the Mind in the time of Age.

div.head: The Almond Tree hall flourih.
div.p:
The Symptome lat treated of was in reference to the great change that is made upon the Mind of Man; thoe which follow have reference to the Body. And that we may accurately oberve the Wie Mans Method, we mut premie one common ditinction of the parts of the body; for we mut know that thee are not independent ayings, cat forth at a venture, but a mot exact and methodical Treatie of the ymptomes of Age, as it influenceth and altereth all the parts of a Man: Now the parts of the Body (as the word is taken in the larget ignification) are either Animate or Inanimate; either uch as participate of the life of the whole, and are nourihed by the intra-uception of enlivened aliment; or uch as have no life at all from the Body, or in themelves, and are nourihed only by the juxta-poition of an excrement: Of the firt of thee, there are very many in the Body of Man, which are treated of in the following words: of the latter
of thee there are very few, as the nails and the Hair; and of thee the hair receiveth the mot notorious alteration in Age, which is here ignifyed unto us by thee words; The Almond Tree hall flourih.

The word which is here tranlated an Almond Tree, is from the original word
< in non-Latin alphabet > , advigilavit, to watch, or wake, as it is ued in that place;Pal. 127. 1. The Watchman waketh but in vain: And by way of Analogy it is tranlated to ignifie Amygdalus, the Almond Tree: Quae prima inter arbores evigilat; becaue this Tree before all others firt waketh, and rieth from its Winters repoe; it Flowers in the Moneth of January, and by March brings its Fruit to Maturity. Plin. lib. 16. c. 25. The forwardnes of this fruit-bearing Tree is intimated unto us by the viion of Jeremy; for the World of the Lord came unto him, aying, Jeremy what ee • t thou? and he aid, I ee a Rod of an Almond Tree: Then aid the Lord unto him, Jer. 1. 11. 12. thou hat well een, for I will haten my word to fulfill it. The ame word is in this Text ued, both for the Almond Tree, and for hatening; Thou hat therefore well een. Nothing could have better repreented the peedy fulfilling of the Word of God, then that hatening, the Almond Tree. The manner that the Wie Man is pleaed here
to take, to expres the great changes that happen to the Body of Man in the time of Age, is according to that intricate, and mot myterious, and aenigmatical way of the Aegyptians; whereby they are wont to expres their meaning of the things intended, by ome other Creatures which do mot reemble what they are peaking of. Now there is no change that befalleth Man that can be o lively repreented by the blooming of the Almond Tree, as that whereby the Hair of the Head becomes Hoary and White; and therefore florebit amygdalus, mut needs ignifie unto us, this great alteration; which bears reemblance unto that of the Almond Tree in everal particulars, ome of which follow hereafter.

Firt, They are both of them of the ame colour, and repreent themelves alike to the ight; the Bloomes of the Almond Tree are perfectly white, and o are the Hairs of the Old Man, and they are not onely nakedly of the ame colour, but both of them o, by way of eminency; not only white, but the whitet of all, none o white as they: Flores amygdali primi exitunt & maximi unt albi prae caeteris arboribus. So alo is it with Man in the time of Age, he is white, and no Creature, living to that time, o white as he: and hence it
is that Logicians make Canecere to be proprium homini, tertio mo • o; quod convenit omni, oli, non emper. They will allow no Creatures at all to grow white when they are old, as Man doth: and although our Sene teacheth us, that almot all Creatures tend towards that colour, yet they very much vilifie it in comparion of a Man, and therefore give it a far more inferior,Gricecere. and an unhandome Name.

Secondly, They do very much agree in their hatines, and forwardnes of putting forth; how early and quick the Almond Tree is in putting both its bloom and fruits hath been already • hewn; and might yet farther be confirmed in that great Mytery the Rod of Aaron, which although it was miraculouly changed in one nights time, as a Token againt the Rebels, to take away their Murmurings; yet it is to be noted, that it was done upon this forward Wood:Numb, 17. 8. And it came to pas that on the morrow, Moes went into the Tabernacle of Witnee, and behold the Rod of Aaron for the Houe of Levi was budded, and brought forth buds, and bloomed Bloomes, and yeilded Almonds. But naturally alo, this bloomes much ooner then other Trees; this is the true Erigeron, that early in the Spring-time bears the repreentati • n
of Old Age. Now it is better known to all Men how exceeding forward Gray-Hairs are.

There is no Symptome of Age puts forth its elf ooner then this; and as the Almond Tree buds ooner by two or tree Moneths then mot other Trees, o do thee haty buds of Age appear ometime twenty or thirty years before ome others: Some Mens Hair begins to change when they are but thirty or forty years of Age, whereas many other ymptoms appear not till they have paed ixty or eventy years. Thee teal upon Men uddenly, before they are aware, to which the Prophet doth allude in thoe ripe and unexpected Judgments that were falling upon Ephraim; Gray haires are here and there upon him, yet he knoweth it not. Ho. 7. 9.

Thirdly, They do agree in their eminency and remarkablenes, they are both of them mot ignal things; Men tand till and admire if accidentally they cat their eyes upon the Almond Tree that tands all on the Bloome; and o they do if they behold a comely and honourable
Head of Hair, that is as white as that: the Trees that bloome in March, or April, are little taken notice of, becaue then it is a common thing, neither have they that plendor upon them, that the Almond Tree hath, that advanceth its mot comely top all alone, while all other leep in their Winter Garments: In like manner the Almond Head is taken pecial notice of among a thouand, every one being very deirous to behold it, and that with great admiration and reverence; The glory of young Men is their trength, and the beauty and honour of old Men is the Gray-Head: Prov. 20. 29. And this honour is put upon it by the pecial appointment of God himelf, Thou halt rie up before the Hoary Head, and honour the face of the Old Man, and fear thy God: I am the Lord. Lev. 19. 32.

Fourthly, They are very much alike in their Indications, they are both of them mot certain Diagnoticks of the thing they appertain to; if there are no other ings then they, yet may all Men be very well aured of the truth they bepeak; If there be no other Tree in all the Woods, or Orchards, bloomed beide the Almond, yet know auredly from thence, the Spring is come; if there be nothing at all beides that hews it: if no Flowers appear on the Earth, if the inging of the Birds be not
come, if the voice of the Turtle be not heard in the Land,Cant. 2. 12, 13. if the Fig-Tree doth not yet put forth her green Figs, not the Vines with their tender Grape give a good mell; yet if the Almond Tree be bloomed, know of a truth, that the year is turned, and that the Sun is coming neerer towards us, and that the Sap tirs, though it be not elehow perceived: The ame certainty of demontration alo doth attend the Hoary Head; if no other ymptome appear, yet if the Hair begin to change white, know from thence, that the Winter of Age hath already begun to hew it elf; the evil dayes are coming on apace, though the Sun, or the Light, or the Moon, or the Stars be not darkned; though the keepers of the Houe, the trong Men, the Grinders, and the lookers out of the Windowes, be not yet enfeebled; though the Doors be open in the Street, and the voice of the Grinding, and the Daughters of Muick be as high as ever; yet if the Almond Tree flourih, if the Hair of the Head be changed to White, it is an undoubted Indication of the weaknes attending age: the habit of the Body is already changed, the innate heat begins to be uffocated, the radical moiture is conuming, the excrements (which contitute the Hair) are inconcocted,
and the temperament of Old age hath already eized the Man, although it be no other wayes to be dicerned.

Latly, They do alo exceeding well agree in their Prognoticks; they are both of them mot certain fore-runners and foretellers of what is to follow after them. If the Almond Tree be bloomed, it is a mot certain ign that Fruit will come after, and that it is not far behind; Aarons Rod budded (as you heard) and oon after it brought forth Almonds, the Flowers are in order to the Fruit that mut ucceed.

q.l: Induet in florem, & ramos curvabit olentes,
Si uperant faetus, pariter frumenta equentur

div.p:
And thus Gray Hairs the flowers of old age, do give a certain Prognotick, that death which is the Fruit thereof, is neer at hand. Jacob aith concerning his on Joeph, If michief befall him by the way, then hall ye bring down my gray hairs with orrow to the grave. Gen. 42. 38. A ad accident might have brought them down with orrow to the grave; but they would have come as urely without. Thee are Church-yard
flowers, which may erve to them that bear them, in tead of Paing-Bels, to give them certain notice, whither they are uddenly going. There are ome Naturalits who are yet bolder, and affirm, that the very thought and imagination of gray hairs, even in the dreams of them, though in a Peron never o young, do portend the ame thing: When they were Sacrificing in behalf of one of the Emperours of Rome, the hairs of a Boys Head, who did Adminiter to the Priets were all on a udden changed to white; which the Soothayers and Wie Men did preently interpret to the Change of the Emperour, and that an Old man hould ucceed, which accordingly fell out; for Nero, who was but one and thirty years old, was oon taken away, and Galba, who was eventy three, Reigned in his tead: There is far more certainty in the reality of the thing. It may thus fall out to young men, but it mut thus fall out to old: Mors, enibus, in foribus et; juvenibus, in infidiis: Young men are taken away, but Old men goe away, in their own natural coure; for Candidi are Candidati mortis, & per eam, immortalitatis. Thoe that are white are marked out in order unto death, and thereby unto immortality.
There might many other Particulars be aigned, wherein the Almond-Tree and the Hoary Head do exactly agree, but thee few may uffice to hew us, that the change of no other part of the Body in age, can be hereby figured out unto us o properly as this we have been peaking of.

Beide Canities is a contant attendant on age, and is intimated unto us in no other part of this allegory: How often in Scripture are they mentioned both together? I am now old and Gray Headed, aith Samuel:1 Sam. 12. 2. and David Prayeth, When I am old and Gray-Headed O Lord forake me not. Pal. 71. 18. Nay, I may ay one thing of this Symptome, that is not to be aid of any of the other; It is a plain and a full decription of Age, without any addition at all; ay a Gray-Headed man, and you ay an Old man, without any farther Periphrais. The word without, and terrour within, hall detroy both the young man, and the Virgin; the Suckling alo, with the man of Gray Hairs. Deut. 32. 25.

In the interpretation of this entence, and that which follows, which doth depend hereon, I mut of neceity recede omewhat both from the common Tranlation, and the uual interpretation of the place; wherein, if my opinion, together with its novelty, bring along with it any thing of atisfaction, I preume it will be never the wore accepted: For in thee Theoretical notions, the danger is not o great, to deviate from the beaten road, and to be Heterodox to the general received opinion. For the ubject of this Propoition, without all controverie, it is the Locut or Grahopper, which differ very little, either in their nature or form, and may very well intend the ame thing: The predicate is far more difficult, and therefore hath given occaion to more variety of tranlations; that which is mot uual is, Erit oneri, which our Englih exactly follows, The Grahopper hall be a burden; from whence mot Interpreters do put this ene upon the place, viz. that the Grahopper, or any uch mall thing, is a great burden to old men; which although it
may be a truth, yet it can in no wie be intended by thee words. For then King Solomon would in this claue vary much from the general cope of all thee veres, which is (as hath already been aid) Allegoricall, and from the particular mode of expreing himelf in this vere, which is Hieroglyphical. Beide the words in no propriety of Grammer can poibly bear uch a ene as this; and it hath been a great wonder to me how this Contruction was firt taken up, and how it hath gained o great credit among men: Nor can I yet give my elf the leat atisfaction herein, unles it be from the ambiguity of the Latine Phrae, Erit oneri, which may very well be taken in a double ene; either Erit oneri eni, seu alteri; or Erit oneri ibi. The firt of thee mut be taken for the carrying the words to the interpretation which hath been before mentioned; but how incongruous it is to the very Grammatical reading of the words, any one who is the leat skilled in the Original can eaily give an account. For what is here predicated is directly predicated of the Grahopper, and not in relation to any other peron, or thing ele whatoever. And hence ome have tranlated it, Onerabitur, ive gravabitur; others, Onerabit,
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
ive gravabit e; others, Crecet; the Vulgar Latine gives the Metaphor one remove more, to thoe that are burdened with fleh or fat, rendring it, impinguabitur Locuta; but the Tranlation of the Septuagint upon this word is mot remarkable, and gives very great light to the undertanding of the true meaning of the place, < in non-Latin alphabet > , Craabitur, denabitur, vel pinguecet. Wherefore that the doubtfulnes of peech, both in the Latine and Englih, (which hath miled mot Interpreters) may be for the future removed, I judge it mot convenient that the Tranlation of the Vulgar Latine take principal place, or that it be rendred in Latine, Locuta, onutam e reddet, or, praebebit; which the Conjugation doth motly favour; and in Englih, the Grahopper hall grow (or hew) big and burdenome. For the right undertanding of which words, we mut be ure to enquire, what parts of the body of man they are, that may be mot aptly repreented by the Grahopper, and what change that is, that is here denoted unto us: Which that we may the better do, we mut alo take notice of one pecial ditinction of the parts of the body.

Of the parts of the body that are enlivened
by the pirit of the whole (for of the other mention was made in the lat) there be two orts: Either the fluid, moyt, ucculent, tender, and oft parts of the body; or the dry, olid, tenile, hard, and cru •• y parts of the body. The firt of thee, eem to be intended in the following words, the lat of thee, in thee that are before us. This ditinction is uually termed, the ditinction of the Philoophers, in oppoition to all thoe manifold diviions of the parts of the body, that are to be found among Phyicians; And indeed it hath more of clearnes and demontration in it, than any of the other; neither that of Hippocrates in < in non-Latin alphabet > , & < in non-Latin alphabet > ; nor that of Galen, in permaticas & anguineas; nor that generally received among mot, In imilares & organicas, is without its difficulties; It hath put very learned and ingenious men very hard to it, to make the bet of thee tand firm againt its oppoers: but this that we are now peaking of, is o plain and obvious to the ene, that no man ever yet diallowed of it, or hath at any time undertaken to contradict it. Indeed, that ditinction of the parts into permatical and anguineous, as uually it is applied, comes the nearet to what is here intended; but
the terms are not o proper; and beide, they are built upon a fale foundation, which is, that the everal parts of the body have their origination from everal and ditinct principles of generation: viz. emen & anguis menstruus; but the ingenuity of this later Age, hath jutly exploded uch a Doctrine as that, and hath brought all knowing men to confes, that all the parts of the body, both of one kind and of another, have their original equally from one and the ame eminal matter. And yet the former ditinction of the parts, in molle • & duras, may be found to have a jut right, even from their firt producer. For the eed it elf, is not of o equal a ubtance and conitence, but that variety of parts, as to oftnes and hardnes, may eaily be dicerned in it. And this Job (beyond all humane Writers whatoever) doth plainly declare, when he aith,Job 10. 10. Thou hat poured me out like milk, and crudled me like Cheee. The very firt matter of generation in this repect hath a double ubtance; there is a lacteous, and a caeous part therein; there is a tenderer and a more fluid part; there is alo a more Condened and Coagulated part; which are apt to produce afterward parts in the body of the like diverification; as the following
vere doth plainly expres; Thou hast covered me with skin, and with fleh; thou hat fenced me with bones and with inews; bones and inews, they proceed from the crudled part of the eed; fleh of all orts, both Muculous, Parenchymous, and Glandulous, that proceeds from the fluid or milky part; and skin, that is the medium participationis of them both. Fleh and bones therefore eem to tand in the greatet oppoition one unto another in repect of this ditinction of the parts; And all the other parts of the body to each other, as they have relation to one of thee. Now which of thee two the Grahopper doth bet reemble, is very eaie for any one to give an account.

The Locut and Grahopper are both of them hard, cruty, cragged, crumpling Creatures, differing from all others principally in the protuberance of their limbs, having their legs trangely crooked, and their joynts very cloely inverted, and at a great ditance from the trunk of their body. And this is the mot remarkable thing in their frame, and that by which they are decribed in the Book of God;Lev. 1. 22. Yet thee may ye eat of every flying creeping thing that goeth upon all four, which have legs above their feet to leap withal upon the
earth; And afterward they are enumerated, The Locut after his kind, and the Grahopper after his kind. Ver. 23. This then being the known form of thee Creatures, they do mot aptly repreent the hard and olid parts of the body, the bones and their protuberances, and all thoe parts that are produced from the thicker part of the eminary matter. Oteologers have very well oberved, that the parts appertaining to the bones, which tand out at a ditance from their bodies, are either the Adnate, or the Enate parts, either the Epiphyes, or the Apophyes of the bones. The firt of thee in Age grow harder and more compact and affixed to the bones themelves; the lat of thee in Age grow more apparent, and eem to be bigger, and tand at a farther ditance, than they did before: And unto this it is that the Chaldee Paraphrae doth directly point; Inflabuntur tali pedum tuorum. Now, the Tali are ometime taken for the Atralagi, the bones in the heel, and ometime for the Malleoli; the Apophyes, of thoe two bones which contitute the leg, namely, the Tibia, and the Fibula; all which, together with them that anwer them in the writ, and all other bunching parts of the bones, (which would be needles particularly
to name,) do in age appear far bigger, and at a greater ditance from the body of the bone, than they did before. Yet I cannot but take more pecial notice of one ort of bones, whoe Apophyes are more eminent, than any others; and may therefore be more aptly reembled by the Grahoppers, and they are the Vertebrae of the Spine; every one of which, both in the neck, in the back, and in the loyns, have even everal prominencies, four oblique ones, namely, two acending, and two decending: two tranvere ones, and one acute, trait forward towards the skin. Now, when man by reaon of age begins to toop and bend forward, and withal thoe flehy parts, that cover thee procees, begin to hrink and decay, (as hall be hewed in the following ymptome) it mut necearily follow, that all thoe Apophyes mut appear a great deal plainer and bigger, than they were before, whereby they will o exactly reemble the everal protuberances of the limbs of the Grahopper, that no words can ufficiently expres their likenes, and none but the diligent oberver of them both, can poibly undertand. And from this exact likenes, without all doubt, aroe the Fable of Tithonus, that living to extream old age, he
was at lat turned into a Grahopper, and into it, it may be very well moralized again; For then the body of man is quite another thing than what it was in its prime, it is contracted, and becomes much les, and crumpled up together, and in the end is brought even to crawle upon the ground.

q.l: Dimidium notri corporis ee putes: • infans,

Fit
que tripes, prorus quadrupe
que ut parvulus
Et per ordentem f •• bile erpit humum.

div.p:
There remaineth yet one reaon more that induceth me to believe, that the parts we have been peaking of, are principally here intended, and that is taken from the word which is here the predicate, whoe root < in non-Latin alphabet > ignifieth primarily, to carry or bear burdens,Lam. 5. 7. Ezr • 6. 3. Nch. 4. 10 and in this ene it is motly ued. Now, the parts in man that may be called the Porters, and which bear the burdens that are carried, can be no othe •
than the S • apula, and its A • r • mion, which is the part upon which the burden is pitched; and the back bone which is the part that gives the greatet trength towards the bearing of it, both which, when age hath much enfeebled a man, become
unerviceable as unto thoe ends, thee Porters do now become a porterage themelves, and thoe parts that were wont to bear the greatet burdens, are now o great a burden themelves, that the man toops under them, and is carce able to bear them.

Now, as the bones are principally here intended, o alo all the other olid parts of the body, that are made of the ame craiment of eed, may be here included; and if we do but here recal the Tranlation of the LXX, we hall undertand what change it is in age, that all thee undergo; the Cartilages of the body, the Ligaments, the Membranes, the Fibres, the Veins, the Arteries, the Nerves, and Tendons, and the like, do all grow harder and drier in age, and tend more towards the nature of bones. The skin alo being partly of this kind (as was before aid) is to be numbred hereunto, which o long as man remains in trength is beautiful, plain, and polite; but as he declines, grows more crutly, and dry, and callous, and conequently falls into abundance of wrinckles.

q.l: Plurima unt juvenum dicrimina, pulchrior ille,

div.p: And that learned Phyician, Valleius, de acra Philo. c. 66. (who in his youth had wearied himelf out with the uncertainty and confuion of prophane Authors, and therefore in his age betook himelf to acred Philoophy,) that he might more powerfully aign over this Hieroglyphical expreion to the ene we have here delivered, aith; the Locut ought to be undertood of the Sea-Locut, which is covered over with an hard, and a cruty and rugged hell: and whooever hall o take it, cannot but conclude, that it doth decipher the parts, we have now treated of. However, I judge the Land-Locut, or Grahopper may very well ignifie the ame thing; beide, it is much better known to men, than the other is, and may be extended to ome parts (that ought here to be included) which the other cannot o ignificantly denote; For by this Claue, the Grahopper hall be a burden, we are to undertand the alteration of all the more hard and olid parts of the body, uually called the permatical; Ductilium, viz. induratio, & incrustatio; & fragilium extantia, & prominentia.

div.head: Deire hall fail, Or rather. The Capers hall hrink.
div.p:
The word < in non-Latin alphabet > hath two remarkable ignifications, the one primary and plain, whereby it ignifieth, deiderium, concupicentia, appetitus; deire, or appetite; the other, econdary or figurative, whereby it ignifieth Capparis, Capers, or the fruit, or rather the flowers of the Caper hrub, or buh. And this word is tranlated from its firt ignification to this latter, becaue of the known ue of Capers, which is to excite the appetite; Capparis excitat orexin, & appetitum, cibi, & veneris: from whence it is, that ome do not improbably derive the word from
< in non-Latin alphabet > , ad luxuriam concito; and for thee ends, epecially that of the tomack, are they preerved in pickle, and o often ued among us for auce. Now, that the word in this place ought to be taken in this latter, that is, in the figurative ignification, thee following reaons do induce me to believe, every one of which ingly, eem to have a good perwaive power; but all of them joyntly, have doubtles a compulive power, to any rational man to be of the ame opinion. The firt, is the general
cope, that the widom of Solomon
propoeth to it elf in this whole decription of age, which is by way of Allegory all along. No wonder therefore if the ame widom, where there be two ignifications of a word, hall rather prefer the Allegorical; the econd, is the particular intent of this vere, which is to hew the enible alterations that are made in man in old age, both in repect of his mind, and of the everal parts of the body, and that ymbolically, or by way of reemblance to other things: and not at all to relate to any of the faculties; and that which doth abundantly back this reaon, is, that the weakned faculties were decribed before, and particularly it was hewn ufficiently, how the appetite both ad cibum and Coitum was weakned, in the lat vere, in thoe words, the voice of the grinding is low: And therefore a learned Commentator upon this place,Cornel. a Lap. when he had aid, Senum libido frigecit, further adds, (that which might better ditinguih it from what went before,) & organa coitus disipantur; which is indeed, the true purport of the words, though but in part. Again, the Contextural expreions are of the elfame nature, both thoe that follow in the Allegory, namely, the ilver Cord, and
the golden Bowl: and alo thoe that immediately precede, namely, the Grahopper, and the Almond tree: And as the word < in non-Latin alphabet > was tranlated from its primary ignification, which is, waking, (as was aid,) to that figurative, of the Almond tree; o alo would it be mot congruous to deal with this word we are now about. Again, Authority is ufficient, yea, abundant for this way of tranlating it: If any one pleae to conult all the variety of Interpreters, he hall find (that which is a great rarity) the mot and the bet to go together, this way; and ince Hieron did but give favour hereunto, I find no Tranlatour vary hencefrom, but ome few into Vulgar Tongues.

Latly, By this way of tranlating only, there will be a direct oppoition, and a perfect Antitheis (which certainly there ought to be) betwixt this word and that which immediatly went before. The Grahoppers and Capers are in their form and fahion; their ubtance and conitence, clean contrary one to another; The one, being protuberous, rough, cruty, and hard: The other, round, mooth, pongy, and oft: And therefore may be very fit Emblems to repreent the everal contraditinct parts of the body, under the
ame variety of conitence. Wherefore, as the Grahopper did principally repreent the bones, and econdarily, all thoe parts that proceed from the Craiment of the eed; o alo here, the Capers do as aptly repreent principally the fleh, and econdarily, the other moyt and fluid parts of the body that proceed from the more tenuous part of the eminary matter: and that which doth farther confirm this reaon, is, from the Antitheis that is alo in the predicate of thee expreions: For as there, the Grahoppers are aid to grow big, or burdenome; So here, the Capers are aid to hrink or decay; for o the word
< in non-Latin alphabet > ignifieth, and is uually tranlated, disipabitur, abolebitur, conteret, hall wat or conume, hall be pent, or worn out; and is a Metaphor taken from interbatation, patching or piecing, ewing or clapping cloe together, making fater or harder thoe things, that were more dilated, pongy, and flourihing before: So that what we are to undertand by this Sentence, the Capers hall hrink, is the alteration of all the moyt and tender parts of the body, uually called, the anguineous; Fluidarum, cil. depravatio & minoratio: & mollium ariditas & conumptio; I cannot exclude hencefrom that change
that befalleth the bloud and natural humours of the body in the time of age: For they become low and much depauperated, they are diminihed, and far les in quantity than they were before.

Nor can I exclude that change that hapneth to the fat and marrow; man in his full trength is decribed by Job to be uch an one,Job 21. 23, 24. Whoe breats are full of milk, and his bones moytned with marrow: But when he is very old, there is carce any milk, or fat, or marrow, or moyture left in all his body; a Conumption is determined concerning them all. But that alteration which is principally here intended, is that which befalleth thoe parts of the body that uually go under the name of fleh. Now, the fleh of the body is of three orts, Parenchymous, Glandulous, or Muculous; The fleh either of the bowels or entrails, or of the Glandules or kernels; or latly, of the Mucles, or outward parts of the body that are the intruments of voluntary motion. It is without all quetion, that the entrails of man, as the Liver, the Spleen, the Heart, the Lungs, &c. do receive great alteration in age, they decline
very much from their oftnes, pongines and porofity, and become far harder and fater, and more Schirrous than they were before. The ame alo may be aid concerning all the natural Glandules in the body of man, thoe that erve either to Excretion, to Reduction, or to Nutrition: They all of them vary much from their primitive tendernes and bignes, and o become more durous, and are far more conumed than they were at firt; and that which the Learned and mot ingenious Author of the late Tract De Glandulis, Dr. Wh • rton, c. 16. doth oberve of the Thymus, by the time of middle age; may be alo oberved of mot of the other Glandules in the time of extream age; that is, that they will bear very little proportion either in weight or ubtance, to what they did at firt, but by experience they are found to hrivel and hrink away, and be conumed almot to nothing.

But of all the parts of the body, thoe lax and tender flakes of fleh, that lye over, and cover the bones, and are at both ends affixed to them, which from the form of ome of them are uually called Mucles, do mot properly deerve the name of fleh, and are conequently chiefly intended in this place. Thee are in Scripture
called the coverings of a man:Pa. 139. 13. Job 10. 11. Thou hat covered me, aith David, in my mothers womb. And again Job, Thou hat covered me with skin, and with fleh. Now, as man declines in years, o do thee coverings wax old and hrink, o that at length they become horter and narrower, than that a man can comelily be wrapped up in them: So that this, together with the former Symptome, doth abundantly hew the great alteration and deformity that is eaily dicerned upon the external parts of the body, in the time of extream age. The body becomes more uncomly, cragged, and crumpled, the bones tare through the skin, the fleh that hould cover them is wated much away. And this condition is lively decribed by Elihu, one of the friends of Job; who peaking of Gods dealing with men, ometime in reference to their body, (pointing therein at Jobs Conumption, which in this repect is exactly anwerable to the Maramus Senilis,) aith, His fleh is conumed away that it cannot be een, and his bones that were not een, tick out. Job 33. 21. I would have this expreion be principally noted, and remembred, as being a mot perfect Comment upon thee two lat mentioned Symptomes of age. For the former words, viz. His fleh is
conumed away that it cannot be een, is the ame that is aid in thee words, Disipatur Capparis: and the latter words, viz. The bones which were not een, tick out, is the ame which is aid in thoe, Impinguatur Locuta.
And thus much hall uffice to have poken for the Explication of all thoe Symtomes that attend a man all along the time of his decrepit tate.

div.head: For man goeth to his long home: and the mourners go about the treets.
div.p:
Thee words being not at all figurative, but only a plain and eaie tranition from one part of the Allegory to another, namely, from thoe Symptomes that attend a man all along his decrepit tate, unto thoe that do immediately forerun his Diolution: It is beide my purpoe to peak to them at all, for my intention hath been only to explain the difficult terms in the Allegory; And I would not willingly eem to any,1 Pet. 4. 15.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , to play the Bihop in anothers Dioces, or to meddle with thoe matters that are peculiarized to another Coat, yet becaue the words are now read, I cannot but take notice of two things in them, that is, firt, the term of long home; and econdly,
the mourning at the funeral.
The word < in non-Latin alphabet > which intimates unto us the tate of death, and is here tranlated Long: hath three eminent ignifications, either of which may be very well accepted in this place.

In the firt place it ignifieth, abditum, occultum; a ecret and an hidden thing, and thus it is derived from the word < in non-Latin alphabet >
Latitavit, abconditum fuit, as it is very often ued:Lev. 4. 13. 5. 2. If the whole Congregation of Irael in through ignorance, and the thing be hid from the eyes of the aembly. And again, (not to cite many places to this purpoe which were eaie to do,) in the lat Vere of this Chapter and Book of Eccleiates; For God will bring every work to judgment, with every ecret thing; which is from the ame original word ued in this fifth vere for long home. And indeed, that home that we are all hating to, and know not how oon we may recover or come at; and aged perons are undoubtedly at the door of: is the true and proper hiding place for all living: For they hall all lye down alike together in the grave, Job 21. 26. and the worms hall cover them. 40. 13. Men are hid together in the dust, and their faces are there bound in ecret. Death is a tate of obcurity, and the
Grave a place of ecreie; and therefore it is that Job, wihing for death, phraeth it;Job 4. 13. Oh that thou wouldet hide me in the Grave, that thou wouldet keep me in ecret: But beide the bare ignification of ecreie, this word doth for the mot part carry along with it an intimation of duration or continu
• nce; and therefore may very well be tranlated, Tempus eujus duratio et abcondita, an hidden duration, a time that no man knows how long; which is exactly anwered by our Englih Law-phrae, time out of mind; and that both à parte, pot; and à parte, ante; time either that is pat, or that is to come; of which no man can give an account: Both which alo are ignified unto us by the Latine word Olim, which without all quetion came from the Hebrew word we are now peakking of;Eccl. 1. 10. as both the ound and ignification will abundantly make appear: Now this duration at leat is in the tate of death, that no man knows how long it will continue: No one living can give an account how long it hall be before, the earth hall dicloe her bloud and her bones, and hall no more cover her lain.

The lat ignification of this word is duratio abolute infinita, aeternitas: A compleat and abolute perpetuity, eternity. And in this ignification it is motly ued, and mut alwayes be interpreted when it is applyed to God, or any of his Attributes, as often it is. When Nebuchadnezzars undertanding was returned to him, he bleed the mot high, Dan. 4. 37. and praied and honoured him that liveth for ever, whoe dominion is an everlating dominion, and his kingdom is from generation to generation: Again it is aid in Iaiah, Ia 45. 17. Irael hall be aved in the Lord with an everlating alvation. Now in this lat ene alo may the ame word in this place be afely taken; in domum aternitatis uae. The tate we arrive at, by Death, is an everlating tate, and we hall never return to this life again through all eternity. And hence it is that uually we find uch Epitaphs; hanc aternam edem ibi po • it: andHac domus aeterna et, hic um itus, hic ero emper.

Nor is the Scripture without its tetimony hereunto;P. 39, 13. for David aith, Spare me a little that I may recover trength before I go hence and be no more. And Job doth not only, ay it, but argue upon it: There is hope of a Tree if it be cut down, that it will prout again, Job 14. Ver. 7. Ver. 8. and that the tender branch thereof will not ceae. Though the root there of wax old in the earth, and the tock thereof die in the ground: Ver. 9. Yet through the ent of water it will bud, and bring forth boughs like a plant; But Man dieth, Ver. 10. and wateth away; yea Man giveth up the Ghot, and where is he? And that Interrogation,Ver. 14. If a Man die, hall he live again? which uually is interpreted vehemently to affirm; eems on the contrary to me, mot earnetly to deny, and is as much as to ay, if a Man die he hall never live more, no hopes of a return to this life again: And this

Firt the manner of propoing the quetion eems chiefly to intend; for it is not negatively propoed; If a man die hall he not live again? but affirmatively, hall he live again? Now Negative Interrogations do in all Languages, and in Scripture phrae too, more properly intend affirmative Propoitions, as where it is aid, Doth not each of you, Luke 13. 15, 16. on the abbath day looe his Oxe, or his As, from the tall? and ought
not this Woman alo to be looed? both of them mot vehemently affirming: and again, another Interrogation; How hall he not alo with him give us all things? Rom. 8. 32. is as much as to ay, he hall mot urely do it. On the other hand, affirmative Interrogations do for the mot part intend negative Propoitions: Joeph aith, How can I do this great wickednes and in againt God? Gen. 39. • . and the Lord aith, How hall I give thee up O Ephraim? how hall I deliver thee Irael? Ho. 11. 8 9. how hall I make thee as Admah? how hall I et thee as Zeboim? all of them intending the denying of the thing: Both thee Interrogations, about the ame ubject too, are together in one Vere of the Palms, till intending their contrary Propoitions; What Man is he that liveth, and hall not ee death? Pal. 89. 48. hall he deliver his oul from the hand of the grave? the firt part of the Vere is negatively propoed, and therefore ignifies the trong affirming of the thing, he hall urely ee death: and the latter part of the vere is affirmatively propoed, and therefore ignifieth the vehement negation of it; he hall in no wie deliver his oul from the hand of the Grave: The manner therefore of propoing this quetion being without a negative, doth eem to carry the ene,
that if a man be dead he hall never live again.

Secondly the inference that is hence made confirms the ame thing; All the dayes of my appointed time will I wait till my change come; doth far more naturally and powerfully proceed from the denying of life again, then from the aerting it: as to the diligent oberver will eaily appear; if a man hall never live again in this world, it is of mot high concern to prepare for that change that foreruns an everlating tate. There is no returning more from death, and therefore let every one wait upon his buines, and finih it, before that time come: There is no work, nor devie, nor knowledge, nor widom in the grave, whither we are going: And ince there is no returning thencefrom, how cogent will the argument be, for every one to wait all the dayes of his appointed time, till his change hall come. If the Tree fall to the outh, Eccle. 9, 10. or to the north, in the place where the Tree falls, there it hall be: And therefore it is of the greatet concern to take care how the Tree fall. If a man at his departure out of this life fall towards happines, or towards miery, in the ame condition he falls, hall he remain for ever; and therefore it is a buines of everlating concern, to await our fall.

But latly, that which makes it yet more clear, that this interrogation intends the negative, is the words in the latter end of this Chapter; where Job reuming the ubject, and ummarily declaring what he had been before peaking of; he aith plainly, Thou prevailet for ever againt him, Job 14. v. 20. and he paeth, thou changet his countenance, and endet him away. I peak not thee things in the leat to enervate that mot comfortable Chritian Doctrine of the Reurrection; and as Job was very carefull in the forecited Chapter, to keep his reerve as unto that; o that in the middet of the Chapter (that therefore it might have an apect over the whole) he interpoeth a entence to that purpoe;Ver. 12. Man lieth down and rieth not, till the Heavens be no more. So I would not have any one o far mitake this Doctrine, as to think the Body of Man hall be kept in everlating Chaines of darknes: for, though it hall never return to this working tate again, yet God hath appointed a et time,Ver. 13. to remember it in: at which time it hall, by the Word of God, hake off its corruption, dihonour, and weaknes; and by his gift hall be cloathed with pirituality,1 Cor. 15. 41, 42. glory, and Immortality. Herein no one can erre, who knowes the Scripture, and the Power of God, as
our Saviour intimates;Mat. 22. v. 29. The Power of God reacheth us, that God can raie the dead; and the Scriptures teach us that he will; and what God can, and will do, mut certainly come to pas: But the Doctrine of the New Tetament gives a far clearer light hereunto, therein there is a ufficient tetimony given unto all Men, in raiing Christ from the dead: 1 Cor. 15. 23. For he being the firt Fruits of them that leep, gives a certain demontration, that all the other alo mut follow in their order.Act. 17. 18.
< in non-Latin alphabet > are o neerly related to each other, that they are Preached, and Believed, they are lighted, and contemned together: their foundation is o much the ame, that they mut necearily tand and fall alike. I have oberved that thoe late preading Doctrines that have purpoely obcured the Hitory of Chrit at Jerualem, have, before they have been aware, wholly lot the Doctrine of the Reurrection: I hall not farther add hereunto; it may eem that I have too much digreed already; but I hope no farther, then for the neceary clearing of the words long home, and the reerving entire, that unquetionable Article of our Faith, the Reurrection of the Body.

The other remarkable thing is the Mourning at the Funeral; I hall not pend
time in dicouring what kind of Mourners thee are; whether Children, Relations, Friends, Neighbours, hired Perons, thee, or any, or all of thee; it is enough that there is a Publick Mourning expreed, at uch a Funeral as this; I ay it is enough, and methinks I hear ome others ay, it is too much; for if it be o, as hath been related, if Age be o mierable and comfortles a condition as hat been decribed; happy ure are they, that are gon, or going, off from it: If all manner of evills do attend thoe that are extreamly aged, and nothing that good or pleaurable is; when they change this State, for that which is perfectly happy (as we ought to believe concerning all our Chritian Friends departed) in tead of Mourning, why hould there not be Rejoycing? in tead of hanging down the Head and Weeping, Why hould there not be lifting up the Head and Triumphing? at o great a bettering their condition, as uch a Change mut necearily produce: To this I mut needs anwer, That, if we truly undertood our elves, and were throughly poeed of what we do profes, in repect of the party Deceaed, there were no caue of Mourning at all, but rather of Rejoycing; And this not onely in repect of Perons decrepit with
Age, but of any other, in whatoever flourihing condition of this Life; for the change would then be, but from a les mierable etate, to that which is mot compleatly bleed: for Man, at his bet etate, as he is altogether Vanity, o is he very mierable, and encompaed and perplexed with abundance of evil, which his lat happy change gives him a deliverance from for ever.Ia. 57. 1. The righteous are taken away from the evil to come: and the tate they are taken to, is infinitely and unexpreibly happy. Mot noble and excellent was that aying upon a Moral account; The elfame journey that thou hat taken from no being, unto being, and from a perexitent being, to this mortal life; thou mayet again take (with the ame aurance of preferment) from this Life, by Death; to a Life that has Immortality in it: but the Believer in Chrit Jeus onely, hath a true propect of the advantages of his great Change: the Life of Chrit, and the gain of death, are known and apprehended together:Phil. 1. 21. For me to live is Chrit, and to die is gain. He that hath lived unto the Lord knowes fullwell;2 Cor. 5. 1. That when his earthly houe of this Tabernacle hall be disolved, he hath a building of God, an Houe not made with hands, eternal in the Heavens. He
auredly knowes from the prelibation of Eternal Life, which he hath had in this World, that then all tears hall be wiped away from his eyes, & he hall never know one evil more, and that he hall be put into immediate poeion of all thoe good things, that he either Prayed, or hoped for in this life, into a perfect tate of Blis, infinite, at leat, for the duration: And therefore upon this account, there will be very little caue of Lamentation. And, whooever he is, that Mournes meerly upon the account of the Party deceaed, he doth necearily redargue himelf of unbelief, and plainly hew, that there is an haeitation in his Mind, concerning one of thee two things; whether Heaven be uch a place as hath been decribed unto us in the Book of God, or whether his Friend be auredly gone to that place. So that Funeral Mournings are, as Divines ay of Funeral Sermons, more in repect of the Living then of the Dead. To go unlamented is no miery to the Dead; but a hame to the Living. There doth indeed lie a Duty upon all that are left behind, to bewail their own los of their Godly Friend; Natural Affection, and the Flehly part of Man ought omething to be indulged in this repect; but the los of a great and a
long Example of Piety, whoe preence hath been a continued bleing, both to perons and places; ought mot eriouly and adly to affect the inward man; and therefore they are harply reproved by the Prophet,Ia. 57. 1. who are negligent in this duty; The righteous periheth, and no man layeth it to heart; the merciful men are taken away, none conidering, &c. And it is to be oberved, that the Saints of God, though never o old, and brought never o low, through the mieries attending them; when they changed this life for a better, were till buried with great lamentation.Gen. 50. 11. Abel-mizraim was a place never to be forgot,1 Sam. 2 • . 1. either by the Egyptians, Num. 20 19. or the Canaanites; and not Jacob only, but Moes, and Aaron, Deut. 34. 8. and Samuel were buried by the aembly of the people of Irael, and very great publick mournings was made for them all.

head.q: Vere 6. Or ever the ilver Cord be looed, or the golden Bowl be broken, or the Pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the Wheel broken at the Citern.

div.p:
THus far the King hath been treating of all thoe Symptomes that accompany a man all along his decrepit tate, which may appear upon him, while yet he may have ome pace given him, to remain in the Land of the living: Thee that follow in this vere are uch that immediately forerun his diolution; which when they once appear, there remains nothing, but a preent preparation for his Funeral.
