And they may erve as indications, not only in this weak and pent condition of age; but in whatoever other condition of mans life, by the violence of a dieae, they are joyntly found; they give a mot certain Prognotick of approaching death. In the Explication whereof there is very much variety of opinions; o that it would be exceeding tedious and troubleome to follow them all; but I hall pare all that pains, and take notice of none of them,
but what I judge to be nearet the intentention of the Wie man, foramuch as mot of the other, carry their own refutations in their faces: and if I may be directed to find out any thing of truth contained in them, that alo will bear its own evidence along with it, and may erve for eviction of whatoever is contrary thereunto. Foramuch as rectum est index, ui, & obliqui. Death, which is the fruit of old age, and the unavoidable receptacle of all living: is decried to be jut at the door, by thoe Symptomes that belong to the intruments, either of the animal faculty, or of the vitall; (as for thoe that belong unto the Natural, they have very little or no certainty in this Cae.) Thoe that belong to the animal, have reference unto the brain, and the parts ariing from it; either as they are continued without the Cranium, Or ever the ilver Cord be looed; or ele as they are contained within the Cranium, The golden Bowl be broken. Thoe Symptomes that belong to the vital faculty, have reference unto the heart, and the parts ariing from it; as they erve, either for importation of the bloud and pirits; The Pitcher broken at the Fountain; or for exportation of the ame; The Wheel broken at the Citern.
Now of all thee in their Order.

div.head: Or ever the ilver Cord be looed.
div.p: The firt thing that we mut here make enquiry into, is what we are to undertand by the Cord; and we mut be ure here alo as in all other parts of the decription, to keep within compas of the Allegory; and find out thoe parts of a man that are hereby repreented. For he it is, that hath hitherto been decribed unto us, as an old houe greatly decayed and ruinated, but yet tanding, by all the foregoing Symptomes; but now as an houe falling down which mut no longer remain, by this Symtome, and thoe three which immediately follow in this vere. And therefore thee may very well be called,Cajetan. quatuor mortis Concomitantia; the four attendants upon dying man.

The Scripture maketh mention of the Cords of a man, Ho. 11. 4. which although they are there to be taken in a Moral ene, and o excentricall to what we are now about, yet they are a Metaphor taken from the natural cords of a man, and may give ome light thereunto: for as love in all bodies politick (and conequently mytical) doth both draw and unite; o in all bodies natural, the elf-ame offices are performed
by thoe parts of which we are about to peak; for we mut know, that all the everal parts of man, are not kept, and bound fat together by pels, nor are his everal members moved everal waies, as it were by Magick Art, the oul of man doth not by a bare jubeo, caue the repreentation of outward objects, or the variation of the poition of the everal limbs, without the help of intruments, but by the apt frame of the whole body, and the pliablenes of the everal parts, and the convenient poition of all the Cords and Pulleys towards their appointed ends, we perceive outward objects, and move our elves at pleaure o; as that an artificial man, could there be in it, the ame organs, and the ame dipoition of them all, together with an active power to put them in execution, would have a like ene and motion with our elves. The Chaldee Paraphrae doth interpret this Cord to the Ligula linguae, the tring of the tongue; others interpret it to the Spinalis medulla, the marrow of the back; others, to the Nerves; others, to the outward Tunicle of the Nerves and marrow, which they have proper to themelves, for their own trength; beide the other two which they receive from the brain. All thee have
offered exceeding well, and without doubt have hit the truth, and being put together may eem to make the whole of what is here intended, which is the whole intrument of ene and motion, after it hath proceeded out of the Scull, and as it is ditributed throughout the body; with all its Coats and Tunicles, with all its diviions and eparations. I mean, not only the pinal marrow is here to be undertood, (as principally it ought to be,) but all the Nerves ariing thence from, (both thoe even pair, be they more or les, that proceed from it, before it hath attained any of the pines; and thoe thirty pair, that proceed from the everal Vertebrae of the neck, the back, the loyns, and the Os Sacrum,) and alo the Filaments, and Fibers, and Tendons, that proceed from all thoe Nerves. The Nerves and Fibers mut in no wie be here left out, foramuch as they do more apparently both unite and draw, than any other of the parts whatoever.Job 10. 11. Job aith, Thou hat fenced me with bones and with inews. I compare thee fences of a man, to thoe of an hedge; where the bones anwer to the takes in the hedge, making the ubtantial trunk of the body, unto which all the other parts are to be fatned: and the
Sinews or Nerves to the binders of the hedge; which faten and unite all the other parts to that trunke; and as for motion or drawing, it is well known that there is none in all the body performed, (whether voluntary or natural,) but by the influence of the animal pirits upon the Nerves and Fibers, and their contraction thereupon, in thoe everal parts, into which they are inerted. Now, although all the everal and innumerable Filaments are to be accounted hereunto, yet they are mot aptly expreed in the ingular number, by funiculus argenteus, the ilver Cord, becaue they are but the continuation of the ame thing: The Fibers being nothing ele but the Nerves divided and dipered, and the Nerves nothing ele but the marrow in like manner eparated, as o many arms and branches of the ame tree; they are all one in their original, the brain; they are all one in their continuation for a long time, in the pine; they are all one in their colour, white; they are all one in their form, long and round; they are all one in their Coats having each the ame three Tunicles, they are all one in their ue, to convey the animal pirits, and all this in an apt reemblance to a Cord; to which alo they are not unlike in their diviion, for then, they
are but as o many wreaths, or wattles of the ame Cord; and that which is mot obervable to our preent purpoe, is that by how much the more ditant they are from their original, by o much the thinner, and finer, the harder, and more compact do they grow, like the everal maller, and better twited ends of the ame Cord.

It is called the ilver Cord, firt from its colour, for it appears to the eye, of a white, hining, replendent, beauty, bright as ilver; and thus it is even when it is taken out of the body, after it is dead; but how much more admirable and glorious mut it needs be, while it remains in the body yet living, and actuated with abundance of mot refined pirits, which continually acend and decend thereupon. An Ancient and an admirable Anatomit,F • llobius upon conideration of the great lutre and perpicuity of it, compares it to the Crytalline humour of the eye, and farther affirms, that he never aw any thing in all his life, more beautiful than thoe two things.

Secondly, It may be called the ilver Cord, from its place in which it is eated in the body: it is placed very deep, ecret, and ecure;Job 2 • . 1. Job aith, Surely there is a vein
for the ilver; that is, there is an intricate, hidden, and myterious Cavity in the earth, in which this Lunar Mineral, doth more ecurely pas its branches; jut thus the Cord of our body, as oon as ever it hath left its original, it is paed into the mot inward, and ecret Cavity of the Spine, which by reaon of that admiration and reverence the Ancients had for it, they called, < in non-Latin alphabet > , the holy Pipe; and when in everal places it paeth thencefrom, it is conveyed all along with wonderful artifice, both for ecreie and ecurity, which is continued to the mot minute Filaments, for throughout the whole body, it lieth lower, and deeper, and afer, than the Veins, or Arteries, or any other common Conveyers in the body of man.

Latly, and chiefly, It is called the ilver Cord, becaue of its excellency: For as Silver above all other Minerals whatoever (ave only that mot abolute and perfect one of Gold,) is, and ought to be mot valued and eteemed; o is, and ought, this part we are now peaking of, next unto that mot abolute and perfect part, the brain, which in the very next following Symptome is aimulated unto Gold. The ingenious Chymits take
pleaure to liken the everal Metals they find in the bowels of the earth, to the heavenly Luminaries, who after they have compared the mot perfect, aptly to the Sun; they in the next place, liken this of Silver as aptly to the Moon, and therefore decipher it alo by the elf-ame Character; hewing us hereby, that as the Moon in Heaven, is far more glorious and excellent, than all other Coeletial Bodies whatoever, (the Sun alone excepted,) o Silver in the earth, above all Terretrial Bodies whatoever (Gold alone excepted) hath the ame preheminence.

And this dignity hath the Spinal Marrow with all its branches above all other parts of the body except the brain; it hath been in uch eteem among Philoophers,Plato in Timaeo. Hippoc. that the bet of them hath acknowledged it the foundation of life; and the great Mater of Phyicians hath dignified it with the name of < in non-Latin alphabet > , thereby clearly intimating, that if vitality be not chiefly therein placed, yet the highet and mot noble operations thereof, are performed
thereupon. And uch an exact likenes there is between the Nerves and Silver, that they do by a mutual and reciprocal Metaphor, utably expres one another, in the two everal Worlds.

For as the Nerves or Sinews are here aid to be the Silver of the Microcome, or little World, o is Silver as aptly aid to be the Sinews of the Macrocome, or greater World. There being nothing in the whole World that is vigorouly carried on among Men, but by the help thereof: Silver is the Sinewes of War and of Peace, of Merchandize and of Tillage, nay I may farther add, of Learning, and of vertue too.
div.q: Quis enim virtutem amplectitur ipam Praemia i tollas.
div.p:
Now, as all the Works of the greater World oon come to nought, if the influences of the Sinewes thereof be intercepted; o do all thoe of the Leer World, if the Silver thereof perih and decay; and therefore the looning of the Silver Cord is here given as an undoubted igne of intant Diolution. For, as it was aid of the Tabernacle,J • r. 10. 20. Ia. 33. 20 That it was poiled, and neer its utter ruine, when the Cords thereof were broken;
o may it alo be aid of this earthly Tabernacle of our Bodies, when we hall be untrung, and the Cords of our Bodies broken aunder; we mut then expect uddenly to be diolved: The Word here is variouly tranlated, rumpatur, elongetur, contrahatur, revertatur, diolvatur; which variety may give very great light unto the everal caues of the ymptome here intended: but becaue uch a narrow crutiny may make a digreion from what is here intended, I hall for the preent pas it by, and onely take notice of the ymptome it elf which is here aimed at; and, that the Latine word diolvatur, and the Englih looned, do directly point at, namely the olution of the Nerves or Marrow, called in Latine (from the Greeks and their Radix
< in non-Latin alphabet > , olvo) paralyis, and in Englih the Paly: Sometime this olution hapneth only to one part of the Silver Cord, which caueth paralyis particularis, and then the enlivening influence of the animal pirits is hindered onely from thoe parts of the Body, to which that doth immediately tend, and o thoe parts become wholly deprived both of ene and motion; Death hath already taken poesion of a Leg, o •
an Arm, or the half of that Man, that is o far paralytick, hardly or never more to be
dipoeed; and therefore in our language it is well tiled the Dead Paly. Sometime it hapneth to the head of the pinal Marrow, and o hindreth the influence of the pirits upon the whole Silver Cord, and conequently takes away all ene and motion from all the ubjected parts; and this caueth Paralyis univeralis, which at all times, and upon all occaions, gives a very probable Prognotick; but in the decrepit Age of Man, a mot certain and infallible one, of immediate Death.

div.head: Or the Golden Bowl be broken.
div.p:
The Symptome lat treated of, had reference to the rivulets of animality; this we are now peaking of, relates to the fountain: For we mut know that the Soul of Man, the Queen Regent of all his operations, makes the Head the Royal Palace of her reidence, from whence he gives forth all her Precepts, Edicts, and Commands, for the regulating and actuating all the ubjected parts of the Body. Now the parts of the Head are of two orts, either the containing, or the contained parts thereof: The lat of thee, namely the encompaed, or contained parts, are the cerebrum, the cerebellum, and the medulla, with all thoe everal maller parts, which
curious obervers have found out, to belong to any of them, which I hall not o much as mention, becaue they are not o directly pointed at in this place: And I do here, as I have done all along, indutriouly avoid all things, epecially all termes of Art, or econd intentions, that do not immediately conduce to the undertanding of the ymptome under hand: but we mut not o exclude thee parts as to judge them not all concerned in this expreion; for upon the breaking of the Golden Bowl, the brain it elf, with all the contained parts appertaining thereunto, doth immediately ceae, from all its operations: And if we hall take the Original word in its plain ignification,Cant 4. 12. and as it is often ued in Scripture too;Judg. 1. 15. for f • ns, or caturigo, a Fountain, or Spring; it would eem mot properly and primarily to intend this mot noble part, the firt pring of animality, the original fountain of all ene and motion.

But becaue I find the word otherwie tranlated, and that upon very good grounds, by all that have undertaken that charge, I hall in no wie dient from them; for indeed the Mytical and Metaphorical ene of Words ought till to be preferred all along the Allegory: And I would not by any meanes break a firm, well et,
and a lating Hedge, if there be any the leat reaon for the tanding of it. The root from which this word is derived is < in non-Latin alphabet >
volvit, circumvolvit, complicavit, circumduxit: Sometime it is tranlated to rowl, or to rowl together, ometimes to rowl away, or to rowl back; ometime to rowl over, wrap up, or encompas; o that the word in the Text is ometime tranlated
• ecythus, Zach. 4. 2, 3. a Pot, or Bowl, to hold any liquid ubtance in: ometime lenticula, a Chrimatory, or Cruet, or Veel to contain Oyl; ometime orbis, 1 King 7. 7. 4 • . a Sphaerical Body encompaing others: The vulgar Latine removes the Metaphor once again, and brings it home to its own door; vitta aurea, the Golden Headband, for vitta ignifieth a Veil, a Coy • e, a Garland, or whatoever ele may circle, or encompas the head: the LXX. hath it < in non-Latin alphabet > , the repoitory of the Braines; by all thee we undertand, that Interpreters do uno ore, with full conent render the Word to the involving, circumcribing, encompaing, containing parts.

Which alo are of two orts, either the external containing parts of the head; or the internal: The external (beide thoe common Vetments that appertain to other parts of the body alo, as
the Cuticula, Cutis, &c. which cannot be here undertood) are only two, the Perieranium, and the Cranium it elf; now although thee are not chiefly intended in this place, yet urely they will put in for a hare of this Elogie; for as much as thee do environ, defend, and upend all the inward parts, and do conequently exceedingly conduce towards all animal operations. And the Chaldee Paraphrae doth directly interpret this word hereunto, when it aith, Et ne it Confractus vertex capitis tui. The Crown of thy head be not broken: beide the Hebrew word for the cull (as it is ued in that place with many others, where it is aid, when they went to bury her, they found no more of her then the Scull,2 King. 9. 30. and the Feet, and the Palmes of her Hands) is very neer a kin to the word here in the Text;Judg. 9. 53. they lie both together in a belly, and are derived from the ame tock. And that famous word which is a medly of the Oriental Languages, being partly Syriac, partly Chaldee, and partly Hebrew, is alo neerly related hereunto; I mean the word Golgotha, that is to ay the place of a Scull.Mat. 27. 33.

The internal containing parts are alo two, thoe two Membranes, namely a thicker and an harder; a thinner and a finer,
that do yet more immediately encompas the brain, which to the Graecians are known by the name of < in non-Latin alphabet > , to the Latines by the name of Matres, which title they took from the Arabians, intimating thereby unto us, not onely that they do give a being to all the other Membranes of the body, as unto their own natural offpring, but chiefly, and that which is mot to our preent purpoe, that they do Maternâ curâ cerebro propicere, Spigelius. With a Motherly care and tendernes over-ee and over-rule all the actions of the brain: but yet more particularly, the mot inward of thee two, that doth by immediate contract encircle the very ubtance of the brain, doth eem to me to be < in non-Latin alphabet > , by way of eminence, the golden bowl here intended. This is that part which deeply ininuates it elf into all the anfractuous paages of the brain; and, being firmly annexed thereunto, keeps every part thereof in its proper place, and due texture; o that whatoever is performed within the whole compas of the brain, whether the making of the animal pirits, their exercie therein, or their ditribution thencefrom, is done principally by the help of this Membrane: Therefore the Ancients from that reverence they had for it, have jutly
honoured it with the name of Pia mater. And if we do but throughly conider the innumerable branches of the veines, but epecially of the Arteries that are hereinto inerted, and their everal wonderful interchaings and intermixtures, and inertions, not onely one into another, but even among themelves (which is not found in any other part of the body) we hall urely be induced to believe, that the greatet depu • ation and defaecation, and conequently the highet exaltation of the blood and vital pirits, is performed herein. And though it pleaeth the mot worthy, and mot learned Author of the Anatomy of the Brain, D. Willis. to give the honour of making the animal pirits, to the Subtantia Corticalis Cerebri; yet if you well weigh the Doctrine there delivered, you will find it clearly evinced, that the greater work is done before; And that the Subtantia Corticalis doth but Midwife that into the World, which the Pia Mater conceives in its own bowels.

Portio anguinis ubtilior (nempe talis facta in vais hujus Membranae) hic (nempe in ubtantia Corticali) rude donata, in piritus animales facesit. Now whether the purification and piritualization; or the manu-mision or liberation, be the mot
noble work, I think it no hard matter to determine.

It is called the Golden Bowl, for the elf-ame reaons for which the other was called the Silver Cord. Firt, In repect of the Colour, not only becaue that mot precious, and deep coloured liquor of life, is abundantly contained in the Veels of this Membrane, but chiefly becaue the Membrane it elf is omewhat of a flavous Colour, and tends more, towards that of Gold, than any other part whatoever. Again, as there is a place for Gold where they find it, o there is an hidden, ecret, and well defended place, where this precious part hath its natural reidence; much indutry mut be ued for the finding out, & yet much more, for the following of it, and tracing it, into all thoe ecret Caverns, into which it doth mot myteriouly diffue its branches; but chiefly it is o called from its excellency, and its univeral ue. The intrument that doth depurate the bet of bloud, and defaecate and exalt the vital pirits, and o prepare them for animality; can be likened in this lower world, to nothing, but that mot abolute, and perfect, that bet concocted and mot exalted Mineral of Gold. When the Lord God had made the whole Creation,
he in the lat place makes him, for whom all the ret were made, And he took man and put him in the Garden of Eden, to dres it, and to keep it: This place, of all the earth, was the meetet receptacle for o noble an Inhabitant, for it had in it a River, which was divided into four heads, Gen. 2. 10, 11. The name of the firt is Pion, which encompaeth the whole Land of Havilah, where there is Gold; and all the other are there reckoned up by their names: when the Lord God had made this noble Inhabitant of the dut of the earth, he in like manner in the lat place breathed into him that more noble part of him, for which all the ret were made; And the oul of man, which is to rule and guide him, hath he placed in this mot convenient eat, which is watered by a River, that is parted, and becomes four heads, which are all known by name, where alo there is Gold. Arteriarum quadriga ad quatuor ditinct as
< in non-Latin alphabet > , plagas evehitur; D. wills, is Anatom cerebri, Cap. 10. the two Carotidal, and the two Vertebral Arteries are this golden quaternion, whoe treams make glad that City, wherein the breath of God hath its principal abode. There is yet another thing, wherein this part we are now treating of, and Gold, have a very great reemblance, and that is
in the ductility of them both: Gold of all Metals is the mot ductile, and may be drawn out at the greatet length; this only makes good that Maxime in Philoophy: Quantitativum et diviibile in emper diviibilia; No man can draw Gold o thin, but a better Artit, can yet make it thinner, it is the nature of this Solar Mineral to be endles in purity; how pure fine the Pia mater Cerebri is, none can expres, and none but the diligent oberver of it, (who hath often endeavoured its eparation from the parts to which it is annexed,) can poibly undertand. This, as o much leaf-gold, drawn out to a very great thinnes, doth ecurely, tenderly, and univerally wrap up, all thoe little hills and valleys, thoe convex or concavous parts, that are within the compas of its own Circumference.

This golden Bowl, o long as man remains in his trength, is firmly knit unto it elf in all its parts, but in the extremity of extream old age, when he is jut giving up the Ghot, it can no longer continue its continuity; but by reaon either of its natural drines, hriveling into it elf, or preternatural moyture, imbibing excrementitious humours, till it is over-full, it often naps aunder, and o recurs into it elf, as
the word properly ignifieth; from whence the brain mut necearily ubide, and all the parts erving in any wie to animality, mut be uddenly and irrecoverably mitten, and ceae from their everal ues; and moreover, immediately hereupon followeth a change of the whole Countenance, the Noe appears very harp, the eyes ink in the head, the Temples are pinched in, the ears become cold and contracted, and the Fibers thereof inverted, the skin about the forehead hard, intene, and dry, and the colour of the whole face livid and black, and in all things perfectly repreenting, that ultimum vaele, known among Phyicians by the name of Facies Hippocratica, and o conequently the man doth immediately dye Apoplectical; according to that of Job, Thou changest his Countenance, (and what followeth immediately thereupon,) Thou endet him away. So that the Symptome hereby intended, is, Repentina omnium operationum Cerebri; motus, viz. enus, & aliarum functionum animalium, tam principalium, quam minus principalium abolitio: cum facie Hippocratica.

It cannot but here upon this occaion be remembred, that an Apoplex was mentioned before, in the Explication of the
econd vere, and that as a dieae of old age, which might urprize a man, and yet not immediately kill him, and of which there might poibly be a removal, at leat for a eaon, that there might ome pace be given him to recover a little trength, before he go hence and be no more een; how therefore comes it to pas, that it is here accounted as one of the immediate Harbingers of death?

For anwer hereunto, we mut know, that an Apoplex falls under a double conideration; either as it is a dieae, or as it is a Symptome. In the firt conideration, it is Morbus Conformationis repectu meatuum; when by reaon of ome preternatural matter, in, or about the Veels, there become an obtruction, contipation, or compreion of them, o that either the vital Spirits cannot be received, or the animal pirits cannot be exercied or ditributed as they ought to be. This matter may ometime poibly be dicued, or carried off for a eaon, or change its eat, and o the Apoplex degenerate into the Palie; however it is not an infallible ign of intant departure, and under this Conideration it was handled in the econd vere. But in the econd Conideration it is Symptoma morbi, nempe olutae unitatis,
when by reaon of the breaking of the Golden Bowl, and hrinking up into it elf, there immediately follows a Coalecene of all the Veels thereof, and a Subidence of the brain it elf, and conequently, a total abolition of all the actions of the animal Faculty, from whence there is not o much as the leat hopes of recovery, and under this Conideration it is handled in this place. Or it may be, the ditinction of the learned Nymmanus,
Nymma. de Apopl. cap. 21. may be more atisfactory to ome in anwer to this Objection.

Apoplexia est vel vera vel notha. A true Apoplex is when the meatus and open paages of the brain are hut up and obtructed, and o the Communication of the pirits is intercepted, the ubtance of the brain, and of all the parts appertaining thereunto, remaining otherwie in good plight, as they ought to be, in their due place, with their wonted firmnes of Compoition: And this is like unto an houe, whoe entry or common paages are wholly filled up with rubbih, o that it becomes altogether ueles, and this is the dieae of old age before-mentioned. But a bastard Apoplex is a far more dreadful thing, when the tone of the brain, and of all the parts within the compas of the
Pia mater, is wholly relaxed and detroyed, and by conequence only thereupon, all animal functions do in a moment ceae, in the manner of the true Apoplex, but yet with far more terrible and amazing Symptomes, the pule and repiration alo being wholly taken away, and the Countenance changed to that gatly apect before mentioned; which is an infallible ign of the dut immediately returning to the earth as it was, without any the leat top in its coure; < in non-Latin alphabet > .Hippo. l. 2. Apho. 42. And this is like that houe wherein the Philitines were gathered together to ee Sampon make port, which came tumbling down, when the two foundation Pillars thereof were violently torn from their place; Ut Collapa ruit domus, ubducta columnis; and this is the certain Symptome of death, treated on in this Vere. And thus much hall uffice to have poken for the Explication of thoe Symptomes of death, that belong to the intruments of the animal Faculty, thoe two that remain belong to the Vital.

div.head: Or the Pitcher be broken at the Fountain.
div.p:
For the right undertanding of this Sentence, and that which follows, which doth depend hereon, both of them belonging
to the vital Faculty, I mut crave leave to premie omething concerning the life of man, wherein it conits; and what thoe parts are, that do principally conduce to the production and preervation of it; for otherwie it is impoible to undertand thee Symptomes. For as the Propheies of Daniel, and mot others of the latter times,Dan. 12. 9. are cloed up and ealed till the time of the end, when their known accomplihments hall demontrate the truths contained in them: Jut thus hath it hapned to the great myterious truths contained in thee two lat expreions; foramuch as the frame, action, and ue of the heart, together with the true motion of the bloud in mans body, hath lain hid from the time of Solomon throughout all generations, unto this lat wherein we now live; the words of this Allegory that contain the um of that Doctrine, have all this while been an undicoverable mytery, as a book ealed up, that none could read or undertand. And as all thoe who have endeavoured to reveal the Revelations, that mut remain unrevealed till the appointed time of their revelation; have by all their indutry only declared their own weaknes and inufficiency for uch a work; And decribing at the bet rate they could the mytery of
Babylon, by their darknes and confuion, have only evinced that they themelves were a part thereof; even o all thoe that have undertaken the explication of what we are now about, before the Doctrine of Circulation was received among Men, and gave light to the World; have, with their utmot endeavours, only declared their own inability, and have left thee two Aenigmatical ymptomes far more intricate then they found them; And of all thoe ancient Commentators and Criticks that I have een upon the place (which has not been a few) I never had the leat content in any, but one; and that is he, who after he had et down the four ymptomes in this lat vere, he ubjoynes as his comment thee words, Haec quatuor ego non intelligo. Mot ingenious Catalio, had all Interpreters been o plain and honet, I perwade my elf we had had leer volumes, and yet far better undertanding of the ene of Scripture, then now we have.

Now, in order to the end propoed, we mut know in the firt place, that which the Scripture doth far above all other Writings mot clearly declare, and that is, that the Life of a Man conits in his Blood. For it is the Life, of all Fleh, the blood of it is for the life thereof; Lev. 17. 1 • . 14. therefore I aid unto
the children of Irael, ye hall eat the blood of no manner of fleh, for the life of all fleh is in the blood thereof. And this mot noble Liquor of Life hath a primary eat or fountain, where it is principally made, and from whence it is dipened throughout the whole Body; and this is none other then the Heart; for out of it are the isues of life, Prov. 4. 23. is a truth not onely Moral and Spiritual, but Natural alo. This part continually iueth forth abundance of blood, wherein is the life, to all the parts that are to be quickned thereby. Hence thoe Medicines that are of a quickning and enlivening vertue, are not unfitly called Cordialls, becaue they help the heart in its work, and do that by art, unto which the heart is by nature appointed: And urely between them there is a very great reemblance, which makes the Wie Man ay, A Merry Heart doth good like a Medicine. Prov. 17. 22. This wonderfull part of Man hath abundance of the widome of the Creatour hewed in its formation, in o much that none is able fully to comprehend it, for it is exceeding deep. Pal. 64. 6.

And that which is aid of the Kings heart, though in another ene, may as truly be aid of Mans heart in general, The heart of Man is unearchable. Prov. 25. 3 Yet thus much
cannot but be oberved by all thoe that take pleaure in earching out this great work of God, that it is the fountain of life, the firt living, and the lat dying part of Man, and that it doth communicate of its life and vigour to all the other parts of the Body, though at the extreamet ditance; which live or die, according as the beames and influences of this glorious Sun of the Body, are communicated unto, or intercepted from them. It is aid of Nabal, his heart dyed within him, and immediately he became as a tone; 1 Sam. 25. 37. If the heart give not forth its vivifying vertue, the fleh doth immediately fail; And there is no fear of the latter, if there be a continuation of the former, for a ound heart is the life of the fleh. Prov. 14. 13. My on give me thy heart, aith Solomon, Prov. 23. 26. intimating that that was vertually a gift of the whole. The overaignty and principallity of the Heart above all the other members of the body, might be abundantly confirmed from Scripture, but what hath been aid may uffice: Yet there is one place relating more particularly to the action and ue of the heart, that I would epecially note; and that is in our Englih Bookes, My heart is inditing a good matter: Pal. 45. 1. But here, as in many other places the Tranlation comes very hort of the Original,
and o the whole trength of the Metaphor is lot. < in non-Latin alphabet > , the word is not elewhere ued in the Bible, and therefore in this place greatly to be weighed, it hath two ignifications, which joyned together, make up the whole work of the heart.

The firt is fervere, ebullire, praeparare cibos; the other is cum impetu pr • trudere, longè eructare ive pulare; the heart gives heat, and motion, and life unto that which is to be our nourihment; and after that it doth with a certain force and vehemency cat it forth, and pule it to all, even the extreamet parts, that are thereby to be enlivened. And this in the Letter not having been undertood by Interpreters, makes them come farr hort alo in the Mytery; which is that the Doctrine of the Kingdom of Chrit (for that is the good thing that his heart is here inditing) having not as yet had its full meaure of trength and life in the World, and that which it formerly had, by reaon of the revolution of time, and circulation of Ages, being much weakned and enfeebled, is now again in Davids heart by the Spirit of the living God, impraegnated with new vigour, and thencefrom with great earnetnes puled forth to the Generations to come, even to the end, to utain and upport them,
and to quicken them all to their duty, and to a longing expectation of the Glorious Kingdom of their Lord. But to return to the Heart with the Blood: We mut farther know for the explication of thee ymptomes, that there are within the body of the heart, two firmly ditinct cavities, a right and a left, uually called Ventricles: from which there arie, and unto which there are annexed certain peculiar veels conducing to the ends hereafter pecified. Out of the right ventricle of the heart, proceed the great vein called Vena Cava, which ends forth branches throughout the whole body, and hath at its entrance into the heart, certain portals, from their form called valvulae tricupides; And alo that Artery, anciently called vena arterioa; inerted into the lungs, unto whoe original are annexed, the portals reembling the Greek Sigma, and are therefore called valvulae igmoideae, Out of the let Ventricle proceed that vein anciently called arteria venoa; inerted in like manner into the lungs; and alo the great Artery, called Arteria aorta, which dipeneth its branches throughout the whole Body, both whoe Cavities are defended with the like portals with the former. It remains onely that we hew how the blood and life is
actuated in thee parts, and howit paeth in, and through them, and in and through the whole habit of the Body; which is by way of Rotation, or running the round, going out from the fountain, and returning thither again.Eccle. 1. Ver. 5. The Sun arieth, and the Sun goeth down and hateth to the place where he aroe; The Wind goeth toward the South, and turneth about unto the North, Vere 6. it whirleth about continually, and the Wind returneth again according to its Circuits; Vere 7. All the Rivers run into the Sea, yet the Sea is not full; unto the place from whence the Rivers come, thither they return again. Thus it pleaeth the King to expres the Circulations of the greater World; thoe of the leer are no les remarkable. The Blood wherein is the Life of Man paeth about the Body continually, and returns according to its circuits; the treames thereof run into the fountain, which is never full, unto the place from whence they come, thither they return again; which is by the Intruments before mentioned thus performed. The Vena Cava containing much blood in its cavity, neer the bais of the Heart, on the right ide, doth gently pas it into the right Ventricle of the Heart, which is dilated in its Diatole for its reception, and immediately thereupon contracting its elf in its
Sytole (the three pointed Portals hindering the paage back again into the Cava) it mut necearily thrut the blood through the open paage of the Vena Arterioa (where the igmoidal Portals hindering its return) it mut pas through the Streiner of the Lungs, and o be received into the branches of the Arteria Venoa, and thereby brought into the left Ventricle of the Heart, where again it is with violence puled forth into the Aorta (the Portals here as before alwayes hindering its regres) by the branches of which Artery it is carried to all the parts of the Body to enliven them, which work being done, what remaines is received into the Capillaries of the Veines in the everal parts, whence it paeth of its own accord naturally towards its Center, from the leer into the greater branches of the veines, and conequently at lat into the great Trunk of the Cava, from whence it is recommitted into the right ventricle of the Heart, to be chaed the Foyl. This is the true Doctrine of the excellency and motion of the blood, and of the ue of the Heart, and the parts appertaining thereunto; all which were perfectly known to Solomon, as will abundantly appear anon, in the explication of the ymptomes we are now about. Yet it pleaed the Lord that this knowledge
hould with the poeor of it, ink into dut and darknes; where it lay buried for the pace of 2500 years at the leat, till it was retreived thence from by the widome and indutry of that incomparable, and for ever to be renouned Dr. William Harvey, the greatet honour of our Nation, and of all Societies of which he was a Member, who tands, and ever will do, with the highet note of Honour in the Calenders both of Phyicians and Philoophers, and it were but jutice to put him with the ame eminence into that of the Church, ince he hath Contributed more to the undertanding of this, and many other places of Scripture, then all that ever undertook that Charge.

Thee things being throughly weighed, and well undertood, the two ymptomes which remain to be poken to, do open themelves into the ame Doctrine without any more ado. By the Pitcher therefore we mut undertand the true and proper conceptacle of the Blood, namely the Veines, which throughout the whole body erve only as a veel, to contain that noble Liquor, and carry it back again to the Fountain. The Original word < in non-Latin alphabet > ignifieth ometime more generally any containing veel,1 King 17. 14. and o is taken for the Widows Barrel in which
was the meal,Gen. 24. 6. Judg. 7. 1. but more epecially that which is called a pitcher, and o more frequently it is ued. This word both the Greeks and the Latines take unto themelves, only varying the Termination as is mot proper to each Language, and that in the very ame ignification. Now the proper containing Veel for the bloud is the Veins, there the bloud is, as I may ay, at home, in its own place; while it is in the heart, it is preparing, enlivening, and enobling; while it is in the Lungs, and all the other Parenchymous parts of the bowels, it is depurating and cleaning; while it is in the Arteries, it is by force journeying; while it is in the Poroities of the flehy parts, it is communicating of life, and nourihing; but while it is in the Veins, it hath no force upon it at all, nor is it doing any thing of general ue to the Body, only conulting its own good, and tending in its own natural coure to its proper Center; as milk is in the breats, and marrow in the bones, o is bloud in the veins, and therefore thee are the Pitcher here intended. This Pitcher alo hath its Ear, which is uually called, Auricula Cordis; which (notwithtanding its name, as if it mot properly appertained to the heart) yet we mut know doth rather belong to the vein,
and is indeed a part thereof, and not only a part, but the principal and primary part thereof, from whence all other parts and branches do arie, as from their original, and whereunto all the bloud of the body by the Compreive motion of the Veins, doth naturally tend, as to its ultimate hold; and whence-from it will in no wie depart but by force; and therefore this head-pring of the veins being dilated by the continual afflux of bloud, is neceitated to eae it elf by Contraction, and o conveniently forceth out a due proportion of bloud into the Fountain, whereunto it is annexed.

Now the Fountain can be no other than the right Ventricle of the heart, for this is yet more trictly the fountain of life, and forge of the vital pirits, and it doth enibly live before, and dye after, the other parts, even of the heart it elf; Moreover, here it is, that the matter of our nourihment receiveth its firt enlivening, for our food being received from the tomack and guts into the common paage of Chyle, is thence-from carried directly into the ubclavial branch of the Vena Cava, where being mixed with bloud, it yet remains lifeles and heartles, till being carried along that vein, it is at lat brought
into the right Ventricle of the heart; wherein the heat, motion, and ferment, et the active principles thereof at a perfect freedom, and o intantly endow it with plenty both of life and pirit. Thus richly fraught, doth the bloud pas out of its fountain, and, by the waies before decribed, it is brought to all the parts of the body, where parting with much of its lading for their utentation, and being refrigerated by the coldnes of the extremities, and the ambient air; it would oon be coagulated, and altogether barren, did it not return again to the right Ventricle of the heart, as unto its own fountain, to recover its former perfection. This part therefore, that doth at the firt give life to that which enliveneth the whole man, and doth, as often as it returns thither, impraegnate it anew with the ame, mut needs be the fountain here intended. And to this the Original word gives an extraordinary clearnes; implying, not only the Signum, but the Signatum; not the Hieroglyphick only, but the part thereby deciphered: ignifying in the firt place, Fons, a Fountain; and econdarily, Scaturigo Venarum, the pring or original from whence the Veins arie; and this is o clear, that made ancient Commentators
interpret the Fountain here unto the Liver: Now, had they been right in their natural knowledge; that is, had they known that the Veins do not arie from the Liver, as from their firt original, but from the right Ventricle of the heart, (as all knowing men now confes they do,) they had without all doubt, by the guidance of this mot ignificant word, pitched upon the true meaning of the place.

Thee Veels being throughly undertood, we mut farther know, that o long as man remains in perfect health and trength, they are uncellantly and carefully performing all thoe offices unto which they are appointed; but this natural Coure doth not continue for ever, for this Pitcher is but an earthen Veel, and doth not o often go to the Fountain, but at lat it comes broken home. This breaking of the Pitcher here (which is the Symptome of old age jut upon the point of death) is the failing of the Veins, their ceaing from their natural action and ue, when they can no longer carry back, nor conveniently pas into the heart that liquor, which they properly contain. That little bloud that remains in the cold body of man near his end is oon Coagulated, and
tagnating in the Veins, the motion and circulation thereof is hindered, and o it becomes thick, like unto the pith of Elder; And becaue it cannot return to the fountain, for a redintegration of its life and pirit; it dyeth in the veins, and o all the extream parts of the body become piritles and cold; which is the Symptome here intended. Frigiditas extremorum is acknowledged by all that have conidered that ubject, as one of the mot certain igns of approaching death. And our great Mater of Prognoticks, in that compleat and yet compendious book of his Aphorims, doth once and again, not out of forgetfulnes, but out of earnetnes, that it may more epecially be taken notice of; give us that famous Maxime,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

div.head: The wheel broken at the Citern.
div.p: The Symptome lat poken of, had reference to the Intruments of the vital Faculty, which erve for importation, and reception of the bloud and pirits; this that we are now peaking to, hath reference to thoe, which erve for exportation and rejection of the ame.

The bloud (as was before oberved) naturally, of its own accord, tends in the
veins, unto the heart; but it returns not from the heart, into the parts of the body, but by force: Thus all the Rivers in the Land naturally ebb into the Sea, but they flow not thence-from, any farther, than the violence and impule of the Sea extends. The bloud, being once forced from the heart, is preently received into the Trunk of the great Artery, called the Aorta; and by the branches thereof is carried to all the parts of the body. This therefore being the chief and principal intrument of Rotation, or Circulation of the bloud, is mot aptly intimated unto us by a Wheel. For what is a Wheel, but an intrument of Circulation? And what can a Wheel be an Hieroglyphick of, but of omething that goes, or makes the round? And this is o obvious to every one, that all that have ever Commented upon this place, have been till hammering at ome uch thing. Some therefore have interpreted this place to the life of man, which paeth as in a Ring, according to that aying, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Others have interpreted it, to the death of man, when his compounding parts hall revert into the firt beings.

Cedit enim retro, de terra quod fuit ante, In terram, &c.
And o they make this expreion explained at large in the following vere; The dut hall return to the earth as it was, and the pirit hall return to God that gave it. Others interpret it to the reciprocal Communications between the heart and the head; the heart continually ending to the head, bloud and vital pirits; and the head again returning them to the heart, ublimed intruments of animality.

Latly, There are that ingeniouly interpret it to Repiration, which is performed by a circular motion, Inpiration, and Expiration continually ucceeding one another in their Coures. All thee Archers have hot exceeding well, and have hit the But, (while many others have hot at Rovers,) yet thee not being able to dicern the White, have not touched that principal Mark. I mean, the grand Circulation in mans body, not being known to thee ancient Commentators, they have done the bet that could be in the econd place. What this grand Circulation is, and how performed, hath been already decribed; and thoe veels that are inward bound, which bring home the noble Travellour, the encompaour of the little World, were decribed in the Explanation of the foregoing Symbole; but thoe which are
outward bound, which carry him forth with all his wealth and ubtance to accomplih his intended end, are here intimated unto us by the Wheel. That the great Artery, with all its branches throughout the whole body, is here principally pointed at, hath been already aid; and may be farther confirmed; firt, in that it anwers o directly to the vein ignified in the lat Symptome, by the Pitcher. Secondly, In that it is to us the mot apparent Pulor; we can feel the bloud to be forced along its Cavity, in the Writs, the Temples, and divers other parts of the body. Latly, in that it is o appoitely placed at the Cock of the Citern, as you hall hear hereafter. Yet we mut not o limit this Wheel to the Arteries, as to exclude the very ubtance and Parenchymous part of the heart it elf: For upon whatoever Intruments the pulifick faculty is exerciing it elf, they are all here intended, by the Wheel; for they are they, and they only, that carry off the bloud from the fountain, and force it from the Center of the body, to the Circumference. Water may eaily be conveyed in Trunks or Pipes, by its own natural tendency only, unto all thoe places that are beneath or level with the Spring from whence it firt comes; but if
you would have it of a farther ue, to erve thoe places that are higher than the pring, you mut then fetch it up with violence, by a Wheel, or ome uch Intrument of force, as is to be een in our Waterhoues, and all uch ingenious Inventions of publick good. Thus all the bloud in mans body is, in certain Pipes and Trunks, by its own natural tendency only, brought home to the heart; but it will in no wie go farther, to be of a more general ue to the whole body, till it have ome Intrument of force to compel it thence-from; The Pulifick faculty is the mover, and the Intruments of Pulation the Wheel, that performs this work, that is of o publick a concern to the whole.

The Cistern from whence this Wheel forceth that liquor which afterwards it conveyeth throughout all the parts, is the left Ventricle of the heart, for hereunto it is, that the great Artery is annexed, and from hence it doth arie. A Citern is a Veel made on purpoe to receive a due proportion of water, and to contain it till the time of ue, and then conveniently to pas it into thoe other veels, that are appointed to receive it thence-from. And thus the left Ventricle of the heart doth in its Diatole, receive that bloud that is
brought unto it by the Arteria Venoa of the Lungs, and having retained it a little, it doth in its Systole, conveniently pas a due proportion thereof into the Aorta, to be dipened as was poken before; And this is the true and only ue of the left Ventricle. For the bloud being enobled and enlivened in the right Ventricle, and refrigerated, and cleaned from its fuliginous vapours in the Lungs, it is now in all things accomplihed for its ultimate ue, and remains only to be ent, into thoe everal parts it is to quicken, which it cannot conveniently be, unles it be firt received into this Citern, and afterwards by the Pulifick Faculty and Intruments, be dipoed of, to that appointed end; and we cannot but here remind, thoe portals that are placed, both at the entrance into, and paage from, the veel we are now peaking of, namely, the Valvulae tricupides & igmoideae, which as the Cocks to let in, and let out, do by their opening or hutting give convenient paage, or abolute toppage to that liquor which continually runs that way.

It cannot but by this time be acknowledged by all thoe that have gone along with us, and taken pecial notice of the aptnes of thee two expreions, viz. The
Pitcher at the Fountain, and the Wheel at the Citern, to ymbolize unto us the circulation of the bloud, and the ue and action of the heart, and the parts belonging thereunto; that the Doctrine which is now jutly called Harvaean, was at firt Solomonian. For as it pleaed God in thee latter daies to give in this certain and mot ueful knowledge, to the indutrious and indefatigable endeavours of the Learned Dr. Harvey; o did he of old, give in the ame, unto King Solomon in the lump, together with all other natural knowledge, as a uperabundant anwer to his fervent and effectual Prayer; which great truth being confirmed by the powerful reaons and ocular demontrations of the one, and by this divine tetimony of the other, let it not be for the future in the leat meaure doubted or quetioned; but let it be greatly prized, and o much the rather, becaue (while many others of great importance, wherein thee two Worthies doubtles agreed, have perihed by the way,) this only from them both, hath ecaped afe to our hands.

And thus I have as plainly, and as briefly as I could, run over all thee mytical Symptomes; both thoe that attend a man all the time of his declining age, and thoe that more immediately forerun, and foretell his lat change. And now I judge it time for me to deit, when all ene and motion, both in the Rivulets and Fountain is quite taken away, when there is death in the face, when there is a coldnes in the extremities, and an utter abolition of the Pule, there is no more room for the Phyician, or
pace given him to intermeddle any longer: Thus far I hope I have kept within my bounds, and given no offence to thoe jealous Overeers, to whom only the interpretation of Scripture is deemed to belong; this Subject hath been purely Phyical, wherefore in the proecution of it, I have not exceeded my own Lat, nor made a breach upon that politick Rule:
Quod medicorum et,
Per tractent medici; tractent fabrilia fabri.
It remains only that we review, and um up, what hath been here poken, and o gather cloe together that plentiful crop of mieries which this Earth we bear about us, naturally produceth.

If what I have aid, may erve only to tell Men, that there is a Treaure hid in this Field, and withall to hew of what nature, and what value it is, and which way the veines of it do ecretly pas under ground, I hall have my full end thereby. For howoever I may, in my own earch, in digging and delving after it, mix earth, and dirt, and rubbih, with Silver, and Gold, and precious Stones; yet it will, without all doubt, give occaion to all thoe, who love and long after the Acquiition of uch Treaures as thee, to come to the place where they are to be had. The Word of God doth upon many Subjects of Natural things, though but briefly and incidently mentioned, give a clearer and more ure light, then all the voluminous Writings of the whole hoale of Heathenih Philoophers. He that planted the Ear hall he not hear, P. 94. 9. and he that made the Eye, hall he not ee? P. 103. 14. he knowes our frame, and the frame of all things that he hath made; and therefore whatoever he aith concerning any of them, ought mot diligently to be hearkned unto, as to the bet and truet word that was ever poken about them. This great Truth, I know, many Learned
Men are not aware of, and none but thoe that do < in non-Latin alphabet > , earch the Scriptures, and dig in them, as for hid Treaure, can ever undertand. The labour that I have taken upon thee ix veres, I am o far confident of, as that it hath made this truth appear upon the Subject we are now treating of, as I have already done upon ome others, epecially that, De formatione foetus in utero materno. And following the commendable intentions of Levinus Lemnius, Valleius, Bueus, and other Learned Men; and the Pious Exhortation of the Honourable Mr. Boyle thereupon,Natural Philoophy, p 31. if God give me life and opportunity, I may yet further cultivate the ame Theame. My deign is plainly to perwade Men to be in love with the Scrip • ure; that as ome looking after eternal Life, have therein by the way, found out many Natural things; o others looking after Natural things only, may yet far more happily find eternal Life: like Zacheus gazing after the Novelties of the World, and yet being in the way where Christ paed by, they may hear that joyful voice of Salvation being brought to their Houe; Necio quo modo acrorum librorum lectio, Vall • ius ac, Philoo. in proae •• io. etiam hitorica aut Phyica, animum pietate imbuit latenter. This eternal concern is the principal drif • of thee
Holy Writings of God, yet they are every where beprinkled with abundance of other Truths of les concernment, which will give great delight and atisfaction to the diligent enquirer: For they are as the Garden of God, Wherein groweth every Tree that is pleaant to the ight, Gen. 2. 9. and good for food, the Tree of Life alo in the middet of the Garden. I mut confes with others that there are many Natural things herein contained, that are inconitant and contrary to what we have learned in the Schooles, but that matters not; let us be ure to make God wie, and him true; though every Man a fool, and a liar. There are alo ome things which will tartle and amaze the bet humane reaon, nay, that which is much farther, ome things that our enes will hardly give conent unto; yet in all thee difficult caes, I have had a ready olution (which although it will not untie all thoe intricate knots I meet with, yet it will looe them, which is full as atisfactory) and that is, that grace and gift of God which is < in non-Latin alphabet > , & < in non-Latin alphabet > .Heb. 11. 1.

I have I hope by this time done a double good work, on the one hand I have vindicated our profeion, from all thoe abominable and filthy candals, that impudent
and malevolent Perons have been apt to cat upon it; as though the tudies we addicted our elves unto, did (like the Sin of Adam) naturally make us run from God, and hide our elves from him, and patch up ome perihing remnants to cover our nakednes, after our own contrivances: whereas in truth, there is nothing in all the World, that Man can be buied about, that will ooner bring him to God, then the earnet beholding him in the Book of the Creatures; there is not the mot contemptible being, which by virtue of the Almighty Fiat, at firt tarted out of nothing, that will not (if it be throughly earched and followed) at length bring us home to its eternal Father; As of him, and from him, Rom. 11. 36. and through him; o to him alo are all things, to whom be glory for ever. But how much more hall we be intructed in this Divine Leon, by intimately contemplating that Heavenly Work of Works, the umm and height of the viible Creation, that honourable piece, tantum non Angelicall, in which the Creatour himelf, reted in time, delighted from Eternity, being the true pattern of his own Divine Image; Man. And God in his Providence having o ordered, that the Holy Writings hould begin, with the Hitory of the Creation of
all things, and latly and chiefly of Man; doth plainly teach us this leon, that none are o Idoneous hearers, or o meet receivers of the words of his mouth, as thoe that have firt well undertood and abundantly admired the Works of his hand. All which fall under our conideration, as the proper ubject of our knowledg, but chiefly the chiefet, which cannot but in the end bring us to him, who made and knowes all things, as the aying of the Woman did the Samaritans, John 4. 39. 42. and being hereby brought unto him, we afterwards hear him our elves, and believe now, for his own word ake; That he is God, and the Father of our Lord Jeus Chrit, the Saviour of the World.

We are o far from lighting or contemning the Scripture, that we are the great admirers of it, and do endeavour to advance it above all other Writings whatoever, and that even in Natural things, though never o accidentally or curorily handled; and we had rather that all our other Books, though very curious, and greatly valuable, hould be burnt; then that one line, nay one letter, one jot, or tittle of it hould in any wie pas away.

And on the other hand, I hope I have perwaded and prevailed with all my own
Brethren, to be more wie for themelves, and more wary in repect of others, then ome evere and jealous-headed cenorours have judged them to be: that we may none of us give the leat occaion for any one to peak evil of the things they undertand not; but by taking heed to a ure Rule, we may bring perpetual honour to our own faculty, and hame to the looe profeors of a better. A light and uperficial knowledg of Natural things, may indeed conit with Atheime, but a deep and a profound earch into them, doth bring Men back again to God, and necearily bind them over to Religion. Solomons Widome tayed not in the Creatures, though he perfectly knew o great a variety; but did from them onely (as it were) take its rie, and mount higher then the Cedars, even into Heaven its elfe, and there onely could find its ret, from whence it had its firt beginning, like the pirit of man, returning to God that gave it. Let no Man think he hath ufficient knowledg in Natural things, who hath not by them been directed to Divine, or that he hath viewed the Creatures enough, who hath not been lead through them to the Creatour. Nor hall ever any one have my conent to pas for a Philoopher, who keeps himelf o ignorant of the
Scripture,Act. 17. 23. as with Devotion to admire that Academical Incription, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Knowledg Natural and Spiritual are not o contrary one to another, but that they may very well agree together, and cohabit in the ame Manion: nay, they are greatly conductive to the growth and promotion of each other. None can be a better Evangelit then the beloved Phyician, and none o compleat a Phyician, as he who is frequently converant in the Word of God; and able to Evangelize: For that is the Fountain that ends forth plentifully of both thee Waters, and is alone able to make a Man perfect, throughly furnihed to every good work.

Now in the lat place I mut acknowledge, upon the review of what is here written, that there are many things herein (I my elf being Judg) which might have been delivered after another manner, much more cononant to thoe plauible and probable Doctrines which are the products of the Indutry and Ingenuity of this Inquiitive Age. It is far more eaie to be Sceptical, and to overthrow the poitive aertions of others, then to produce anew thoe which will prove more firm and lating, or to intaurate better in their room. But I quetion not but the good intention hereof,
will among all honet and Candid Perons, in ome meaure, compenate for all thoe micarriages; epecially ince by this leading attempt, in a way o obcure and difficult, and withall o untrodden, Men of the greatet parts and abilities will be induced for the future to tep into, and to become painfull labourers in, the Vineyard of God.

Which will be a mot acceptable work to the whole Chritian World, and mot honourable to themelves; For as Hiram was eminent in Tyre, for his Widom, Undertanding,1 King 7. 14. and Cunning in all manner of Workmanhip, yet that which crowned all his Excellencies, and renowned him to this very day, was, that he came to the adorning of the Temple of God at Jerualem. Thoe Learned Men who exercie themelves in Natural Philoophy alone, produce onely Newes-Books for the preent Generation, and o a little time doth conume all together: Whereas the labour that is taken in the Word of God, is of a far more durable nature, and is like to run Parallel with everlating truth.

But yet more particularly, I cannot but call for help upon this individual Subject: It is my earnet deire that Phyicians would tudy the Gerocomical part of Phyick
more then they do: And indeed no part wants our help o much as this; for among all the Verboious Graecians there is not one compleat Tract upon this Subject onely: And there are but very few to be found among all other Writers, and thoe o mierable and barren, that the Readers are left exceedingly in the dark, and can carcely be reolved in the firt quetion belonging thereunto, namely to what part of Phyick it mot properly appertaines. That one Aphorime of Hippocrates which a Man might eaily prove (would it not give occaion to ome foul-Mouthed Libellers farther to detract from the reverence due to Antiquity) is not Totum teres atque rotundum, Lib. 3. Ap • o. ult. perfect and compleat in all things; hath carce been out-done for thee 2000 ucceeding years.

div.p:
The reaons why Perons in this Age fall o oon into this decrepit tate, and why the mieries thereof are o multiplied and magnified upon them, is, becaue either they call not in oon enough for help, or becaue thoe that are called in, either undertand not, or minde not what they ought to do. An honet and an able Phyician, may urely approve himelf to his ancient Patient (as Ruthe's Son was to
his Grandmother,) A retorer of life, Ruth 4. 15. and nouriher of old age. Much, without all quetion, may be done by humane knowledge, for the retarding and keeping off Old Age for a competent eaon; and for the quitting and clearing of it, from that multitude of grievances that do o eaily beet it: Though the Completion of this work be reerved in Gods own hand, until he hall bring that happy tate upon his People, which was typified by Moes, Who when he was one hundred and twenty years old, Deut. 34. 7. had not his eye dim, nor his natural force abated. And was plainly propheied by Iaiah, aying,Ia. 65. 20. There hall be no more thence an infant of daies, nor an old man that hath not filled his daies, for the child hall dye an hundred years old.

And yet farther, it eems not to me in the leat incongruous to Chritian Religion to affirm, that life it elf may be prolonged. There are certain waies and methods that have a natural tendency in them either to life or death:Prov. 11: 19. As righteounes tendeth unto life, o he that purueth evil, purueth it to his own death. Abbreviation and prolongation of life tand upon the ame foundation, and the elf-ame arguments either confirm them, or overthrow them both together. Now mot
certain it is,Pal. 55. 23. that evil men hall not live out their daies; And as certain it eems to me, that good men hall out-live their daies, ele what means that promie of additional life;Pro 3. 2. My on forget not my Law, but l • t thine heart keep my Commandments, for length of daies, and long life, and peace hall they add unto thee. Yet the words of Job are everlatingly true,Job 14. 5. The daies of man are determined, the number of his months are with God, he hath appointed his bounds that he cannot pas; His Precience and Predetermination do not at all hinder the influences of naturall Caues, but he knows and dipoeth of them alo, equally with their effects. And thus thoe things, that are with us reputed the mot contingent, are alo fore-een and fore-ordered, as well as others.1 King. 22. 34. The drawing of a Bow of a certain man at a venture, was as well known and determined, as the death of that King that fell thereby. The whole Story of Hezechiah's life and death was alike predetinated;Ia 38. yet he was ick unto death, and had then certainly died, had not God lengthned out his life yet fifteen years, and had he not followed his appointment in making ue of the Plaiter of Figs. Pauls mot comfortable words in his dangerous Voyage to Rome,
There hall be no los of any mans life among you, Act. 27. 22, 31. was a true report of the ure unchangeable and Eternal Counel of God: Yet had not the hipmen abode in the hip, they could not have been aved. The death and continuation of life of every man, and of every individual living Creature is certainly determined; yet they hall both of them as necearily follow their contituted means, as day and night, do the preence or abence of the Sun.

But yet once more, it is more than probable, that uch noble medicines may be found out and precribed, that may innovate the trength of all the parts of old men, and bring their Temperament back again to equality; that may o fortifie nature, and conume or expell whatoever is contrary thereunto; as life and vigour may be retored to uch a meaure, which may afely be called, The renewing of youth. It is aid of Captain Naaman the Leper, after he had made ue of the Ordinance of God for his recovery, that his fleh came again like the fleh of a little child, 2 King 5. 17. and he was clean. And thus through the bleing of God upon our weak endeavours, we dayly ee brought again from the Graves mouth, and retored to perfect health and trength, many that were Confecti
morbo, pent and conumed with a dieae, and why ome that are Confecti enio, wated with age, may not in like manner be renewed, eems not at all impoible. Nay, this Elihu, one of Jobs friends, doth abundantly prove, from the power and providence of God, when he aith;Job 33. 25. His fleh hall be freher than a childs, he hall return to the daies of his youth. And thoe Critical returns of nature, (which are vulgarly called lightnings before death) that do uually continue but for two or three hours or daies at the mot; are notwithtanding ometime by the trength of nature only; lengthned out to o many weeks or months; and there can no reaon be given, why a skilful and uccesful Artit, may not be made intrumental for the farther prolonging them, with greater comfort, to o many years or Lutra's. The whole Creation now grown old expecteth and waiteth for a certain rejuvenecency,Rom. 8. 19, 2. with which ere long it hall urely be bleed: In the mean time, this is preented unto us in a figure, in thoe everal Transformations and Renovations of the Ant, and Silk-worm, and many uch Inectiles, which are oon brought to extream old age by their inceant labour, in recompence whereof, by a wonderful Metamorphois
they are renewed into brisk and lively Flies. And there are abundance of more perfect Creatures alo, which depoiting their old skins, or hels, or ome uch emblem of their age, are at certain eaons brought back again to a youthful tate, and uch are Snakes, Lizzards; Crabs, Crevies; Eagles, King-fihers, and uch like; and why ome uch thing as this, or at leat omething Analogous hereunto, may not be wrought upon man, the mot perfect Creature of all the earth, I am ure no one can give an account. David in his Doxology intimates, that there may, aying, concerning God in his Providences; He atisfieth thy mouth with good things, o that thy youth is renewed like the Eagles. Pal. 103. 5. Yet were not thee things thus viibly demontrated to us, God might in his < in non-Latin alphabet > alter the Coure wherein hitherto he hath manifeted himelf;Eph. 3. 10 And in ome things he hath given us aurance that he will; the way that hitherto he hath been pleaed to take to bring our bodies to glory and immortality, hath been through miery, dut, and darknes, but in the lat day he will take a nearer coure to do the ame thing; 1 Cor. 15. 51, 52. Behold, I hew you a mystery, we hall not all leep, but we hall all be changed, in a moment, in the twinckling
of an eye at the lat trump, for the Trumpet hall ound, and the dead hall be raied incorruptible, and we hall be changed.

Thee Magnalia naturae, (viz. the preventing, alleviating, and curing (as far as is attainable) the dieaes before mentioned, the retarding of Age, the prolonging of Life, the renewing of Youth,) that have carce entred the thoughts of Vulgar Pretenders to Phyick; have been as unto the practick part under our Conideration, with like care and indutry, as what you here ee in the Theory; and that from principles gathered up, not only from reaon, reading, and experience; but from ome eminent intructive expreions of Holy Writ, which are not obvious to every curory and uperficial Reader: all which may alo be communicated to you in a convenient eaon.
